'''James McMurtry''' (born March 18, 1962, in [[Fort Worth, Texas]])<ref>{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p4878}}</ref> is an American rock and folk rock/[[Americana (music)|americana]] singer, songwriter, guitarist, bandleader, and occasional actor (''[[Daisy Miller (film)|Daisy Miller]]'', ''[[Lonesome Dove (TV miniseries)|Lonesome Dove]]'', and narrator of ''Ghost Town: 24 Hours in Terlingua''). He performs with veteran bandmates Daren Hess, Cornbread and Tim Holt.

His father, novelist [[Larry McMurtry]], gave him his first guitar at age seven. His mother, an English professor, taught him how to play it: "My mother taught me three chords and the rest I just stole as I went along. I learned everything by ear or by watching people."

==Biography==
McMurtry spent his first seven years in Ft. Worth<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hobotrashcan.com/2008/04/17/one-on-one-with-james-mcmurtry/ |title=One on One with James McMurtry |publisher=HoboTrashcan |date=2008-04-17 |access-date=2012-11-21}}</ref> but was raised mostly in [[Leesburg, Virginia]]. He attended the [[Woodberry Forest School]], [[Orange, Virginia]]. He began performing in his teens, writing bits and pieces.  He started performing his own songs at a downtown [[beer garden]] while studying English and Spanish at the [[University of Arizona]] in [[Tucson]]. After traveling to [[Alaska]] and playing a few gigs, he returned to [[Texas]] and his father's  "little bitty ranch house crammed with 10,000 books". After a time, he left for [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], where he worked as a house painter, actor, bartender, and sometimes singer, performing at writers' nights and open-mic events.

In 1987, a friend in San Antonio suggested McMurtry enter the Kerrville Folk Festival New Folk songwriter contest; he became one of six winners that year. Also around this time [[John Mellencamp]] was starring in a film based on a script by McMurtry's father, which gave McMurtry the opportunity to send a demo tape to Mellencamp. Mellencamp subsequently served as co-producer on McMurtry's debut album, ''[[Too Long in the Wasteland]]'' (1989). McMurtry also appeared on the soundtrack of the film ''[[Falling from Grace (film)|Falling from Grace]]'', working with Mellencamp, [[John Prine]], [[Joe Ely]] and [[Dwight Yoakam]] in a "supergroup" called Buzzin' Cousins.

McMurtry released follow-up albums ''[[Candyland (James McMurtry album)|Candyland]]'' (1992) and ''Where'd You Hide the Body'' (1995). 1997 saw the release of "It Had to Happen" which included a cover of "[[Wild Man from Borneo (song)|Wild Man from Borneo]]" originally done by Kinky Friedman and "[[Sixty Acres]]"; a rollicking tune about a dead grandma and the events afterwards.

''Walk Between the Raindrops'' followed in 1998 and 2002 brought ''St. Mary of the Woods''. In April 2004, McMurtry released a tour album called ''Live in Aught-Three''. "[[Choctaw Bingo]]", one of McMurtry's most popular songs, is featured on both ''St. Mary of the Woods'' and ''Live in Aught-Three''.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/the_spectator/2009/03/choctaw_bingo.html|author=Rosenbaum, Ron|title=Choctaw Bingo : A modest proposal for a new national anthem|journal=SLATE|date=13 March 2009|access-date=13 March 2009}}</ref>

In 2005, McMurtry released his first studio album in three years. ''[[Childish Things]]'' again received high critical praise, winning the song and album of the year at the 5th Annual [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Awards]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. The album was perhaps McMurtry at his most political, as his working-class anthem "We Can't Make It Here" included direct criticism of [[George W. Bush]], the [[Iraq War]], and [[Wal-Mart]]. The music critic [[Robert Christgau]] ranked "We Can't Make It Here" as the best song of the 2000s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/list/rs00.php |title=Rolling Stone Ballot: The 00's Best Songs & Albums |publisher=Robert Christgau |access-date=2012-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102174101/http://robertchristgau.com/xg/list/rs00.php |archive-date=2010-01-02 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

McMurtry released his follow-up album to ''[[Childish Things]]'' in April 2008. ''[[Just Us Kids]]'' continued with the previous album's political themes and included the song "Cheney's Toy," McMurtry's most direct criticism of [[George W. Bush]] so far. Like "We Can't Make It Here" from the previous album, "Cheney's Toy" was made available as a free Internet download.

McMurtry's ninth album, ''[[Complicated Game (album)|Complicated Game]]'' was released on February 24, 2015 on an L.A. record label also named Complicated Game.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/11/04/james-mcmurtry-returns-with-howm-i-gonna-find-you-now-from-new-lp-exclusive/ |title=James McMurtry Returns With 'How'm I Gonna Find You Now' From New LP (Exclusive)|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=4 November 2014|publisher=The Wall St Journal |access-date=2014-11-07|last1=Danton|first1=Eric R.}}</ref> The album achieved critical acclaim, scoring 87 on Metacritic. Lead single "How’m I Gonna Find You Now" and other tracks such as album opener "Copper Canteen" have become staples in the McMurtry canon.{{citation needed|date=November 2021}}<ref>{{Cite web|title=James McMurtry tour statistics|url=https://www.setlist.fm/stats/james-mcmurtry-3bd798bc.html|website=Setlist.fm}}</ref>

''Cold and Bitter Tears: The Songs of Ted Hawkins'', released in late 2015 on Austin-based Eight 30 Records, includes McMurtry's take on the late busker's song "Big Things". Additionally, ''Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay'', released in early 2016 (also on Eight 30 Records), features McMurtry's version of Finlay's "Comfort's Just a Rifle Shot Away."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dreamer-a-tribute-to-kent-finlay-mw0002916063 |title=Various Artists: Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay |work=AllMusic }}</ref>

McMurtry contributed his rendition of Adam Carroll's "Screen Door" to ''Highway Prayer: A Tribute to Adam Carroll'' (Eight 30 Records, 2016) as well as "Grandpa's Promise" to the satirical album ''Floater: A Tribute to the Tributes to Gary Floater'' (Eight 30 Records, 2018).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eight30records.com/|title=Eight 30 Records|website=Eight 30 Records|access-date=24 April 2018}}</ref> Also in 2018 McMurtry performed at the Vancouver Folk Music Festival.<ref>[https://vancouverweekly.com/41st-vancouver-folk-music-festival-still-true-to-tradition-still-young-at-heart-61154-2/ "41st Vancouver Folk Music Festival still true to tradition, still young at heart"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190713225922/https://vancouverweekly.com/41st-vancouver-folk-music-festival-still-true-to-tradition-still-young-at-heart-61154-2/ |date=2019-07-13 }}. July 14, 2018 , ''Vancouver Weekly'', Paul Hecht and Elmira Kuznetsova</ref>

During restrictions on touring and live music imposed by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States]], McMurtry started streaming several live acoustic performances a week on Facebook and YouTube. After using this platform to premiere new songs including "If It Don't Bleed", a new album, ''The Horses and the Hounds'', was announced on June 9, 2021 and released on August 20. Lead track "Canola Fields" was released to streaming services at the time of the announcement and would go on to get an Americana Music Award nomination. The album, produced by longtime collaborator Russ Hogarth and recorded at Jackson Browne's Santa Monica [[Groove Masters]] studio, was reviewed positively, scoring an 81 on Metacritic.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=James McMurtry Is Hung Up on the Details|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/james-mcmurtry-horses-and-the-hounds-album-1214772/|magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The Horses and the Hounds by James McMurtry|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/the-horses-and-the-hounds/james-mcmurtry|website=Metacritic}}</ref> Pitchfork reviewer [[Stephen Deusner]] said of the record: "McMurtry sounds more engaged here, more focused, and more generous to his hard-luck characters."<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Horses and the Hounds|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/james-mcmurtry-the-horses-and-the-hounds/}}</ref>

McMurtry lives in [[Lockhart, Texas]], 30 miles south of [[Austin, Texas]] where, until recently, he and The [[Heartless Bastards]] regularly played a midnight set at The Continental Club on Wednesday nights after [[Jon Dee Graham]], another Austin roots rock musician.<ref>{{Cite web|title=James McMurtry Remains The Harbinger Of American Truth|url=https://glidemagazine.com/228503/james-mcmurtry-remains-the-harbinger-of-american-truth-interview/|website=Glide Magazine|date=11 July 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=James McMurtry releases new live EP to benefit Continental Club|url=https://www.statesman.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/09/02/james-mcmurtry-releases-new-live-ep-to-benefit-continental-club/42521801/|website=Austin American-Statesman}}</ref>

McMurtry's son, Curtis, is also a singer-songwriter and has performed with his father, as well as filling in for his father's Tuesday night solo residency at The Continental Club when James is on tour.

| [[Linda Feferman]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQsEAAAAMBAJ&dq=james+mcmurtry+%22levelland%22+video+%22directed+by%22&pg=PA35|title=Learning About 'Real Life' Directing: Students Take Plunge On McMurtry Clips|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|last=Atwood|first=Brett|date=1995-07-29|accessdate=2021-12-13|archive-url=https://archive.today/20211213085611/https://books.google.com/books?id=yQsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=james+mcmurtry+%22levelland%22+video+%22directed+by%22&source=bl&ots=0R6p0hPViU&sig=ACfU3U0fdF1vknzBug2fQnMuzsscqmWjQA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjm9_LJ6tr0AhWaLc0KHUzEBXYQ6AF6BAgLEAM%23v=onepage&q=james%20mcmurtry%20%22levelland%22%20video%20%22directed%20by%22&f=false|archive-date=2021-12-13|url-status=live}}</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=November 2010}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name = Jay Farrar
| image = Jay Farrar (freeloosedirt).jpg
| caption = Farrar in Los Angeles in 2007
| background = solo_singer
| birth_name = Jay Stuart Farrar<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/310921894 |title=ALL OF YOUR MIGHT |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023}}</ref>
| alias = Cane Skretteburg
| birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1966|12|26}}
| birth_place = [[Belleville, Illinois]], United States
| death_date = 
| instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|harmonica}}
| genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative rock]]|[[alternative country]]|[[blues rock]]}}
| years_active = 1984–present
| label = {{flatlist|
* Giant/Rockville
* [[Sire Records|Sire]]
* [[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]
* [[Artemis Records|Artemis]]
* Act/Resist
* [[Legacy Recordings|Legacy]]
}}
| associated_acts = [[Uncle Tupelo]], [[Son Volt]], [[Gob Iron]] 
| website =
}}

'''Jay Stuart Farrar''' (born December 26, 1966) is an American songwriter and musician currently based in [[St. Louis]].  A member of two critically acclaimed music groups, [[Uncle Tupelo]] and [[Son Volt]], he began his solo music career in 2001.  Beyond his established talents as a songwriter, he is a guitarist, pianist, harmonicist, and a vocalist.

==Uncle Tupelo==
Farrar formed [[Uncle Tupelo]] with [[Jeff Tweedy]] and [[Mike Heidorn]] in 1987 after the lead singer of their previous band, The Primatives, left to attend college. The trio recorded three albums for Rockville Records, before signing with Sire Records and expanding to a five-piece. Shortly after the release of the band's major label debut album [[Anodyne (album)|''Anodyne'']], Farrar announced his decision to leave the band owing to a soured relationship with his co-songwriter Tweedy. Uncle Tupelo is often mentioned as one of the originators of the [[Alternative country|alt-country]] genre of music or subgenre of country music that combines country, folk and/or bluegrass with punk rock, alt-rock, indie rock or other generes.

==Son Volt==
{{see also|Son Volt#Discography}}
After the dissolution of [[Uncle Tupelo]] in 1994, Farrar formed the rock group [[Son Volt]], whose original lineup released three albums in the late 1990s, before undergoing a hiatus in 1999. In 1999, Farrar was invited to participate in the [[tribute album]] for [[Moby Grape]] co-founder [[Skip Spence]], who was terminally ill with cancer. The album, ''[[More Oar: A Tribute to the Skip Spence Album]] '' ([[Birdman Records|Birdman]], 1999), was an album of [[cover version]]s of the songs on Spence's only solo album, ''[[Oar (Skip Spence album)|Oar]]'' ([[Columbia Records|Columbia]], 1999). In 2005, the band re-formed with a different lineup and has since released seven additional albums.

==Other==
{{see also|Jay Farrar discography}}
In 1995, Farrar collaborated with Kelly Willis on the song "Rex's Blues", which appeared on the [[AIDS]] benefit album [[Red Hot + Bothered]] produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]].

As a solo artist, Farrar has released two full-length albums, two EPs, one film score, and various live recordings.  His full-length albums are ''[[Sebastopol (album)|Sebastopol]]'' (2001) and ''[[Terroir Blues]]'' (2003), the first released on the [[independent record label]] Artemis Records and the second released on his own label, Transmit Sound.

An EP of songs from the ''Sebastopol'' sessions, entitled ''ThirdShiftGrottoSlack'' was released in 2002.  His score for the [[independent film]] ''The Slaughter Rule'' (2002, directors Alex and Andrew Smith) was released in 2003 on the independent record label Bloodshot Records.  Farrar formed his own independent record label in 2003, '''Transmit Sound''' (formerly called "Act/Resist Records").

In 2004, Farrar released a six-song live acoustic EP entitled ''Live EP''. Also 2004 marked the release of the live CD/DVD ''[[Stone, Steel & Bright Lights]]''.

Farrar worked closely with keyboardist [[Steven Drozd]] of [[The Flaming Lips]] during the recording of ''Sebastopol''. Eric Heywood, [[Mark Spencer (guitarist)|Mark Spencer]] from the [[Blood Oranges (band)|Blood Oranges]], and the rock group [[Canyon (indie rock band)|Canyon]] have often accompanied Farrar in his solo recordings and performances. Spencer is now a full-time member of Son Volt.

In 2006, Farrar announced the formation of a new band, [[Gob Iron]], with Varnaline's Anders Parker. The songs which would make up their debut album were recorded in autumn 2004, while Farrar was in the process of recording a new Son Volt album. In April 2019, Parker and Farrar released a [[single (music)|7-inch single]] using the Gob Iron moniker.

Farrar collaborated with [[Ben Gibbard]] (of the indie rock band [[Death Cab for Cutie]]) to create all of the music for the soundtrack for the 2009 documentary film ''One Fast Move or I'm Gone'', about [[Jack Kerouac]]'s time spent at [[Big Sur]]. The [[One Fast Move or I'm Gone|soundtrack]] was released on October 20, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267721/death-cabs-ben-gibbard-jay-farrar-team-up-for-kerouac-soundtrack|title="Death Cab's Ben Gibbard, Jay Farrar Team Up For Kerouac Soundtrack"|author=Michael D. Ayers|website=Billboard.com|access-date=13 August 2009}}</ref>

In 2012, Farrar, along with [[Will Johnson (musician)|Will&nbsp;Johnson]], [[Jim James|Yim&nbsp;Yames]], and [[Anders Parker]] collaborated on the [[Woody Guthrie]] archive project, ''[[New Multitudes]]''.

==Style==
His musical style ranges from sparse, unaccompanied [[folk music]] to full [[rock and roll]] band arrangements comparable to [[Neil Young]] or [[Dinosaur Jr.]] His solo recordings also often include sound experiments, reminiscent of psychedelia, with a distinct [[Eastern world|Eastern]] bent. One of the hallmarks of his sound is the use of alternate tunings on the [[guitar]]. His love for Woody Guthrie inspired a custom guitar made by [[Creston Electric Instruments|Creston Lea]] of Vermont. The guitar was made from artifacts Jay gathered from the site of Guthrie's childhood home.

{{Short description|American musician (born 1967)}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name             = Jeff Tweedy
| image            = Jeff Tweedy 20120122-00075 (33423676505).jpg
| image_upright    = 
| image_size       = 
| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->
| alt              = 
| caption          = Tweedy performing in 2012
| background       = solo_singer
| birth_name       = Jeffrey Scot Tweedy
| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1967|8|25}}
| birth_place      = [[Belleville, Illinois]], U.S.
| genre            = {{hlist|[[Alternative country]]|[[alternative rock]]|[[indie rock]]|[[country rock]]}}
| occupation       = {{hlist|Musician|singer|songwriter|author|record producer}}
| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|bass|harmonica|programming}}
| years_active     = 1984–present
| label            = {{hlist|Giant/Rockville|[[Sire Records|Sire]]|[[Reprise Records|Reprise]]|[[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]]|[[Drag City (record label)|Drag City]]|[[Dbpm Records|dBpm]]}}
| current_member_of = {{hlist|[[Wilco]]|[[Golden Smog]]|[[Tweedy (band)|Tweedy]]}}
| past_member_of   = {{hlist|[[Uncle Tupelo]]|[[The Minus 5]]|[[Loose Fur]]|The Racoonists}}
}}
'''Jeffrey Scot Tweedy''' (born August 25, 1967) is an American musician, singer songwriter, author, and record producer best known as the lead vocalist and guitarist of the band [[Wilco]]. Tweedy, originally from [[Belleville, Illinois]], began his music career in high school with his band The Plebes along with [[Jay Farrar]], also in the band. It became the [[alternative country]] band [[Uncle Tupelo]]. 

After Uncle Tupelo broke up Tweedy formed Wilco which found critical and commercial success, most notably with ''[[Yankee Hotel Foxtrot]]'' and ''[[A Ghost Is Born]]''. The latter received a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Album]] in 2005.

During his career Tweedy has released 20 studio albums including [[Uncle Tupelo#Discography|four with Uncle Tupelo]], [[Wilco discography#Studio albums|twelve with Wilco]], [[Sukierae|one with his son Spencer]], [[Together at Last|a solo acoustic album]], three solo studio albums, along with numerous collaborations with other musicians, most notably ''[[Mermaid Avenue]]'' with [[Billy Bragg]].<ref name="Kot-LHTD-2004">{{cite book|last1=Kot|first1=Greg|title=Wilco : Learning How To Die|url=https://archive.org/details/wilcolearninghowt00kotg|url-access=registration|date=2004|publisher=Broadway Books|location=New York, N.Y.|isbn=978-0-767-91558-8|edition=1.}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes-RockStar-2009">{{cite news|last1=Carr|first1=David|title=Torture-Free but Still a Rock Star|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/arts/music/05carr.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 1, 2009|archive-date=August 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821090505/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/arts/music/05carr.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Early life ==
Tweedy was born in [[Belleville, Illinois|Belleville]] on August 25, 1967,<ref name=FamilySearch>{{cite web|title=Jeff S Tweedy: United States Public Records, 1970–2009|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/KL3T-1W8|website=[[FamilySearch]]|access-date=August 20, 2014}}</ref> the fourth child of Bob and JoAnn Tweedy (née Werkmeister).<ref name=SunTimes-GregTweedy-obit-2013>{{cite news|last1=O'Donnell|first1=Maureen|title=Greg Tweedy, 55, railroad man, brother of Wilco founder, dies|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/obituaries/22315588-418/greg-tweedy-55-railroad-man-brother-of-wilco-founder.html#.U_RUX7xdXXE|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=September 2, 2013}}</ref> Bob Tweedy (died August 4, 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/belleville/obituary.aspx?n=robert-l-tweedy&pid=186298161&fhid=4962|title=Robert L. Tweedy's Obituary on Belleville News-Democrat|website=Belleville News-Democrat|access-date=2017-08-06|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162254/https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/belleville/name/robert-tweedy-obituary?id=22012086|url-status=live}}</ref>) worked for [[Alton and Southern Railroad|Alton & Southern Railroad]] in [[East St. Louis, Illinois|East St. Louis]]; JoAnn was a kitchen designer.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|11–15}} Tweedy grew up with three siblings, older brother Greg Tweedy (he died in 2013), brother Steven Tweedy, and sister Debbie Voll.<ref name=SunTimes-GregTweedy-obit-2013 />

Tweedy's mother bought him his first guitar when he was six years old, although he did not begin to play it seriously until he was twelve. Apparently Tweedy told people that he knew how to play the guitar once he got his first guitar, even though he did not know how to play. 

When he was twelve, Tweedy was injured in a bicycle accident and was laid up for the summer. He decided to learn how to play a few chords before somebody "called him out" on the lie.<ref name="Kot-LHTD-2004" /> On an appearance of [[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]], he remembered attending an [[X (American band)|X]] concert as a youngster in [[St. Louis]]. Tweedy said [[The Replacements (band)|The Replacements]] opened for the band. [[Paul Westerberg]], the guitarist and vocalist for The Replacements, fell off the stage while performing. Tweedy said while he can't think of a song which inspired him to be in music he thought it looked like fun to be in a band after seeing The Replacements at that show.{{cn|date=January 2024}}

In 1981, when Tweedy was fourteen years old, he befriended [[Jay Farrar]] during an English class at [[Belleville Township High School West]].<ref name="Kot-LHTD-2004" />{{rp|10}} All of the members of Farrar's family enjoyed playing music; he already knew [[rock and roll]] music very well. By that time, Tweedy was a fan of [[The Ramones]] and [[country music]] while Farrar enjoyed [[The Sex Pistols]].<ref name="NYTimes-LHTD-2004">{{cite news|last=Klein|first=Joe|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/13/books/alt-country-roads.html|title=Alt-Country Roads: Wilco, Learning How to Die|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 13, 2004|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162252/https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/13/books/alt-country-roads.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Tweedy attended [[Belleville Area College]] and [[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]].<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />

== Career ==

=== Early music ===

In the early 1980s, Tweedy joined The Plebes, a [[rockabilly]] band, with brothers Wade and Dade Farrar which Tweedy joined in order to qualify for a battle of the bands competition. They won.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|10,17}}<ref name=OptionMag-HeartCountry-1993>{{cite news|last1=Fine|first1=Jason|title=Heart of the Country|url=http://www.gumbopages.com/music/uncle-tupelo/text/heart_of_the_country.html|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Option (music magazine)|Option]]|date=Nov–Dec 1993|location=The Gumbo Pages|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162254/https://www.gumbopages.com/music/uncle-tupelo/text/heart_of_the_country.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Tweedy pushed The Plebes away from the rockabilly music that they had been playing, which caused Dade Farrar to leave the band. The band renamed themselves The Primitives in 1984, taking their name from a song by [[garage rock]] band The Groupies.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|18}}<ref>The band was also known as The Primatives due to a misprint on their business cards</ref> Wade Farrar sang lead vocals and played harmonica, Jay Farrar played guitar, Tweedy played bass guitar, and [[Mike Heidorn]] played drums. In late 1986, the band decided to change their name to Uncle Tupelo, because a more popular British band was also using the name "[[The Primitives]]".<ref name=NoDepression-liner-notes-2003>{{cite web|last1=Heidorn|first1=Mike|title=Liner notes for No Depression (2003 reissue)|url=http://www.factorybelt.net/nd_notes.htm|website=Factory Belt|access-date=August 20, 2014|date=January 2003|archive-date=January 23, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123082925/http://www.factorybelt.net/nd_notes.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> The Primitives went on hiatus in 1986 after Wade Farrar left the band to finish his engineering degree at Southern Illinois University.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|22}} While waiting for Wade to return from campus, Farrar, Tweedy, and Heidorn formed Uncle Tupelo.

=== Uncle Tupelo (1987–1994) ===
{{main|Uncle Tupelo}}
At his parents' request, Tweedy attended several universities, but dropped out of all of them to concentrate on Uncle Tupelo. While [[wiktionary:moonlight|moonlighting]] as a record store clerk at Euclid Records in St. Louis,<ref name=RiverfrontTimes-SolidSoundFest-2011>{{cite news |last=Zaleski |first=Annie |url=http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/rftmusic/2011/01/euclid_records_wilco_solid_sound_festival_2011_pop-up_store.php |title=Euclid Records Having a "Pop-Up Store" at Wilco's Solid Sound Festival |work=[[Riverfront Times]] |date=January 19, 2011 |access-date=November 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821022731/http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/rftmusic/2011/01/euclid_records_wilco_solid_sound_festival_2011_pop-up_store.php |archive-date=August 21, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name=StLouisMag-Redemption-2011>{{cite news |url=http://www.stlmag.com/St-Louis-Magazine/September-2011/Wilcos-Jeff-Tweedy-Finds-Redemption-in-Music/ |title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Finds Redemption in Music |work=[[St. Louis Magazine]] |date=September 2011 |access-date=November 29, 2012 |archive-date=February 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162257/https://www.stlmag.com/Wilcos-Jeff-Tweedy-Finds-Redemption-in-Music/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Tweedy met Tony Margherita. After Margherita saw the band perform at an acoustic concert in 1988, he decided to become the band's manager. The band began playing regular shows at Cicero's basement bar in the [[Delmar Loop]] near [[Washington University in St. Louis]] with other bands playing in a similar style.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|24–26}}<ref name=NoDepression-liner-notes-2003 /> Uncle Tupelo recorded a ten-track demo tape entitled ''Not Forever, Just For Now'' in 1989, attracting the attention of [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant/Rockville Records]]. The independent label signed the band, and Uncle Tupelo's first album, ''[[No Depression (album)|No Depression]]'', was released the next year.<ref name=NoDepression-liner-notes-2003 /> The [[No Depression in Heaven|title song]], originally performed by the [[Carter Family]], became strongly associated with the [[alternative country]] scene, and became the name of an influential alternative country periodical called ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]].''

During times when Uncle Tupelo was not touring, Tweedy and Farrar played as Coffee Creek, a short-lived cover band with [[The Bottle Rockets]]' [[Brian Henneman]] and Mark Ortmann.<ref name=Request-AreYouReady-1993>{{cite news|last1=Durchholz|first1=Daniel|title=Are You Ready for the Country?|url=http://www.gumbopages.com/music/uncle-tupelo/text/are_you_ready.html|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=Request Magazine|date=November 1993|location=The Gumbo Pages|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162256/https://www.gumbopages.com/music/uncle-tupelo/text/are_you_ready.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Around this time, Tweedy began developing problems with alcohol, leading to tensions between Tweedy and Farrar. While he never refused to play a gig, Tweedy was forced to sit out in place of Henneman at some performances. Tweedy quit drinking entirely after meeting future wife Sue Miller, although he replaced this habit with smoking [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]. However, after developing a dependence on marijuana, he quickly quit using it, as well.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|51–53,95}} After releasing ''[[Still Feel Gone]]'', the band formed a friendship with [[Peter Buck]] of [[R.E.M.]], who produced their third album ''[[March 16–20, 1992]]'' for free.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 /> Uncle Tupelo left the Rockville label in favor of [[Sire Records]] ([[Warner Brothers|Warner]]) later in 1992 because Rockville refused to pay the band any royalties for their albums.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|72}} After the signing, [[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]] and [[John Stirratt]] joined the band as Mike Heidorn was replaced by Bill Belzer who was later replaced by [[Ken Coomer]].<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|74–75}} The five-piece band recorded ''[[Anodyne (album)|Anodyne]]'', which sold over 150,000 copies and debuted at number 18 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Heatseekers|Heatseekers]] chart, but was the last album Uncle Tupelo released.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|80}}<ref name=Billboard-Heatseekers-1993>{{cite magazine|title=Heatseekers|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=October 23, 1993}}</ref>

==== Breakup ====
In January 1994, Farrar called Tony Margherita to tell him that the band was breaking up, saying that he was not having any fun in the band anymore and was not getting along with Tweedy. Tweedy was enraged that Farrar decided to break up the band without notifying him, and this led to a series of harsh verbal exchanges. Farrar and Tweedy agreed to a final Uncle Tupelo tour, but the concerts were marred by the two not participating in each other's songs. The band decided to play Tweedy's "The Long Cut" on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', which further distanced Farrar and Tweedy.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|80–84}} Farrar began to assemble a new band named [[Son Volt]] with Mike Heidorn, bassist Jim Boquist, and his brother Dave Boquist. At the same time, Jeff Tweedy formed [[Wilco]] with Stirratt, Johnston, and Coomer.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|88,90}}

=== Wilco (1995–present) ===
{{main|Wilco}}
In 1994, Tweedy formed [[Wilco]] with [[John Stirratt]], [[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]], and [[Ken Coomer]]. Wilco has released twelve albums and found commercial success with their albums ''[[Yankee Hotel Foxtrot]]'', ''[[A Ghost Is Born]]'', ''[[Sky Blue Sky]]'' and ''[[Wilco (The Album)|Wilco]]''. The band also released two collaboration albums with [[Billy Bragg]] and one with [[The Minus 5]]. Jeff Tweedy has been the recipient of two [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Alternative Album for ''A Ghost Is Born''. Tweedy has also participated in a number of side groups including [[Golden Smog]] and [[Loose Fur]], published a book of poems, and released a DVD of solo performances. He was originally influenced by punk and country music, but has later reflected more experimental themes in his music.

[[File:Wilco - Roskilde Festival 2007.jpg|alt=|thumb|Tweedy singing with Wilco in 2007]]
Wilco signed with [[Reprise Records|Reprise]]/[[Warner Records|Warner Bros. Records]] and began recording ''[[A.M. (Wilco album)|AM]]'' almost as soon as the band was formed.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|89–91}} After recording, Tweedy was introduced to [[Jay Bennett]], who then joined the band. Also during this time, Tweedy quit smoking marijuana after a particularly bad experience with some [[cannabis brownie]]s.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|94–96}} ''A.M.'' did not fare as well commercially in comparison to Son Volt's first album, only reaching number 27 on the Heatseekers chart while Son Volt's debut ''[[Trace (Son Volt album)|Trace]]'' hit the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name=Billboard-Heatseekers-1995>{{cite magazine|title=Heatseekers|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=April 15, 1995}}</ref><ref name=Billboard-SonVolt>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/son-volt/chart-history/|title=Artist Chart History – Son Volt|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=December 29, 2006|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162256/https://www.billboard.com/c/music/|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Dan Murphy (musician)|Dan Murphy]] of [[Soul Asylum]] invited Tweedy to join him in a supergroup named [[Golden Smog]] with [[Gary Louris]] and Marc Perlman of the [[Jayhawks (band)|Jayhawks]], Kraig Johnson of Run Westy Run, and Noah Levy of [[The Honeydogs]]. Under the pseudonym Scott Summit, Tweedy released ''[[Down by the Old Mainstream]]'' with Golden Smog in 1996.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|105–106}}

Tweedy and Wilco began to explore new styles and broke from the style of previous recordings on the seminal sprawling double album ''[[Being There (Wilco album)|Being There]]'' in 1996. Tweedy did not write music for many of the songs ahead of time, and welcomed unexpected sounds into the recording. Wilco recorded nineteen songs for the double-CD album, and wanted the label to release it with a retail price comparable to a single-CD release.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|113,116}} ''Being There'' was a commercial success, selling 300,000 copies and peaking in the top half of the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wilco/chart-history/|title=Artist Chart History – Wilco (albums)|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=December 29, 2006|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162258/https://www.billboard.com/artist/wilco/chart-history/|url-status=live}}</ref> Reprise records invested $100,000 in the single "Outta Mind (Outtasite)", but received little radio exposure.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|125}}<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wilco/chart-history/|title=Artist Chart History – Wilco (singles)|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=December 29, 2006|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162258/https://www.billboard.com/artist/wilco/chart-history/|url-status=live}}</ref> While on tour, Tweedy began to spend time reading books by [[William H. Gass]], [[Henry Miller]], and [[John Fante]]. As he read their books, Tweedy decided to place more of an emphasis on writing.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|136}} Representatives in the A&R department of Reprise wanted a radio single from ''Summerteeth'', and Wilco reluctantly agreed to a re-working of "[[Can't Stand It]]". The single was a top five hit on [[adult album alternative]] radio stations, but failed to cross over to a larger audience.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|162–167}}

Before the release of ''Summerteeth'', the daughter of the late folk legend Woody Guthrie contacted [[folk rock]] singer [[Billy Bragg]], who in turn contacted Tweedy about recording an album of unreleased [[Woody Guthrie]] songs. Tweedy was indifferent to the idea of working with Bragg, but Jay Bennett's enthusiasm about the idea convinced Tweedy to get the band involved in the project. As a result of Tweedy's feelings on the political nature of some of the lyrics, Bragg recorded mostly political songs while Wilco recorded more neutral songs. Almost all of the songs that appeared on ''[[Mermaid Avenue]]'' and ''[[Mermaid Avenue Vol. II]]'' were recorded over a six-day period in December 1997.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|142–145}} The first ''Mermaid Avenue'' album and a second Golden Smog album (''[[Weird Tales (album)|Weird Tales]]'') were released in 1998, ''Summerteeth'' was released in early 1999, and ''Mermaid Avenue Vol. II'' was released in 2000. Tweedy received his first Grammy nomination when ''Mermaid Avenue'' was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album]] in 1999.<ref name=MilwaukeeJournalSentinel-Grammys-1999>{{cite news|last1=Associated Press|title=Fugees phenom Lauryn Hill gets 10 Grammy nominations|url=http://www2.jsonline.com/enter/daily/0106grammys.asp?format=print|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=January 6, 1999|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513171703/http://www2.jsonline.com/enter/daily/0106grammys.asp?format=print|archive-date=May 13, 2007}}</ref>

==== ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' ====
[[File:Wilco MassMoca AustinNelson.jpg|left|thumb|Wilco at MassMoca]]
Jeff Tweedy was invited to play at Chicago's Noise Pop festival, and was told that he could collaborate with a musician of his choosing. Tweedy chose [[Jim O'Rourke (musician)|Jim O'Rourke]] based on his fascination with O'Rourke's ''[[Bad Timing (Jim O'Rourke album)|Bad Timing]]'' album. O'Rourke offered to bring drummer [[Glenn Kotche]] to the festival, and the trio formed a side project named [[Loose Fur]]. The other band members of Wilco had written a number of songs for ''[[Yankee Hotel Foxtrot]]'', but Tweedy was unsatisfied with them because he believed that the songs did not sound like the ones he played with Loose Fur. Tweedy became such a fan of Kotche's playing style that he decided to dismiss Ken Coomer from the band in favor of Kotche.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|176–183,188}} Tweedy had strong feelings about how songs should be sequenced, which clashed with Jay Bennett's focus on the songs themselves. Because Bennett was mixing the album, this led to a series of arguments between songs about how the album should sound. Tweedy asked O'Rourke to remix several songs on the album that had been mixed by Bennett, which caused tensions within the band to escalate. The album was completed in June 2001, and Tweedy was insistent that it was in its final form.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|197–200}}<ref name=IATTBYH-Documentary-2006>{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Sam|title=I Am Trying To Break Your Heart: A Film About Wilco|date=2006|publisher=Plexigroup|location=New York|oclc=68940599}}</ref> Tweedy also fired Bennett around this time, believing (according to Bennett) that Wilco should only have one core member.<ref name=IATTBYH-Documentary-2006 /> The band maintains that the firing of Bennett was a collective decision.<ref name=Pitchfork-Interview-2007>{{cite news|last1=Crock|first1=Jason|title=Interviews: Wilco|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/interviews/6602-wilco/|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]|date=May 7, 2007|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162803/https://pitchfork.com/features/interview/6602-wilco/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Reprise Records' parent company [[Time Warner]] merged with [[America Online]] in 2001, and the recording company was asked to cut costs. [[Howie Klein]], the CEO of Reprise Records, considered Wilco to be one of the label's core bands, but was offered a lucrative buy-out by AOL Time Warner. Reprise did not consider the album commercially viable and was not interested in releasing the album. David Kahne (Head of A&R) agreed to release Wilco from Reprise under the condition that Wilco got to keep all legal entitlements to the ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' album.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|201–207}}<ref name=IATTBYH-Documentary-2006 /> After an article in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' publicly described these managerial practices, CEO Gary Briggs quit.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|208–209}} Shortly after leaving the label, Briggs remarked:

{{centered pull quote|It [dropping Wilco from the label] should never have happened. One of the most embarrassing moments in my career at Warner Brothers was the day they let Wilco go. It broke my heart, and it told me that I no longer have a home there.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|208–209}}}}

''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' was originally scheduled to be released on Reprise on September 11, 2001, prior to the band's departure from Reprise. Seven days later, Tweedy decided that he would stream the entirety of ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' on Wilco's official website.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|225}} Over thirty record labels offered to release ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' after the departure from Reprise was official.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kot|first=Greg|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/lifestyle/chi-0108150038aug15.story?coll=chi-leisure-hed|title=Wilco's shot in the arm|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=August 15, 2001|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010826133635/http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/lifestyle/chi-0108150038aug15.story?coll=chi-leisure-hed|archive-date=August 26, 2001}}</ref> One of the thirty was Warner Brothers affiliate [[Nonesuch Records]], who signed Wilco in November 2001. AOL Time Warner paid Wilco to make the album on Reprise, gave them the record for free, and then bought it back on the Nonesuch label.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|209–210}} The album was released on April 23, 2002 to significant critical acclaim, including being named the best album of the year by ''[[The Village Voice]]''.<ref name=Pitchfork-YHF-2002>{{cite web|last=Sirota|first=Bent|url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/23177/Wilco_Yankee_Hotel_Foxtrot|title=Wilco: Yankee Hotel Foxtrot: Pitchfork Record Review|date=April 22, 2002|work=[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]|access-date=December 21, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061031092741/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/23177/Wilco_Yankee_Hotel_Foxtrot|archive-date=October 31, 2006|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=VillageVoice-PazzJop-2002>{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/specials/pazznjop/02/ |title=Pazz & Jop 2002 |work=[[The Village Voice]] |access-date=December 26, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030220134654/http://www.villagevoice.com/specials/pazznjop/02/ |archive-date=February 20, 2003 }}</ref> The album became the biggest hit of Jeff Tweedy's career and was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for selling over 500,000 copies.<ref name=RIAA-DBsearch-2006>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gp/database/default.asp |title=Gold and Platinum Database Search |website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |access-date=December 26, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061221102221/http://www.riaa.com/gp/database/default.asp |archive-date=December 21, 2006 }}</ref>

==== ''A Ghost Is Born'' ====
[[File:Jefftweedyps07.jpg|alt=|thumb|Tweedy in 2007]]
[[Scott McCaughey]] contacted Tweedy about recording an album together for a [[The Minus 5]] release. They scheduled a meeting for September 11, 2001, but were reluctant to enter the recording studio after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|terrorist attacks]]. At night, McCaughey and Tweedy decided to begin recording songs as a way to calm down. A few more tracks were later added to the album with the rest of Wilco, and it was released with the name ''[[Down with Wilco]]'' in 2003.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|220–222}}

In November 2003, Wilco began recording a fifth studio album. Unlike their previous albums, all of the songs were originally performed in the studio and then later adapted for playing at concerts. Wilco released ''[[A Ghost Is Born]]'' on June 22, 2004, and it attained a top ten peak on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name=MTVNews-Charts-2004>{{cite web|last=D'Angelo|first=Joe|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1489256/20040707/story.jhtml|title=Lloyd Banks' Hunger Debuts At #1; Brandy Settles For #3|work=[[MTV News]]|date=July 7, 2004|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=December 20, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220232139/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1489256/20040707/story.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref> The album was awarded with Grammy Awards for [[Best Alternative Music Album]] and [[Best Recording Package]] in 2005.<ref name=AP-Grammys-2005>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/2005-grammy-award-winners/|title=2005 Grammy Award Winners: Complete List Of 47th Annual Grammy Awards Winners|agency=Associated Press|date=February 13, 2005|work=[[CBS News]]|access-date=December 28, 2006|archive-date=June 20, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620131904/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/02/14/in_depth_showbiz/main673822.shtml|url-status=live}}</ref> A few weeks before the album's release, Tweedy released a book of forty-three poems entitled ''Adult Head'' on Zoo Press.<ref name=ChicagoSunTimes-Poetic-2004>{{cite news|last=DeRogatis|first=Jim|url=http://www.jimdero.com/News2004/May9RockPoetry.htm|title=Poetic license or verbal abuse?|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=May 9, 2004|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162803/http://www.jimdero.com/News2004/May9RockPoetry.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> The following year, the band released their first live album, a two-disc set entitled ''[[Kicking Television: Live in Chicago]]'', recorded at [[The Vic Theater]].<ref>''Kicking Television: Live in Chicago'' liner notes</ref>

==== Later Wilco albums ====
Wilco recorded twelve tracks for a sixth studio album entitled ''[[Sky Blue Sky]]'', which was released on May 15, 2007.<ref name="Billboard-SBS-2007">{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Jonathan|url=http://billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003534789|title=Wilco Soars Into 'Blue Sky' In May|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=January 18, 2007|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=December 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229001122/http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003534789|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''Sky Blue Sky'' debuted at number four on the ''Billboard'' 200, the band's highest debut yet. It sold over 87,000 copies in its first week of release.<ref name="Billboard-Chart-2007">{{cite news|last=Hasty|first=Katie|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1051972/linkin-park-scores-years-best-debut-with-midnight|title=Linkin Park Scores Year's Best Debut With 'Midnight'|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=May 23, 2007|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=January 1, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160101062240/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1051972/linkin-park-scores-years-best-debut-with-midnight|url-status=live}}</ref>

In early May 2009, former Wilco member [[Jay Bennett]] sued Tweedy for breach of contract.<ref name="MemphisFlyer-LivingLife-2009">{{cite news |last=Lisle |first=Andria |date=2009-05-14 |title=Is Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Living the Life He Sings About? |work=[[Memphis Flyer]] |url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/SingAllKinds/archives/2009/05/14/is-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-living-the-life-he-sings-about |url-status=dead |access-date=2009-05-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210512084255/https://www.memphisflyer.com/is-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-living-the-life-he-sings-about |archive-date=2021-05-12}}</ref> Bennett died later that month of an apparent accidental overdose of the painkiller [[fentanyl]].<ref name="ChicagoTribune-JayBennett-2009">{{cite news|last1=Kot|first1=Greg|last2=Associated Press|title=Coroner: Painkiller killed ex-Wilco member|url=http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/06/coroner-painkiller-killed-ex-wilco-member.html|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=June 23, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625053327/http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/06/coroner-painkiller-killed-ex-wilco-member.html|archive-date=June 25, 2009}}</ref> In June 2009 Wilco released their seventh studio album ''[[Wilco (The Album)]]'', followed by ''[[The Whole Love]]'' in 2011, [[Star Wars (Wilco album)|''Star Wars'']] in 2015, ''[[Schmilco]]'' in 2016, ''[[Ode to Joy (Wilco album)|Ode to Joy]]'' in 2019, ''[[Cruel Country]]'' in May 2022, and ''[[Cousin (album)|Cousin]]'' in 2023.

=== Other work ===
Jeff Tweedy has performed several solo tours, on which he typically plays acoustic music.  He also recorded the song "Simple Twist of Fate" for the soundtrack to ''[[I'm Not There]]''.<ref name=RollingStone-LoungeAx-1998>{{cite news|last=Josephson|first=Issac|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5920882/jeff_tweedy|title=Jeff Tweedy: Lounge Ax, Chicago, March 26, 1998|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=March 31, 1998|access-date=November 29, 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> On October 24, 2006, Nonesuch Records released ''[[Sunken Treasure: Live in the Pacific Northwest]]'', a live DVD by Tweedy. The disc includes performances and conversations gathered over five nights on Tweedy's February 2006 solo acoustic tour, with footage from concerts at Seattle's Moore Theater, Portland's [[Crystal Ballroom (Portland, Oregon)|Crystal Ballroom]], Eugene's McDonald Theatre, Arcata's Humboldt State University, and [[The Fillmore]] in San Francisco. The DVD was directed by Christoph Green and [[Fugazi]]'s Brendan Canty, the creators of the documentary series ''[[Burn to Shine (DVD series)|Burn to Shine]]''.<ref>''Sunken Treasure: Live in the Pacific Northwest'' liner notes.</ref>

Tweedy has partnered with [[Mavis Staples]] on three acclaimed albums. In 2010 they released ''[[You Are Not Alone (Mavis Staples album)|You Are Not Alone]]'', in 2013, ''[[One True Vine]]'', and in 2017 ''[[If All I Was Was Black]]''. Tweedy played an array of instruments on these albums and wrote many of the songs.<ref name="RollingStone-OneTrueVine-2013">{{cite news|last1=Gross|first1=Joe|title=One True Vine Mavis Staples|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/one-true-vine-20130625|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=June 25, 2013|archive-date=December 28, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228000311/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/one-true-vine-20130625|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Tweedy worked with the psychedelic-influenced garage rock group [[White Denim]] on their record ''[[Corsicana Lemonade]]'', recording some songs at Wilco's Chicago studio The Loft.<ref name="Relix-WhiteDenim-2013">{{cite news|last1=Greenhaus|first1=Mike|title=White Denim Working on New Studio Album With Jeff Tweedy|url=http://www.relix.com/news/2013/04/02/white-denim-working-on-new-studio-album-with-jeff-tweedy|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Relix Magazine]]|date=April 2, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405051252/http://www.relix.com/news/2013/04/02/white-denim-working-on-new-studio-album-with-jeff-tweedy|archive-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref> In 2015 the album ''[[Still (Richard Thompson album)|Still]]'' by [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]] was released. The album was produced by Tweedy in The Loft Studios and features Tweedy on guitar and backing vocals.<ref name="Aqua">{{cite web|url=http://www.aquariumdrunkard.com/2015/04/28/richard-thompson-beatnik-walking/|title=Richard Thompson :: Beatnik Walking|last=Wilcox|first=Tyler|date=28 April 2015|publisher=Aquarium Drunkard|access-date=29 April 2015|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162806/https://aquariumdrunkard.com/2015/04/28/richard-thompson-beatnik-walking/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Tweedy has appeared as a fictional singer-songwriter on 2014 episodes of ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' and ''[[Portlandia (TV series)|Portlandia]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/54740-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-reunites-his-fictional-band-on-parks-and-recreation/|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Reunites His (Fictional) Band on "Parks and Recreation" {{!}} Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|date=April 11, 2014|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162808/https://pitchfork.com/news/54740-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-reunites-his-fictional-band-on-parks-and-recreation/|url-status=live}}</ref>

On June 4, 2014, it was announced that he had formed a new band called [[Tweedy (band)|Tweedy]] with his son Spencer. The band's debut album ''[[Sukierae]]'' was released on September 16. The release was followed by a world tour in which half of the set consisted of new songs off ''Sukierae'' performed by a touring band including Spencer. The latter half of the set Tweedy plays solo, typically performing Wilco and Uncle Tupelo classics.<ref name="Pitchfork-Sukierae-2014">{{cite news|last1=Pelly|first1=Jenn|last2=Camp|first2=Zoe|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Forms Band With Son, Announces New Album Sukierae, Shares "I'll Sing It"|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/55323-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-announces-new-album-sukierae-shares-ill-sing-it/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606180816/http://pitchfork.com/news/55323-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-announces-new-album-sukierae-shares-ill-sing-it/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 6, 2014|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]|date=June 4, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Grantland-Sukierae-2014">{{cite news|last1=Hyden|first1=Steven|title=How to Fight Loneliness: Why Jeff Tweedy set aside his Wilco responsibilities for his first solo project, which features his drumming son, Spencer|url=http://grantland.com/features/jeff-tweedy-wilco-sukierae-spencer-tweedy/|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Grantland]]|date=August 19, 2014|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162805/http://grantland.com/features/jeff-tweedy-wilco-sukierae-spencer-tweedy/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In June 2017 Jeff Tweedy released a solo acoustic album of eleven songs spanning his career from [[Wilco]], [[Loose Fur]], and [[Golden Smog]] titled ''[[Together at Last]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jeff-tweedy-together-at-last/|title=Jeff Tweedy: Together at Last Album Review {{!}} Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-30|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162808/https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jeff-tweedy-together-at-last/|url-status=live}}</ref> In November 2018 Jeff Tweedy released a memoir titled ''[[Let's Go (So We Can Get Back)]]'' and his first solo album of new material, titled ''[[Warm (Jeff Tweedy album)|Warm]]''.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|date=2018-09-24|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Previews New Solo LP 'Warm' With First Single 'Some Birds'|language=en-US|magazine=Rolling Stone|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wilco-jeff-tweedy-warm-some-birds-728227/|access-date=2018-11-26|archive-date=November 8, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181108224627/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wilco-jeff-tweedy-warm-some-birds-728227/|url-status=live}}</ref> A companion album to ''Warm'' titled ''[[Warmer (Jeff Tweedy album)|Warmer]]'' was released on April 13, 2019, as a [[Record Store Day]] exclusive.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Jeff Tweedy: WARMER|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jeff-tweedy-warmer/|access-date=2020-10-06|website=Pitchfork|language=en|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162808/https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jeff-tweedy-warmer/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2020 during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] Susan Tweedy and her family created a recurring video series on [[Instagram]] dubbed ''The Tweedy Show'' featuring Jeff and their sons performing original and cover songs.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Baker|first=Peter C.|title=The Talented Tweedy Family|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-talented-tweedy-family|access-date=2020-10-06|magazine=The New Yorker|date=June 25, 2020|language=en-us|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162809/https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-talented-tweedy-family|url-status=live}}</ref> During the shelter-in-place Jeff Tweedy also wrote and recorded his third solo album titled ''[[Love Is the King]]'' which was announced to release on October 23, 2020<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ruiz|first=Matthew Ismael|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy Announces New Album Love Is the King, Shares New Songs|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/wilcos-jeff-tweedy-announces-new-album-love-is-the-king-shares-new-songs-listen/|access-date=2020-10-06|website=Pitchfork|date=September 15, 2020|language=en-us|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162810/https://pitchfork.com/news/wilcos-jeff-tweedy-announces-new-album-love-is-the-king-shares-new-songs-listen/|url-status=live}}</ref> and wrote his second book titled ''How to Write One Song'' which was announced to release on October 13, 2020, on the [[E. P. Dutton]] publishing label.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Blistein|first=Jon|date=2020-08-11|title=Jeff Tweedy Details New Book 'How to Write One Song'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/jeff-tweedy-book-how-to-write-one-song-release-1042471/|access-date=2020-10-06|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162809/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/jeff-tweedy-book-how-to-write-one-song-release-1042471/|url-status=live}}</ref> His third book, ''World Within a Song'', will be released in November 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=World Within a Song by Jeff Tweedy: 9780593472521 {{!}} PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books |url=https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/714352/world-within-a-song-by-jeff-tweedy/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=PenguinRandomhouse.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

== Musical style ==
[[File:Tweedy Kotche 2012.jpg|left|thumb|Jeff Tweedy and Glenn Kotche Wilco at Susquehanna Bank Center XPoNential Music Festival 2012]]
Tweedy's musical style has varied over his music career. Tweedy's vocal style is considered nasal, emotional, and raspy, and has been compared to that of [[Neil Young]].<ref name=NYTimes-LHTD-2004 /><ref name=BBC-AGIB-2002>{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Chris|title=Wilco – A Ghost Is Born|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/release/m34h/|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[BBC]]|date=November 20, 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530034932/http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/release/m34h/|archive-date=May 30, 2008}}</ref> His first exposure to music was through [[gramophone record]]s that his siblings left behind when they attended college, and he particularly liked [[The Beatles]]' [[The Beatles (album)|White Album]]. Tweedy would frequently read issues of magazines such as ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', and began to purchase [[punk rock]] albums such as [[The Clash]]'s ''[[London Calling]]'' and [[X (U.S. band)|X]]'s ''[[Wild Gift]]''. Belleville crowds did not respond well to punk music, so while Tweedy was a member of The Primitives they played covers of [[country music|country]] songs at much faster tempos.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|13–19}}  When Uncle Tupelo formed, the band began composing its own songs influenced by [[Jason & the Scorchers]] and [[The Minutemen (band)|The Minutemen]].<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 /> Wilco's first album shared many musical similarities with the four previous Uncle Tupelo albums, but on ''Being There'', Tweedy began introducing more experimental themes into his music. He claims that he wanted to rebel against the belief spread by the ''No Depression'' magazine that Wilco was primarily a country band.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|110–111}} One of the most influential albums for Tweedy was ''[[Bad Timing (Jim O'Rourke album)|Bad Timing]]'' by Jim O'Rourke, which helped to inspire ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot'' and ''A Ghost Is Born''.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|176–177}} Tweedy uses a 1957 Gibson J-45 acoustic guitar, as well as a 1965 Fender Jazzmaster, at least three different Telecasters, an Epiphone Casino, a Rickenbacker 360, and a Gibson SG Standard. He has vintage SGs from '62 and '65 as well as a 2007 Custom Shop model and a 2008 Custom Shop Vintage Original Spec (V.O.S.) that are all rigged with Maestro tremolo bars.<ref name=Gibson-Sound-2009>{{cite news|last=Drozdowski|first=Ted|url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/ProductSpotlight/Tone-Tips/how-to-get-wilcos-live-420/|title=How to Get Wilco's Live Guitar Sound|work=[[Gibson Guitar Corporation|Gibson]]|date=April 20, 2009|access-date=November 29, 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907150018/http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/ProductSpotlight/Tone-Tips/how-to-get-wilcos-live-420/|archive-date=September 7, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He also has been known to use a Breedlove 000<ref name=GuitarWorld-RadioHead-2002>{{cite news|last=Beaujour|first=Tom|title=Radio Head|work=[[Guitar World]]|date=June 2002}}</ref> and even designed a limited edition 000 for Breedlove in 2007.<ref name=PremierGuitar-Breedlove-2007>{{cite news|title=Breedlove's Jeff Tweedy Guitar|work=[[Premier Guitar]]|date=November 20, 2007}}</ref> His amplifier of choice is a Vox AC30.

== Personal life ==
Tweedy has been prone to having [[migraines]] throughout his life; he has missed as many as forty days of elementary school in one year with the condition.<ref name=Kot-LHTD-2004 />{{rp|50}}<ref name=IATTBYH-Documentary-2006 /> While he attempted to regulate the use of painkillers, he was never able to stop using them for more than five weeks. He attributes that to a [[comorbidity]] with [[major depressive disorder]] and severe [[panic attacks]].<ref name=NYTimes-Migraine-2008>{{cite news | url= http://migraine.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/05/shaking-it-off/ | last= Tweedy | first= Jeff | title= Shaking It Off | work= [[The New York Times]] | date= March 5, 2008 | access-date= May 6, 2010 | archive-date= June 12, 2010 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100612015646/http://migraine.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/05/shaking-it-off/ | url-status= live }}</ref> In 2004, he entered a [[dual diagnosis]] rehabilitation clinic in order to receive treatment for an addiction to prescription [[painkiller]] [[Vicodin]].<ref name=Filter-Interview-2004>{{cite news|last=LaGambina|first=Gregg|url=http://www.filter-mag.com/features/interior.46.html|title=The Wilco Interview|work=[[Filter (magazine)|Filter]]|date=August 30, 2004|access-date=November 29, 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905165630/http://www.filter-mag.com/features/interior.46.html|archive-date=September 5, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=RollingStone-Rehab-2004>{{cite news |last=Devenish|first=Colin|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5937295/wilcos_jeff_tweedy_in_rehab|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109084011/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5937295/wilcos_jeff_tweedy_in_rehab/|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 9, 2006|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy in Rehab|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=April 6, 2004|access-date=November 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Barton|first=Laura|date=2018-11-30|title=Wilco's Jeff Tweedy on addiction, obsession and politics: 'White men are very fragile'|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/nov/30/wilco-jeff-tweedy-addiction-obsession-politics|access-date=2021-03-22|issn=0261-3077|archive-date=December 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201203050110/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/nov/30/wilco-jeff-tweedy-addiction-obsession-politics|url-status=live}}</ref> Tweedy quit smoking the next year; [[John Stirratt]] claimed afterward that significantly improved the focus of the band.<ref name=ChicagoTribune-Simpler-2007>{{cite news|last=Kot|first=Greg|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/arts/chi-0705111528may13,1,6133788.story?ctrack=1&cset=true|title=Wilco pares down for simpler, more intimate work|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=May 13, 2007|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205162811/https://www.chicagotribune.com/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/featured/wilco-jeff-tweedy-a-ghost-is-born-july-2004-interview-a-ghost-story/|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20191127212530/https://www.spin.com/featured/wilco-jeff-tweedy-a-ghost-is-born-july-2004-interview-a-ghost-story/|archive-date = November 27, 2019|title = Wilco: Our 2004 Interview with Jeff Tweedy|date = November 18, 2019}}</ref>

Tweedy is married to former bookkeeper Sue Miller and lives in the [[Irving Park, Chicago|Irving Park]] area of Chicago.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2019/nov/28/wilco-jeff-tweedy-home-shot-chicago|title='A bullet lodged in the door': shots fired at Wilco frontman Jeff Tweedy's home|last=Beaumont-Thomas|first=Ben|date=2019-11-28|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-11-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205163411/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2019/nov/28/wilco-jeff-tweedy-home-shot-chicago|url-status=live}}</ref> He first met Miller when he was trying to get Uncle Tupelo booked at [[Cubby Bear]], where Miller worked. Miller also worked in a club in Chicago named [[Lounge Ax]] in 1989, and booked [[Uncle Tupelo]] for 16 shows over four years. They began dating in 1991 and were married on August 9, 1995.<ref name="Kot-LHTD-2004" />{{rp|53,96}} She was diagnosed with cancer in 2014. During a 2015 interview with ''Rolling Stone'', Tweedy said "she's doing great now." 

Tweedy also said that music is a healthy distraction in such difficult times.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Doyle |first1=Patrick |title=Jeff Tweedy on 'Star Wars,' Bob Dylan and Wilco's Next LP |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/jeff-tweedy-on-star-wars-bob-dylan-and-wilcos-next-lp-20150819 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=August 19, 2015 |access-date=September 1, 2017 |archive-date=October 6, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171006205135/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/jeff-tweedy-on-star-wars-bob-dylan-and-wilcos-next-lp-20150819 |url-status=live }}</ref> They have two sons: [[Spencer Tweedy|Spencer]] and Sam. Spencer was the drummer for pre-teen rock band The Blisters and a new band called Tully Monster.<ref name="ChicagoTribune-EricZorn-2005">{{cite news|last=Zorn|first=Eric|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/columnists/ericzorn/weblog/archives/2005/05/blisstered.html|title=Eric Zorn's Notebook: Blisstered|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=May 2, 2005|access-date=November 29, 2012|archive-date=February 5, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230205163415/https://www.chicagotribune.com/|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2008, Spencer joined Wilco on stage at [[Madison Square Garden]] to play drums on their song "The Late Greats," while opening for [[Neil Young]].<ref name="RollingStone-BoyGenius-2008">{{cite news|last1=Scaggs|first1=Austin|title=Spencer Tweedy, Boy Genius|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/blogs/smokingsection/2008/12/spencer-tweedy-boy-genius.php|access-date=August 20, 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=December 17, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404161151/http://www.rollingstone.com/blogs/smokingsection/2008/12/spencer-tweedy-boy-genius.php|archive-date=April 4, 2010|url-status=dead|location=Smoking Section}}</ref> Tweedy has [[Conversion to Judaism|converted]] to Judaism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radio.wpsu.org/post/not-my-job-we-quiz-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-yankee-hotel-and-foxtrot|title=Not My Job: We Quiz Wilco's Jeff Tweedy On 'A Yankee, A Hotel, And A Foxtrot'|website=Radio.wpsu.org|date=August 11, 2018|access-date=November 30, 2018|archive-date=August 13, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180813004448/http://radio.wpsu.org/post/not-my-job-we-quiz-wilcos-jeff-tweedy-yankee-hotel-and-foxtrot|url-status=live}}</ref> His wife is [[Jewish people|Jewish]]; their sons both had [[Bar Mitzvah]] ceremonies.<ref name=Uncut-Audience-2013>{{cite news|title=An Audience With… Wilco's Jeff Tweedy|url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/wilco/an-audience-with-wilco-s-jeff-tweedy-feature|access-date=December 20, 2014|work=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]|date=February 2013|archive-date=December 20, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220212609/http://www.uncut.co.uk/wilco/an-audience-with-wilco-s-jeff-tweedy-feature|url-status=live}}</ref> During the ceremony for his older son, Tweedy played an acoustic version of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "[[Forever Young (Bob Dylan song)|Forever Young]]".<ref name=NYT-RockofAges-2009>{{cite news|last1=Solomon|first1=Deborah|title=Questions for Jeff Tweedy: Rock of Ages|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/magazine/05fob-q4-t.html|access-date=December 20, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 1, 2009|archive-date=December 20, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220213758/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/magazine/05fob-q4-t.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

In November 2019 Tweedy's home in Irving Park was shot at least seven times in an attack described by his son as "not targeted".<ref name=":1" /> No injuries were reported.

}}

'''Jesse Dayton''' is an American musician, actor and record producer from [[Austin, Texas]] best known for his guitar contributions to albums by country musicians including [[Johnny Cash]], [[Waylon Jennings]], and [[Willie Nelson]].<ref name="indie1">{{cite web|url=http://www.indie911.com/directory/country-and-western/jesse-dayton |archive-url=https://archive.today/20060507125317/http://www.indie911.com/directory/country-and-western/jesse-dayton |url-status=dead |archive-date=2006-05-07 |title=De beste bron van informatie over indie911. Deze website is te koop! |language=nl |publisher=Indie911.com |date= |access-date=2012-03-04 }}</ref><ref name="westword">{{cite web|last=Solomon|first=Jon|title=Jesse Dayton Wonders Where the Protest Songs Have Gone|url=https://www.westword.com/music/jesse-dayton-talks-bill-clinton-rob-zombie-waylon-jennings-and-nazis-10969705|website=[[Westword]]|date=November 5, 2018|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref> He is also notable for his collaborations with horror film director [[Rob Zombie]], who has commissioned Dayton on multiple occasions to record music to accompany his films.<ref name="westword"/>

==Career==
Dayton was born in [[Beaumont, Texas]], where he was raised on the music of [[George Jones]], [[Hank Williams]], and [[Lefty Frizzell]], all the while harboring an affinity for the spirit of punk with bands like [[the Clash]].<ref name="indie1"/> After touring with two rockabilly bands, the Road Kings and the Alamo Jets, Dayton ventured off into solo territory, recording his Americana-chart-topping record ''Raisin' Cain''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gray |first=Christopher |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/AMDB/Profile?oid=oid:93829 |title=Austin Music Database |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date= |accessdate=2012-03-04}}</ref>

With [[Lucinda Williams]] Dayton performed at [[Bill Clinton]]'s second inaugural ball.<ref name="westword"/>

Since then Dayton has released several different solo albums and worked with a variety of country rock artists, most notably [[Waylon Jennings]] and [[Johnny Cash]] on ''Right for the Time'' (1996)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Right-Time-Waylon-Jennings/dp/B000000NRU |title=Right for the Time: Waylon Jennings: Music |website=Amazon |date= |accessdate=2012-03-04}}</ref> after Jennings injured his picking thumb and required a guitar stand-in. Dayton also contributed guitarwork on albums by [[the Supersuckers]] and [[Kris Kristofferson]].<ref name="indie1"/>

In 2004, horror film director [[Rob Zombie]] commissioned Jesse Dayton to record an album for the fictional characters Banjo & Sullivan from his sophomore feature ''[[The Devil's Rejects]]''.<ref name="westword"/> The resulting album was a collection of tongue-in-cheek honky-tonk country entitled ''[[Banjo & Sullivan: The Ultimate Collection]]''. In Zombie's ''[[Halloween II (2009 film)|Halloween II]]'', Dayton performs as the lead singer and guitarist of the fictional psychobilly band Captain Clegg & the Night Creatures. He released an album entitled ''Rob Zombie presents Captain Clegg & The Night Creatures'' on August 28, same day as the film ''Halloween II'' premiered.<ref>[http://www.fangoriaonline.com/features/halloween/2731-halloween-ii-captain-clegg-a-the-night-creatures-cd-on-the-way.html]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607093202/http://www.fangoriaonline.com/features/halloween/2731-halloween-ii-captain-clegg-a-the-night-creatures-cd-on-the-way.html|date=June 7, 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.fangoria.com/musick/lists-of-doom/2893-exclusive-lists-of-doom-xvi-capt-cleggs-top-10-horror-films.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620001145/http://www.fangoria.com/musick/lists-of-doom/2893-exclusive-lists-of-doom-xvi-capt-cleggs-top-10-horror-films.html|date=June 20, 2009}}</ref> Following this, Jesse Dayton wrote and directed the 2013 horror film ''Zombex'', starring [[Malcolm McDowell]], [[Lew Temple]] and [[Sid Haig]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Whittaker|first=Richard|date=May 20, 2013|title=Jesse Dayton Walks With a 'Zombex'|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/screens/2013-05-20/jess-dayton-walks-with-a-zombex/|access-date=2021-02-18|website=www.austinchronicle.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Dayton|first=Jesse|title=Zombex|date=2013-10-26|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1916763/?ref_=ttfc_fc_tt|type=Horror, Sci-Fi, Thriller|others=Lew Temple, Malcolm McDowell, David Christopher, Sid Haig|publisher=Baumant Entertainment|access-date=2021-02-18}}</ref>

In 2014 he toured with [[John Doe (musician)|John Doe]] both as the opening act and a member of Doe's backing band.<ref name="westword"/> In 2015 Dayton played guitar in the band [[X (American band)|X]] on their US tour, filling in for [[Billy Zoom]] who had been diagnosed with cancer.<ref name="westword"/> In 2016 he again toured with John Doe as well being the opener on the [[Supersuckers]] European and US tours.

On September 16, 2016, he released his ninth album titled ''The Revealer'' on his Hardcharger Records imprint through [[Blue Élan Records]].<ref name="westword"/> This was followed by ''The Outsider'' in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-06-08|title=Jesse Dayton: The Outsider « American Songwriter|url=https://americansongwriter.com/jesse-dayton-outsider/|access-date=2021-02-17|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}}</ref> 2019 saw the release of a live album, ''On Fire in Nashville'', and ''Mixtape Volume 1'', a collection of covers.<ref>{{Citation|title=On Fire in Nashville|url=https://open.spotify.com/album/6piEzYrtM6CKlyWvPb7nU6|language=en|access-date=2021-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=2019-08-05|title=Hear Jesse Dayton Cover Neil Young, AC/DC on New Album 'Mixtape Volume 1'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jesse-dayton-mixtape-album-stream-listen-867446/|access-date=2021-02-18|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2020, Dayton released the ''Gulf Coast Sessions'' EP, as well as ''Texas '45 RPM Showdown'', a limited 7 inch vinyl made in conjunction with [[Record Store Day]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=2020-07-22|title=Jesse Dayton Is a One-Man Band on New EP 'Gulf Coast Sessions'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jesse-dayton-is-a-one-man-band-on-new-ep-gulf-coast-sessions-1032076/|access-date=2021-02-18|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=RSD '20 Special Release: Jesse Dayton - Texas 45 RPM Showdown|url=https://recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/11979|language=en|access-date=2021-02-18}}</ref>

On October 30 & 31, 2021, Jesse played guitar at the Danzig Sings Elvis shows (along with Glenn Danzig-vocals, Steve Zing-drums, and Ronnie King- piano) at the Hollywood Roosevelt hotel in Los Angeles, California.

== Awards and honors ==
In 2023, Dayton and musician [[Samantha Fish]] received ''[[OffBeat (music magazine)|OffBeat]]''<nowiki/>'s Best of the Beat Awards in the categories of Best Music Video (for "Deathwish") and Best Blues Album (for ''Deathwish'').<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=2011-09-08 |title=Best of the Beat Award Winners:Complete List - OffBeat Magazine |url=https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/,%20https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/ |access-date=2024-02-29 |website=www.offbeat.com |language=en-US}}</ref>
