=== Other honors and recognitions ===
* 1999&nbsp;– Ranked No. 97 on [[VH1]]'s [[The Greatest (TV series)|100 Greatest Women in Rock & Roll]].<ref name=rockonthenet/>
* 2002&nbsp;– Named "America's best songwriter" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref name=time/>
* 2002&nbsp;– Ranked No. 36 on [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]'s 40 Greatest Women of Country Music.<ref name=cmt40/>
* 2015&nbsp;– Ranked No. 79 on [[Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time]].<ref name=rswriter/>
* 2017&nbsp;– Received the [[Berklee College of Music]] Honorary Doctorate of Music Degree.<ref name=berklee/>
* 2017&nbsp;– Ranked No. 91 on [[Rolling Stone|''Rolling Stone's'']] 100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time.<ref name=rscounty/>
* 2020&nbsp;– ''Car Wheels on a Gravel Road'' ranked No. 97, and ''Lucinda Williams'' ranked No. 426, on [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 500 Greatest Albums of All Time]].<ref name=rscar/><ref name=rslu/>
* 2021&nbsp;– Inducted into the [[Austin City Limits]] Hall of Fame.<ref name=austinhallfame/>
* 2021&nbsp;– "Passionate Kisses" ranked No. 437 on [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 500 Greatest Songs of All Time]].<ref name=rspk/>
* 2022&nbsp;– Received the Americana Music Association-UK International Lifetime Achievement Award.<ref name=uklifetime/>
* 2022&nbsp;– Received the [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] Troubadour Award.<ref name=bmiaward/>
* 2023&nbsp;– Honored with the AMERICANAFEST Pre-Grammy Salute to Lucinda Williams.<ref name=AMERICANAFEST/>
* 2023&nbsp;– Awarded Best Roots Rock / Americana Artist, and Best Roots Rock / Americana Album (for ''Stories from a Rock n Roll Heart'') in [[OffBeat (music magazine)|''OffBeat'']]'s Best of the Beat Awards.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2011-09-08 |title=Best of the Beat Award Winners: Complete List |url=https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/,%20https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/ |access-date=2024-02-29 |website=[[OffBeat (music magazine)|OffBeat Magazine]] |language=en-US}}</ref>
*2024&nbsp;– Ranked No. 8 on ''[[American Songwriter]]'s'' list of the 10 Greatest Female Songwriters of All Time.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://americansongwriter.com/the-10-greatest-female-songwriters-of-all-time-period/ |title=The 10 Greatest Female Songwriters of All Time, Period |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |access-date=2024-04-16}}</ref>
*2024&nbsp;– Elected as a member of the [[Texas Institute of Letters]].<ref name=TIL>{{cite news|url=https://texasinstituteofletters.org/twelve-new-members-elected-to-til/|date=March 3, 2024|title=Twelve New Members Elected to TIL|work=Texas Institute of Letters}}</ref>

===In popular culture===
* 1991&nbsp;– "Lucinda Williams" is the title of a song on the [[Vic Chesnutt]] album ''West of Rome''.<ref name=vicwest/>
* 2008&nbsp;– The American folk/rock band [[Augustana (band)|Augustana]] references the musician in the song "Meet You There", on their album ''[[Can't Love, Can't Hurt]]''. The lyrics state "Just put on Lucinda, Baby, and dance with me."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metrolyrics.com/meet-you-there-lyrics-augustana.html |last1=Layus |first1=Dan |last2=Flynn |first2=Mike |title=Meet You There Lyrics |website=Metro Lyrics |publisher=CBS Interactive |access-date=June 14, 2023 |archive-date=December 20, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220145546/http://www.metrolyrics.com/meet-you-there-lyrics-augustana.html |url-status=dead}}</ref>
* 2014&nbsp;– Williams is referenced by the character Kathleen "Kat" Hall, played by [[Mireille Enos]], in the film ''[[If I Stay (film)|If I Stay]]''.

'''Lydia Loveless''' ([[née]] '''Ankrom''', born September 4, 1990) is an American [[alternative country]]<ref name=SPIN-KickAss-2014>{{cite web|last=Oliphint|first=Joel|title=Lydia Loveless Probably Won't Kick Your Ass|url=https://www.spin.com/2014/01/lydia-loveless-interview-somewhere-else/|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> singer-songwriter from [[Columbus, Ohio]].<ref name=lantern_loveless>{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Andrea|title=Lydia Loveless to show sisterly love in Columbus show|url=http://thelantern.com/2012/04/lydia-loveless-to-show-sisterly-love-in-columbus-show/|work=The Lantern – The student voice of the Ohio State University|date=April 20, 2012}}</ref> Their{{efn|name=fn1}} music combines pop music, [[classic country]], [[honky tonk]], and [[punk rock]].<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012>{{cite news|title=Lydia Loveless: Defiance on the farm |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2011/11/22/lydia-loveless-defiance-on-the-farm/|newspaper=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|date=November 22, 2011|last=Kot|first=Greg}}</ref><ref name="AllMusic-Bio">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p2348170|pure_url=yes}}|title=Lydia Loveless Overview|last=Deming|first=Mark|work=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>

== Early life ==
Loveless was born in [[Coshocton, Ohio]], in the [[Newcastle Township, Coshocton County, Ohio|Newcastle]] area.<ref name=OGibbs-2013>{{cite web|last=Gibbs|first=Otis|title=Lydia Loveless|url=http://otisgibbs.com/episode-23-lydia-loveless/|work=Episode 23: Lydia Loveless|format=podcast|date=March 12, 2013}}</ref> They are the daughter of Parker Chandler and have two older sisters: Eleanor Sinacola, and Jessica, who now performs under the stage name "Jessica Wabbit".<ref name=lantern_loveless /> Loveless grew up on a farm in a rural area outside of Coshocton and was home-schooled.<ref name=KidsInterviewBands2014>{{cite web|last=Olivia|title=Lydia Loveless|url=http://www.kidsinterviewbands.com/video/lydia-loveless/|work=Kids Interview Bands|location=Big Fun – Columbus, Ohio|date=February 1, 2013|access-date=February 19, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223111736/http://www.kidsinterviewbands.com/video/lydia-loveless/|archive-date=February 23, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=Grantland-PopCulture-2014>{{cite web|last1=Koppelman|first1=Brian|title=The Moment – Lydia Loveless|url=https://www.espn.com/radio/play/_/id/12037733|website=[[Grantland]] – Pop Culture|publisher=[[ESPN]]|format=Audio interview|date=December 16, 2014}}</ref> They said they felt like an outcast in a town that emphasized religion and conformity<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012/><ref name=AllMusic-Bio /> until they moved to [[Columbus, Ohio]] when they were 14. They enjoyed [[Hank Williams III]] and punk-influenced country music, while also embracing popular music and rock and roll and "pretty much anything on [[Kemado Records]]."<ref name=Interview-Machine>{{cite web|last=Valish|first=Frank|title=Lydia Loveless and The Machine|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/lydia-loveless-indestructible-machine|work=[[Interview Magazine]]|date=July 11, 2013 }}</ref><ref name=NoDep-Indest />

Their family is musical: Loveless' father was a pastor, drummer, and later country-western bar owner for a time.<ref name=Interview-Machine/> They and their sisters played several instruments.<ref name=lantern_loveless /> Loveless took piano lessons,<ref name=WattFromPedro-Real-2016>{{cite news|last1=Watt|first1=Mike|title=on-air guest lydia loveless from columbus, oh via skype|url=http://www.twfps.com/Past-Episodes/on-air-guest-lydia-loveless-from-columbus-oh-via-skype|work=[[The Watt from Pedro Show]]|date=September 6, 2016|format=Radio show with interview|access-date=September 12, 2016|archive-date=September 13, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160913122717/http://www.twfps.com/Past-Episodes/on-air-guest-lydia-loveless-from-columbus-oh-via-skype|url-status=dead}}</ref> then began trying to play the guitar at 12.<ref name=AmSong-2014>{{cite web|last=Schlansky|first=Evan|title=Lydia Loveless|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2014/03/lydia-loveless-2/|work=[[American Songwriter]]|date=March 10, 2014}}</ref><ref name=MusicLegends-SE-2014 />

[[File:Lydia Loveless at DC9.jpg|thumb|Loveless at DC9 (Washington DC) September 2014]]

== Career ==
[[File:Lydia Loveless performing at SXSW 2014.JPG|thumb|Lydia Loveless performing at SXSW 2014]]
In 2004, Loveless, their father, and their sisters made up part of a four-member new wave pop band called Carson Drew,<ref name=WattFromPedro-Real-2016 /> named after the father in the [[Nancy Drew]] books. Loveless played bass.<ref name=NoDep-Indest>{{cite web|last=Mateer|first=Chris|title=Interview: Lydia Loveless on "Indestructible Machine"|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blog/show?id=2342817%3ABlogPost%3A639421&commentId=2342817%3AComment%3A647046&xg_source=activity|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|date=September 12, 2011|access-date=January 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102200003/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blog/show?id=2342817%3ABlogPost%3A639421&commentId=2342817%3AComment%3A647046&xg_source=activity|archive-date=January 2, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> The band broke up in 2007.<ref name=lantern_loveless />

At a show in [[Cincinnati]] where they opened for his band, Loveless met producer David Rhodes Brown ([[500 Miles to Memphis]])<ref name=Grantland-PopCulture-2014 /> who went on to produce their first album, 2010's ''The Only Man''. Loveless was not happy with the slick production of the album.<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /> Loveless made the record when they were 15 years old.<ref name=CMJ-QA-2014>{{cite web|last=Davidson|first=Eric|title=Q&A: Lydia Loveless|url=http://www.cmj.com/feature/qa-lydia-loveless/|work=[[CMJ.com|CMJ]]|publisher=CMJ Holdings Corp.|date=February 13, 2014}}</ref> Loveless clarified that they like the songs they wrote, but the drawn-out process (over three years) to get the album released influenced their feelings about the project.<ref name=Grantland-PopCulture-2014 /><ref name=ColMnthly-breakout-2012>{{cite web|last=Oliphint|first=Joel|title=Lydia Loveless: Her breakout year just behind her, the rocker with a punk country sound is still touring while planning her next recording.|url=http://www.columbusmonthly.com/February-2012/Lydia-Loveless/|work=[[Columbus Monthly]]|date=February 2012|access-date=January 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102200427/http://www.columbusmonthly.com/February-2012/Lydia-Loveless/|archive-date=January 2, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Columbus attorney Steve McGann became their manager. Loveless and their band drove 20 hours to Austin, Texas, and ended up playing for [[Bloodshot Records|Bloodshot]] owners Rob Miller and Nan Warshaw at the [[South by Southwest#2010|2010 South by Southwest]] music festival.<ref name=ColMnthly-breakout-2012 />

In 2012, signed with Bloodshot and determined to make a more raw and edgier album, they released ''Indestructible Machine'' with songs that feature themes of frustration with their hometown, [[Drinking#Alcoholic beverages|drinking]], depression, and a humorous song about being stalked by a man who referred to himself as [[Steve Earle]] but was not in fact the singer of "[[Copperhead Road (song)|Copperhead Road]]".<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /><ref name=AllMusic-Bio/><ref name=spinner>{{cite web|last=Danton|first=Eric|title=Lydia Loveless Makes Men Cry, Professes Her Love for Britney and Booze|url=http://www.spinner.com/2011/09/16/lydia-loveless-indestructible-machine/|work=[[Spinner.com]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Wildsmith|first=Steve|title=Sassy, saucy, fearless: Singer-songwriter Lydia Loveless is an 'Indestructible Machine'|url=https://www.thedailytimes.com/entertainment/sassy-saucy-fearless-singer-songwriter-lydia-loveless-is-an-indestructible-machine/article_a041e0ff-23aa-5e50-b560-7b27ac6dbb29.html|access-date=2020-07-31|website=The Daily Times|date=January 25, 2012 |language=en}}</ref> Loveless recorded the album with many live takes and a minimum of overdubs at [[Grove City, Ohio]]'s Sonic Lounge recording studio with engineer Joe Viers.<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /><ref name=ColMnthly-breakout-2012 /> ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' characterized the record as standing out "for its utter lack of bullshit", with "roaring vocals, in her narrators' lived-in-bars recklessness, and in her overall inability to mince words."<ref name=SPIN-BlazesAhead-2014>{{cite web|last=Hogan|first=Marc|title=Lydia Loveless Blazes Ahead on Real-Talk 'Really Wanna See You'|url=https://www.spin.com/2014/01/lydia-loveless-really-wanna-see-you-stream/|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] magazine|date=January 22, 2014}}</ref>

''Indestructible Machine'' received praise from [[AllMusic]] and in publications such as the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', ''Spin'', and ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /><ref name=AllMusic-Bio /><ref name=wpost_blog>{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Allison|title=Singles file: Bjork, Premonition 13, Lydia Loveless|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/click-track/post/singles-file-bjork-premonition-13-lydia-loveless/2011/06/28/AGzHb7oH_blog.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 28, 2011}}</ref><ref name=cdispatch>{{cite web|last=Joy|first=Kevin|title=Profile of songstress rising outside Columbus|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/life_and_entertainment/2011/09/29/profile-of-songstress-rising-outside-columbus.html |work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]]|date=September 29, 2011}}</ref> [[Greg Kot]] wrote that Loveless' "defiant tone is matched by songs that put country and punk on equal ground, unvarnished and direct".<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /><ref name=PM-Indestructible>{{cite web|last=James|first=Matt|title=Lydia Loveless: Indestructible Machine|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/147029-lydia-loveless-indestructible-machine/|work=[[PopMatters]]|date=November 8, 2011}}</ref><ref name=MusicTimes-2013>{{cite web|last=Book|first=Ryan|title=Lydia Loveless Finds Her Country Music At The Hands of Nick Lowe and Richard Hell, Not Another Redheaded Alt-Country Chanteuse |url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/158/20130709/lydia-loveless-finds-country-music-hands-nick-lowe-richard-hell.htm |work=Music Times|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref>

In the Spring of 2013, Loveless did an extensive Canadian tour supporting the [[Supersuckers]].<ref name=SuoniPer-2013>{{cite web|title=The Supersuckers + Lydia Loveless|url=http://suoniperilpopolo.org/the-supersuckers-lydia-loveless/|work=Suoni Per Il Popolo|date=April 9, 2013}}</ref> Loveless and their band also toured Scandinavia and Spain during the fall of 2013.
[[File:Lydia Loveless with Old 97s.jpg|thumb|Lydia Loveless singing Four Leaf Clover with the [[Old 97s]]. 9:30 Club (Washington DC) May 31, 2014]]
In 2013, Loveless released ''Boy Crazy'', an [[Extended play|EP]]. Mark Deming of AllMusic praised the release, asserting that the album "is further proof that Loveless is a major talent, and if her next album is as good as this, she may run the risk of becoming a very big star".<ref name=amg_boycrazy>{{cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|title=Boy Crazy EP|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/boy-crazy-ep-mw0002597778|work=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> One of the songs, "Lover's Spat", is about the serial killer [[Jeffrey Dahmer]].<ref name=BostonGlobe-BC>{{cite news|last=Munro|first=Stuart|title=Lydia Loveless, 'Boy Crazy'|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2013/11/18/album-review-lydia-loveless-boy-crazy/5ETBmrp49lhd6qgV9ILSQP/story.html|newspaper=[[Boston Globe]]|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref>

''[[Rolling Stone]]'' cited Loveless as one of its "10 New Artists You Need to Know: January 2014".<ref name=RStone-10Artists-2014>{{cite magazine|last=Hermes|first=Will|title=10 New Artists You Need to Know: January 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/10-new-artists-you-need-to-know-january-2014-20140124/lydia-loveless-0011881#ixzz2tkFNGeB4|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 24, 2014}}</ref>

In February 2014, Loveless released their third full-length record, ''[[Somewhere Else (Lydia Loveless album)|Somewhere Else]]'', on [[Bloodshot Records]], which has a dark, "poppy" vibe.<ref name=BSHQ-SomewhereElse>{{cite web|title=Lydia Loveless – Somewhere Else|url=https://www.bloodshotrecords.com/album/somewhere-else|work=[[Bloodshot Records]]|date=February 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref name=SPIN-Cowpunk2013>{{cite web|last=Martins|first=Chris|title=Hear Lydia Loveless' Cowpunk Paean 'To Love Somebody'|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/12/hear-lydia-loveless-cowpunk-paean-to-love-somebody/|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=December 11, 2013}}</ref> ''[[Stereogum]]'' said Loveless is using their "unmistakable voice as a songwriter, and she's only getting better at using it to blur the line between running her mouth and pouring out her heart."<ref name=Stereogum-ReallyWant-2014>{{cite web|last=DeVille|first=Chris|title=Lydia Loveless – "Really Wanna See You" (Stereogum Premiere)|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1637922/lydia-loveless-really-wanna-see-you-stereogum-premiere/mp3s/|work=[[Stereogum]]|date=January 22, 2014}}</ref> Loveless was listed as one of "5 Best New Artist for January 14" by ''Spin'' magazine.<ref name=SPIN-5Best-2014>{{cite web|title=5 Best New Artists for January '14: Lydia Loveless|url=https://www.spin.com/2014/01/5-best-new-artists-january-14-drenge-sohn-seven-davis-jr-gorgeous-children-lydia-loveless/131226-lydia-loveless/|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=January 2, 2014}}</ref> The record includes "Head", a single Loveless wrote with their guitar player, Todd May, a fellow songwriter.<ref name=Elle-2014>{{cite web|last=Hyman|first=Dan|title=Exclusive: Lydia Loveless Gets Raunchy on New Single "Head" |url=http://www.elle.com/news/culture/exclusive-lydia-loveless-gets-raunchy-on-new-single-head|work=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> The album had a very positive reception<ref name=Metacritic-SE>{{cite web|title=Somewhere Else – Lydia Loveless | url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/somewhere-else/lydia-loveless|work=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> and entered [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']]'s [[Billboard Heatseekers|Heatseekers]] chart (new entries to ''Billboard'' charts, compiled by [[Nielsen SoundScan]]) the first week of its release at position number 7.<ref name=MusicLegends-SE-2014>{{cite web|title=Lydia Loveless Interview|url= http://musiclegends.ca/interviews/lydia-loveless-interview-2014/|work=Music Legends| first=Jason|last=Saulnier|date=February 4, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Billboard-Heatseekers-7-Feb2014>{{cite magazine|title=Heatseekers Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/heatseekers-albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard's]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227231847/http://www.billboard.com/charts/heatseekers-albums|archivedate=February 27, 2014|quote=Peak position: 7; Last week's position: -; Weeks on chart: 1}}</ref>

In April 2014, Loveless released the ''Mile High/Blind'' 7" record for [[Record Store Day]]. The record had a non-album cut titled "Mile High" on the A side and a cover of [[Kesha]]'s "Blind" on the B side. It was a limited edition release on lime green vinyl.<ref name=Spin-Blind-2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2014/04/lydia-loveless-kesha-blind-cover/|title=Lydia Loveless Gives Kesha's 'Blind' An Alt-Country Makeover|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=April 3, 2014}}</ref> The tracks were released in digital album format on May 27, 2014.<ref name=BklynVegan-2014>{{cite web|last=Sacher|first=Andrew|title=Lydia Loveless giving RSD single "Mile High" a wider release (stream it +++ updated tour dates)|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2014/05/lydia_loveless_1.html|work=[[Brooklyn Vegan]]|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref>

In April 2015, Loveless was part of a [[Record Store Day]] release with label-mate, [[Cory Branan]]. The two artists cover two [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] songs: Loveless doing "[[I Would Die 4 U]]" and Branan doing "[[Parade (Prince album)|Under the Cherry Moon]]". The 7" limited edition releases were also pressed onto purple vinyl.<ref name=NPR-AllSongs-IWouldDie4U-2015>{{cite news|last1=Ganz|first1=Jacob|title=Hear Lydia Loveless Cover Prince's 'I Would Die 4 U'|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/allsongs/2015/03/11/392213072/hear-lydia-loveless-cover-princes-i-would-die-4-u|work=[[All Songs Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=March 11, 2015}}</ref>

Loveless donated their vocal talent to the end credits song from the film, ''[[A Dog Named Gucci]]'', in the song "One Voice", which also features the voices of [[Norah Jones]], [[Aimee Mann]], [[Susanna Hoffs]], [[Neko Case]], [[Brian May]] and [[Kathryn Calder]]. It was produced by Dean Falcone, who also wrote the film's score. "One Voice" was released on [[Record Store Day]], April 16, 2016, with profits from the sale of the single going to benefit animal charities.<ref name=DVDReport-DogGucci-2016>{{cite web|url = http://dvdandblu-rayreleasereport.blogspot.com/2016/03/filmmaker-gorman-bechards-dog-named.html|title = DVD & Blu-Ray Release Report: Filmmaker Gorman Bechard's A Dog Named Gucci To Make Its DVD Debut On Apr. 19|last=Tribbey|first=Ralph|date=March 19, 2016|website=DVD & Blu-Ray Release Report}}</ref>

In August 2016, [[Bloodshot Records]] released their third studio album, ''[[Real (Lydia Loveless album)|Real]]''.<ref name=Spin-Longer-2016>{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/2016/06/lydia-loveless-longer-stream/|title=Lydia Loveless Needs a Little Bit 'Longer' (to Get Over You) on New Single|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=June 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name=BostonGlobe-Real-2016>{{cite news|last1=Munro|first1=Stuart|title=Lydia Loveless takes a long, honest look at relationships on 'Real' – The Boston Globe|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2016/08/17/lydia-loveless-takes-long-honest-look-relationships-real/i6N03qi7ipU00f8SBbcXcN/story.html|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=August 18, 2016}}</ref> Their first ever music video, for the album's first single "Longer" received its world premiere through ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' in July 2016. The video was directed by filmmaker [[Gorman Bechard]], who directed the documentary on Loveless.<ref name=RollingStone-Longer-2016>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/see-lydia-loveless-day-in-bed-for-new-longer-video-20160706|title=See Lydia Loveless' Day in Bed for New 'Longer' Video|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> On August 19, a second Bechard-directed music video was released this time for the song "Clumps".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noisey.vice.com/blog/lydia-loveless|title=Watch Lydia Loveless Pine for Romance In a Record Store with "Clumps"|work=Noisey|date=August 19, 2016 }}</ref> The next morning Loveless and their band made their American TV network debut, performing three songs on ''[[CBS Saturday Morning]]''.<ref name=CBSNews-SatSessions-2016>{{cite news|title=Saturday Sessions: Lydia Loveless performs "Same To You"|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/saturday-sessions-lydia-loveless-performs-same-to-you/|work=[[CBS News]]|date=August 20, 2016}}</ref> A video for the song "European", also directed by Bechard, debuted in November 2016.<ref name=RollingStone-Real-EuropeanDebut-2016>{{cite magazine|last1=Bernstein|first1=Jonathan|title=Inside Lydia Loveless' Genre-Bending Country Breakthrough|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/inside-lydia-loveless-genre-bending-country-breakthrough-w449282|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=November 15, 2016}}</ref>

''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called ''Real'' "an adventurous, brutal honest sucker punch",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/lydia-loveless-real-adventurous-brutally-honest-su-241026|title=Lydia Loveless' Real is an adventurous, brutally honest sucker punch|website=[[The A.V. Club]] |date=August 19, 2016}}</ref> while ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' said, "Loveless continues to manifest a remarkable combination of bruised vulnerability and desperate longing, alongside a tough, self-deprecating resilience, but there's more of the former and less of the latter this time. She's still preoccupied with the downsides of love: longing for something you don't (or can't) have, the inevitable dissolution of whatever you manage to find (and the difficulty of finding it in the first place), and the emotional pitfalls of navigating it."<ref name=Globe-Real-2016>{{cite news|last1=Munro|first1=Stuart|title=Lydia Loveless takes a long, honest look at relationships on 'Real'|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2016/08/17/lydia-loveless-takes-long-honest-look-relationships-real/i6N03qi7ipU00f8SBbcXcN/story.html|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=August 18, 2016}}</ref> ''Rolling Stone'' liked the shift in genre towards a more pop sound.<ref name=RStone-Real-Review-2016>{{cite magazine|last1=Hyman|first1=Dan|title=Lydia Loveless on Internet Stalkers, Badass Image and Raw New Album|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/lydia-loveless-on-internet-stalkers-and-raw-new-album-w435106|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=August 18, 2016}}</ref>

Loveless released their fourth studio album ''[[Daughter (album)|Daughter]]'' through their own label, Honey, You're Gonna Be Late Records on September 25, 2020.<ref name="auto">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lydia-loveless-new-album-daughter-1031581/|title=Lydia Loveless Previews New Album 'Daughter' With Rocking 'Love Is Not Enough'|first1=Jonathan|last1=Bernstein|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 21, 2020}}</ref>

== Documentary ==
Loveless was the subject of a documentary called ''[[Who Is Lydia Loveless?]]'',<ref name=ArgusLeader-LovelessDoc-2015>{{cite news|last1=Hudson|first1=Scott|title=Kickstarter launched for new Loveless documentary|url=http://www.argusleader.com/story/scotthudson/2015/01/21/lydia-loveless-documentary-kickstarter/22102313/|work=[[Argus Leader]]|date=January 21, 2015}}</ref> in which filmmaker [[Gorman Bechard]] (''[[Color Me Obsessed]]'', ''[[Every Everything: The Music, Life & Times of Grant Hart]]'') documented the making of Loveless' album ''Real'',<ref name="ArgusLeader-LovelessDoc-2015" /> as well as following their on the road, and looking into what life is like for a band at their level in the music industry.<ref>from and interview on the [https://americanamusicshow.com/episode299 Americana Music Show #299]{{Dead link|date=July 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, published May 10, 2016</ref> "I also wanted to look at stuff we normally don't see a lot of. What are the finances for a band like this? Where does the money go? Who gets the money? Is Spotify good? Is Spotify bad? How does piracy affect you? What about the fans? I really wanted to go into all of that for a band that can still sell out 200–250 seat venues and bars but is still all travelling in an old Ford van. A good night is when they have a couple of hotel rooms. No one is rolling in the dough so to speak. So what is it at that point when you have amazing critical success and acclaim but you're not there yet?"<ref name=NoDep-WhoIs-2016>{{cite web|url=http://nodepression.com/article/who-lydia-loveless-year-we-find-out-0|title=Who Is Lydia Loveless? This Is the Year We Find Out|date=December 31, 2015|website=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]}}</ref> In October 2015, Bechard and his crew filmed a live Lydia Loveless concert at Skully's in their hometown of Columbus for the documentary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbusalive.com/content/stories/2015/10/15/the-ten-best-rock-docs-of-all-time-in-the-humble-opinion-of-a-rock-documentarian.html|title=The ten best rock docs of all time: (in the humble opinion of a rock documentarian)|website=Columbus Alive}}</ref> The film had its world premiere on April 7, 2016 at the [[Columbus International Film & Video Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbusalive.com/content/stories/2016/04/07/staff-pick-the-rest-of-the-country-prepared-to-find-out-just-who-is-lydia-loveless.html|title=Staff Pick: The rest of the country prepared to find out just "Who Is Lydia Loveless"|website=[[Columbus Alive]]}}</ref>

== Songwriting ==
Loveless characterizes their songwriting as "singing about emotions".<ref name=Interview-Machine/> Loveless is an avowed fan of [[Kesha]], and has played "Blind" in their live shows, as well as in a recording featured on their ''Boy Crazy and Single(s)'' release.<ref name=MercNews-AE-2012>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Michael|title=SXSW: More great bands you don't want to miss|url=http://blogs.mercurynews.com/aei/2012/03/30/sxsw-more-great-bands-you-dont-want-to-miss/|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=March 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name=WSJ-2014>{{cite news|last=Danton|first=Eric R.|title=The Hard-Living Kid of Alt-Country |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303880604579403460922985686|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=February 27, 2014}}</ref>

=== Live performances ===
In addition to touring extensively Loveless has performed at many in-studio radio shows, including [[Daytrotter]], [[KEXP-FM]], and [[NPR]].<ref name=Daytrotter-2011>{{cite web|title=Lydia Loveless|url=http://www.daytrotter.com/lydia-loveless/daytrotter-studio-october-18-2011.html|website=[[Daytrotter]]|format=Audio|date=October 18, 2011}}</ref><ref name=KEXP-InStudio-2011>{{cite web|title=Lydia Loveless|url=http://kexp.org/live/liveperformance.aspx?rId=33776|website=[[KEXP-FM]]|format=In-studio performance|date=November 7, 2011}}</ref><ref name=NPR-TinyDesk-2014>{{cite news|title=Lydia Loveless: NPR Music Tiny Desk Concert|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3XyKhTwk9X8|work=[[NPR Music]]|date=July 1, 2014}}</ref>

* 2023: "Toothache"

== Personal life ==
Loveless was married to their bassist, Ben Lamb,<ref name=cdispatch /> who is also a graphic artist.<ref name=hot17-Ben-2012>{{cite news|last1=Shaw|first1=Chris|title=Ben Lamb Talks Bloodshot, Drunk Europeans, and Being Married to Lydia Loveless|url=http://www.thehot17.com/ben-lamb-discusses-bloodshot-drunk-europeans-married-lydia-loveless/|work=the hot 17|date=December 13, 2012}}</ref> They resided in [[Columbus, Ohio]];<ref name=ChiTrib-PunkRock-2012 /><ref name=AllMusic-Bio /> after they divorced, Loveless moved to Raleigh, North Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/charleston_scene/lydia-loveless-gets-past-depression-is-ready-to-be-real/article_e0392adc-97d6-11e7-9de9-0f0959be2d5f.html|title=Lydia Loveless gets past depression, is ready to be real again|author=L. Kent Wolgamott|website=Postandcourier.com|date=September 13, 2017 |accessdate=November 21, 2017}}</ref>

Loveless' older sisters, Jessica Wabbit and Eleanor Sinacola, also have their own bands (The Girls! and Dead Girlfriend, respectively).<ref name=lantern_loveless /> Loveless' younger brother, Nate, is the drummer of Shores of Elysium, a [[death metal]]/[[deathcore]] band from [[Columbus, Ohio]].<ref name=NPR-FirstListen>{{cite web|last=Hermes|first=Will |title=First Listen: Lydia Loveless, 'Somewhere Else' |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/02/09/271517779/first-listen-lydia-loveless-somewhere-else |work=NPR First Listen |publisher=[[NPR]]|date=February 9, 2014}}</ref>

Loveless is gender-fluid and uses they/she pronouns.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/lydia_loveless/status/1449492428843536384 |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=Twitter |language=en}}</ref><ref name="Instagram">{{Cite web |title=Lydia Loveless (@LydiaLovelesss) • Instagram photos and videos |url=https://www.instagram.com/LydiaLovelesss/}}</ref>

{{Short description|American country singer (born 1957)}}

|publisher=Chicago Tribune |access-date=2022-09-04}}</ref>}}

'''Lyle Pearce Lovett''' (born November 1, 1957)<ref name="allmusic">[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p4798|pure_url=yes}} Lyle Lovett Page] at [[Allmusic]] – Lovett's Genre and Styles. Retrieved February 2, 2007</ref> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer. Active since 1980, he has recorded 14 albums and released 25 singles to date, including his highest entry, the number 10 chart hit on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, "Cowboy Man". Lovett has won four [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Male Country Vocal Performance and Best Country Album.<ref name="Grammy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/lyle-lovett|title=Lyle Lovett|date=June 4, 2019|website=GRAMMY.com}}</ref> His most recent album is ''12th of June'', released in 2022.

==Early life==
Lovett was born in [[Houston]], Texas,<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.visithoustontexas.com/travel-tools/myhouston/lyle-lovett/
|title=Lyle Lovett – Musician
|year=2012
|work=Visit Houston
|publisher=Houston Convention & Visitors Bureau
|quote=I was born at the Methodist Hospital in Houston, TX.
|access-date=2013-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.uh.edu/features/on-campus/Lyle-Lovett/
 |title       = Musician Recalls Early Connection to UH
 |date        = September 21, 2012
 |work        = University of Houston
 |type        = University website
 |quote       = I was born at Methodist [hospital] and never lived anywhere else but Houston.
 |access-date  = November 6, 2013
 |url-status     = dead
 |archive-url  = https://archive.today/20131106174606/http://www.uh.edu/features/on-campus/Lyle-Lovett/
 |archive-date = November 6, 2013
|df          = mdy-all
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
|url=https://www.facebook.com/Houstorian/posts/569499003104812?comment_id=5146607&offset=0&total_comments=2
|date=November 1, 2013
|work=Houstorian
|type=Facebook page
|title=&#91;No title&#93;
|publisher=James Glassman
|quote=Mr. Lovett just DM'ed me that he was born in Methodist Hospital in the Medical Center.
|access-date=2013-11-06}}</ref> when his family lived in the nearby community of [[Klein, Texas|Klein]]. He is the son of William Pearce and Bernell Louise (née Klein) Lovett, a marketing executive and training specialist, respectively. He was raised in the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1501840|title=Lyle Lovett: 'My Baby Don't Tolerate'|website=Npr.org|access-date=July 22, 2016}}</ref> Lovett attended [[Texas A&M University]], where he received Bachelor of Arts degrees in both German and Journalism in 1980. In the early 1980s, Lovett often played solo acoustic sets at the small bars just off the A&M campus.

==Career==
Lovett began his music career as a singer-songwriter. By the early 1980s, Lovett had already distinguished himself in the burgeoning [[Texas]] folk acoustic scene.  He had performed in the New Folk competition at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]] in 1980 and 1982.<ref name = "KFF">"Kerrville Folk Festival Finalist History", compiled by Doug Coppock ([http://www.happenstance-music.com/KFF_History.asp link] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060220031051/http://www.happenstance-music.com/KFF_History.asp |date=February 20, 2006}})</ref> An American singer, Buffalo Wayne, whom he had met in 1978 during a college trip to Germany, invited Lovett to play with him at the 1983 [[Schueberfouer]] in Luxembourg. One of the [[happening|events]] at the [[funfair]] was an American musical tent.  The owner of that event was a fan of the [[Phoenix, Arizona]], [[house band]] J. David Sloan and the Rogues.<ref name = Lu/> He invited the Rogues for the event, and Lovett was encouraged by band members [[Ray Herndon]] and [[Matt Rollings]] to sit in with the group,<ref name = s>{{Cite web |last=Coughlin |first=Kevin |title=Lyle Lovett and His Band loom Large in Morristown {{!}} Morristown Green |date=August 2, 2016 |url=https://morristowngreen.com/2016/08/02/lyle-lovett-and-his-band-loom-large-in-morristown/ |access-date=2022-06-16 |language=en-US}}</ref> which did some of his songs. They opened his eyes to what his songs could sound like with proper backing; Lovett had never sung with a band before.<ref name = Lu>{{Cite web |last=Leatherman |first=Benjamin |title=Mr. Lucky's Oral History: 55 Years of Wild Tales From Phoenix's Iconic Country Nightclub |url=https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/music/mr-luckys-oral-history-55-years-of-wild-tales-from-phoenixs-iconic-country-nightclub-12142863 |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=Phoenix New Times |language=en}}</ref> Sloan and band member [[Billy Williams (record producer)|Billy Williams]] offered Lovett a deal on studio time, first day free. In 1984 Lovett took them up on the offer. After several stays in Arizona over that summer he recorded 18 songs.<ref name = L/> The demo tape of the first four songs led to his first record deal;<ref>{{Cite web |title=How to Hire LYLE LOVETT – Booking Alt-Country Singer/Songwriters Music – Corporate Event Booking Agent |url=https://www.delafont.com/music_acts/lyle-lovett.htm |access-date=2022-06-15 |website=www.delafont.com}}</ref> ten of those songs, recorded with the Rogues, became Lovett's self-titled debut album.<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 1, 2014 |title=Arizona Country Roads |url=https://www.phoenixmag.com/2014/07/01/arizona-country-roads/ |access-date=2022-06-15 |website=PHOENIX magazine |language=en-US}}</ref> He made many longtime contacts in Arizona during that time.  Several of the Rogue players, Herndon, Matt McKenzie, Rollings, and Williams, went on to play in his band. Williams produced or co-produced several of his albums from 1987 to 2007. Through them he met [[Francine Reed]], who began recording with him in 1985 and toured with him for decades.<ref>{{Cite web |title=How Francine Reed became a Phoenix legend, from church radio to touring with Lyle Lovett |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/02/03/francine-reed-on-singing-with-lyle-lovett/69864700007/ |access-date=2023-02-07 |website=The Arizona Republic |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhythm and blues singer known for Lovett link to perform in Olin |date=October 5, 2011 |url=https://www.bates.edu/news/2011/10/05/reed-music/}}</ref>  In 2022, reliving his Phoenix connection:<blockquote>It led to a demo tape, an album and now, this rolling Thanksgiving tour...It's all because of running into this band in Luxembourg. That's a long way to get to Phoenix from Texas. It's a lot shorter if you just do [[Interstate 10|I-10]].<ref name = L>{{Cite web |last=Masley |first=Ed |title=Lyle Lovett on his new album '12th of June' and how a Phoenix house band changed his life |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/music/2022/06/11/lyle-lovett-tour-2022-phoenix-date/7572710001/ |access-date=2022-06-15 |website=The Arizona Republic |language=en-US}}</ref></blockquote>

He signed with [[MCA Records]] in 1986 and released his eponymous [[Lyle Lovett (album)|debut album]]. He sang harmony vocals on Nanci Griffith's ''[[The Last of the True Believers]]'' album (1986). While typically associated with the [[country music|country]] genre, Lovett's compositions often incorporate [[Folk music|folk]], [[Swing (genre)|swing]], [[blues]], [[jazz]] and [[gospel music]] as well as more traditional country & western styling. He has won four [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Country Album (1996 for ''The Road to Ensenada''), Best Country Duo/Group with Vocal (1994 for "Blues For Dixie" with the Texas swing group [[Asleep at the Wheel]]), Best Pop Vocal Collaboration (1994 for "[[Funny How Time Slips Away]]" with [[Al Green]]) and Best Country Male Vocal (1989 for ''Lyle Lovett and His Large Band''). In 1995, Lovett performed a duet of "[[You've Got a Friend in Me]]" with [[Randy Newman]] for ''[[Toy Story]]''. He plays [[Collings Guitars|Collings acoustic guitars]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/06/play-guitar-lik.html |title=Fretbase: Play Guitar Like Lyle Lovett |access-date=July 8, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009120151/http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/06/play-guitar-lik.html |archive-date=October 9, 2008}}</ref>

[[File:Lylelovett2-fls.jpg|thumb|left|Lyle Lovett performing on the Watson Stage at [[MerleFest]] in 2011, [[Wilkesboro, North Carolina]]]]
Lovett has acted in a number of films, notably four for director [[Robert Altman]]: ''[[The Player (1992 film)|The Player]]'' (1992), ''[[Short Cuts]]'' (1993), ''[[Prêt-à-Porter (film)|Prêt-à-Porter]]'' (1994), and ''[[Cookie's Fortune]]'' (1999). He also composed the score for the director's ''[[Dr. T & the Women]]'' (2000).  Some of his other film roles include ''[[Bastard out of Carolina (film)|Bastard Out Of Carolina]]'' (1996), ''[[The New Guy]]'' (2002), ''[[Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story]]'' (2007), and a humorous role in ''[[Angels Sing]]'', a family Christmas movie (alongside fellow actors and musicians such as [[Harry Connick, Jr.]], [[Connie Britton]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Kris Kristofferson]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1833888/ |title=Angels Sing |publisher=IMDb|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> His television acting forays include guest roles on ''[[Mad About You]]'' and ''[[Castle (TV series)|Castle]]'', a recurring role on ''[[The Bridge (2013 TV series)|The Bridge]]'' (as Flagman, a lawyer), and appearances as himself on ''[[Dharma & Greg]]'' and ''[[Brothers & Sisters (2006 TV series)|Brothers & Sisters]]''.

[[Mary Chapin Carpenter]]'s 1992 song "[[I Feel Lucky]]" makes reference to Lovett, as does [[Bloodhound Gang]]'s 1999 song "[[The Bad Touch]]", which includes the lyric, "and you'll Lovett just like Lyle."

Lovett was given an award called an "Esky" for Surest Thing in [[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire's]] 2006 Esky Music Awards in the April issue. The magazine said of Lovett: "The secret of Lyle Lovett's endurance comes down to the three C's: class, [[charisma]] and consistency... In the studio and on stage with his giant orchestra, he's spent two decades gracefully matching genuine songcraft with A-list musicianship".

In 2010, Lovett appeared on an episode of ''[[Spectacle: Elvis Costello with...]]'' that also featured [[John Prine]] and [[Ray LaMontagne]].

In 2011, Lovett was named ''Texas State Artist Musician ''by the Texas Commission on the Arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.texas.gov/initiatives/texas-state-artist/state-musician/ |title=State Musician &#124; Texas Commission on the Arts |website=Arts.texas.gov |access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref>

Lovett contributed a cover of [[Buddy Holly]]'s "[[Well... All Right]]" for the tribute album ''[[Listen to Me: Buddy Holly]]'', released on September 6, 2011.

On October 24, 2019, Lovett was inducted into the [[Austin City Limits]] Hall of Fame.

In 2022, he released his first album since 2012, ''12th of June''.

==Personal life==
[[File:Lyle Lovett at Oregon Zoo.jpg|thumb|150px|Lovett performing at the [[Oregon Zoo]], July 2016]]
Lovett married actress [[Julia Roberts]] after meeting her on the set of ''The Player''. Following a three-week romance, they eloped and married in June 1993 in [[Marion, Indiana]]. In March 1995, they divorced after less than two years of marriage. ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine reported that the breakup was caused by career demands.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20105480,00.html|title=One Last Sad Song|work=People|access-date=March 6, 2013|date=April 10, 1995|author=Schneider, Karen S.}}</ref> They remained friends afterwards.<ref name="heraldscotland.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts-ents/music/lyle-lovett-goes-where-the-love-is.14371767?_=540d3e47795cb7cf660d17fac99e2ad4296c26ca|title=Lyle Lovett goes where the love is|website=Heraldscotland.com|date=July 17, 2011 |access-date=July 22, 2016}}</ref>

On March 28, 2002, Lovett was trapped by a bull against a fence on his uncle's farm in [[Klein, Texas]], before being pulled to safety. He fully recovered after six months from a badly broken leg, and he began touring again in summer 2003.

Lovett was conferred an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] by the [[University of Houston]] on May 15, 2010, at its general commencement ceremony.<ref name="University of Houston">{{cite web|url = http://www.uh.edu/features/on-campus/Lyle-Lovett/index.php|title = Musician Recalls Early Connection to University of Houston|publisher = [[University of Houston]]|access-date = May 16, 2010|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100519024424/http://www.uh.edu/features/on-campus/Lyle-Lovett/index.php|archive-date = May 19, 2010|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.uh.edu/news-events/stories/2010articles/May2010/05132010Commencement.php|title = The University of Houston to Graduate More Than 4,500 Students|publisher=[[University of Houston]] |access-date =May 16, 2010}}</ref> His mother was in the audience as her son was presented with an honorary doctorate from the same university from which she had received her bachelor's degree in 1960.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.chron.com/news/photogallery/UH_graduation.html#21668742|title = Singer and songwriter Lyle Lovett received an honorary degree during the ceremony|work=Houston Chronicle |date = May 15, 2010|access-date =May 16, 2010}}</ref> His father was also a graduate of the [[Hines College of Architecture|Gerald D. Hines College of Architecture]] of the University of Houston.<ref name="University of Houston"/>

In 2015, Lovett received the Distinguished Alumnus Award from Texas A&M University.

Lovett is also a horse enthusiast and co-owns and competes in [[reining]] competitions with world class [[Quarter Horse]], Smart and Shiney.<ref name="EQLiving">{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Stephanie|title=The Renaissance Cowboy of Texas|url=https://eqliving.com/the-renaissance-cowboy-of-texas-text-errors/|website=eqliving.com|date=December 23, 2014|access-date=May 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="H&R">{{cite web|title=Horse & Rider Q&A with Lyle Lovett|url=http://horseandrider.com/training/lyle_lovett_041610|website=Horse & Rider|date=April 16, 2010 |access-date=May 13, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="RollingStoneHorse">{{cite magazine|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Hear Pat Green and Lyle Lovett's Ode to Texas Girls|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/lyle-lovett-records-duet-with-pat-green-shows-off-horse-skills-on-letterman-20140827|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=August 27, 2014|access-date=May 13, 2017}}</ref> In 2012, Lovett was inducted into the [[Texas Cowboy Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Inductees|url=http://www.tchof.com/inductees|publisher=Texas Cowboy Hall of Fame|access-date=March 7, 2020}}</ref> In 2018, he was awarded the [[National Reining Horse Association]] Lifetime Achievement Award in the [[National Reining Horse Association Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Dale Wilkinson Lifetime Achievement Award |url=https://nrha.com/halloffame |website=National Reining Horse Association Hall of Fame |publisher=www.nrha.com |access-date=May 14, 2019}}</ref>

* ''[[61*]]'' (TV movie, 2001)&nbsp;— song performer "Nobody Knows Me"
* ''[[All Over the Guy]]'' (2001)&nbsp;— song performer and composer "She Makes Me Feel Good" and "The Blues Walk"
* ''[[Dr. T & the Women]]'' (2000)&nbsp;— Song performer and composer and also used a recording of "You've Been So Good Up to Now" (1992), "She's Already Made Up Her Mind" (1992), "Ain't It Something" (1994)

* ''[[Hope Floats]]'' (1998)&nbsp;— song performer "[[Smile (Charlie Chaplin song)|Smile]]"
* ''[[The Apostle]]'' (1997)&nbsp;— song performer "(I'm a) Soldier in the Army of the Lord"
* ''[[Toy Story]]'' (1995)&nbsp;— song performer "You've Got a Friend in Me" with [[Randy Newman]] as the lead vocals.
* ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'' (TV series, episode "[[Beverly Hills, 90210 (season 6)#ep154|One Wedding and A Funeral]]", 1995)&nbsp;— song performer "Nobody Knows Me"

* ''[[With Honors (film)|With Honors]]'' (1994)&nbsp;— song performer "Blue Skies"
* ''[[Major League II]]'' (1994)&nbsp;— song performer and composer "All My Love Is Gone"
* ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'' (1993)&nbsp;— song performer "M-O-N-E-Y"
* ''[[Leap of Faith (film)|Leap of Faith]]'' (1992)&nbsp;— song performer "Pass Me Not"
* ''[[The Crying Game]]'' (1992)&nbsp;— song performer "[[Stand By Your Man]]"
* ''[[Major League (film)|Major League]]'' (1989)&nbsp;— song performer "Cryin' Shame"
* ''[[Always (1989 film)|Always]]'' (1989)&nbsp;— song performer "Cowboy Man"

| image               = Martie Maguire in 2010.jpg

| website             = {{URL|thechicks.com}}<br/>{{URL|courtyardhounds.com}}

'''Martha Elenor Maguire''' (née '''Erwin''', previously '''Seidel'''; October 12, 1969) is an American musician who is a founding member of the country band [[the Chicks]] and the country bluegrass duo [[Court Yard Hounds]]. She won awards in national fiddle championships while still a teenager. Maguire is accomplished on several other instruments, including the mandolin, viola, double bass and guitar. She has written and co-written a number of the band's songs, some of which have become chart-topping hits. She also contributes her skills in vocal harmony and backing vocals, as well as orchestrating string arrangements for the band.

Maguire learned several instruments at a young age, honing her skills with her younger sister, [[Emily Strayer]] (born Emily Erwin) and two schoolmates (a brother and sister team, Troy and [[Sharon Gilchrist]]) for over five years as a part of a touring bluegrass quartet while in high school. After graduation, the sisters forged an alliance with two other women they had met through the Dallas music scene, [[Laura Lynch (musician)|Laura Lynch]] and Robin Lynn Macy, forming a bluegrass and country music band, [[busking]] and touring the bluegrass festival circuits for six years. After the departure of Macy, and the replacement of Lynch with singer [[Natalie Maines]], the band widened their musical repertoire and appearance. The result was a trio so commercially successful that it took the country music industry by surprise, with 19 singles hitting the [[Hot Country Songs|Billboard Country Charts]], 2 Diamond Albums, 2 Platinum albums, and 13 [[Grammy Awards]].  Maguire subsequently stood by her bandmates as they were engulfed in a 2003 controversy for [[Dixie Chicks controversy|criticizing George W. Bush]], which led to the Chicks being [[blacklisted]] by many country radio stations.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tyrangiel |first1=Josh |title=Chicks in the Line of Fire |url=https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,1196419,00.html |access-date=October 5, 2022 |publisher=Time Magazine |date=May 21, 2006}}</ref>

==Early life==
Martha Elenor Erwin, nicknamed Martie, was born October 12, 1969, in [[York, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="TV guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/martie-maguire/256027 |title=Martie Maguire News, Martie Maguire Bio and Photos |publisher=TVGuide.com |access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref>

Encouraged by her parents &ndash; educators at private schools &ndash; Maguire began playing violin at age five, and by age 12, started to learn to play "[[fiddle]] style" after receiving a birthday gift of fiddle lessons.<ref name="Ladies Home Journal">[http://www.lhj.com/lhj/story.jhtml?storyid=/templatedata/lhj/story/data/martiemaguirecelebprofile_01132003.xml]{{dead link|date=July 2014}}</ref> She also was active in her school orchestra.<ref name="Gilchriest">[http://www.freewebs.com/originalchicks/newsarchive.htm]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219045902/http://www.freewebs.com/originalchicks/newsarchive.htm|date=December 19, 2007}}</ref>

Her sister Emily shared her love and interest in music, and displayed early talent herself. The two sisters were provided musical instruction on several instruments, and their talent for [[vocal harmony]] continued to be nurtured. Although Maguire became famous for her harmony and mastery of the fiddle, she also plays a variety of [[String instrument|strings]] that include the [[viola]], guitar, [[mandolin]], and double bass.<ref name=Leggett>Leggett, Steve [https://archive.today/20130104003115/http://music.msn.com/artist/?artist=16649328&menu=bio All-Music Guide writer on MSN] (Retrieved March 9, 2008)</ref> Maguire [[Composer|compose]]s songs and [[arrangement|arrange]]s the use of [[stringed instrument]]s for concert and recording performances.

==Early career==
By 1983, Maguire was touring with her sister Emily and school friends siblings Troy and [[Sharon Gilchrist]].<ref name="JamBase">{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Artists/Bio.aspx?ArtistID=29795 |title=Sharon Gilchrist Bio, History, Info on JamBase |publisher=Jambase.com |access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref> The sisters showed an "almost obsessive" interest in [[busking]] at small venues and attending bluegrass festivals.<ref name="Frost">Frost, Jane [http://www.dixie-chicks.com/stories.shtml Walnut Valley Festival in Winfield, KS, Early 1980s The All-Inclusive Dixie Chicks Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923215315/http://www.dixie-chicks.com/stories.shtml |date=September 23, 2015 }}</ref> The four students formed the teenage [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] group "Blue Night Express", playing together for five years, from 1984 to 1989,<ref name="Faraway Hills">Gilchrist, Sharon [http://homepage.ntlworld.com/farawayhills/sharon_gilchrist.html  Faraway Hills Retrieved 12 February, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182257/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/farawayhills/sharon_gilchrist.html |date=March 3, 2016 }}</ref> while still attending private [[Greenhill School (Addison, Texas)|Greenhill School]].<ref name=Leggett/> "We'd drive down to the west end of Dallas and open our cases, and that was our job," Maguire said of it in a later interview to [[60 Minutes II]] [[correspondent]] [[Dan Rather]]. "That's how we made money in high school."<ref name="Rather">Rather, Dan 60 Minutes
II [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/10/23/60II/main243501.shtml?source=search_story Dixie Chicks Not Whistling Dixie The Trio Has Sold 17 Million CDs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016114544/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/10/23/60II/main243501.shtml?source=search_story |date=October 16, 2013 }} September 6, 2002 Retrieved June 26, 2008</ref> Also while in high school Maguire performed at Six Flags Over Texas in Arlington, TX, in a strolling duo with Troy Gilchrist for a summer.

In 1987, Maguire was awarded second place for the fiddle in the National fiddle championships held yearly in [[Winfield, Kansas]]. Upon graduation from high school, with Emily still in high school, she spent a year attending college at [[Southwestern University]] in [[Georgetown, Texas]], from 1988 to 1989. She performed in the school orchestra there and again competed in the national fiddle championships at the [[Walnut Valley Festival]], in Winfield, earning third place that year.<ref name="Walnut Valley Association">{{cite web|url=http://www.wvfest.com/ |title=Walnut Valley Festival - Winfield, Kansas |publisher=Wvfest.com |access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref>

In the 90s she played occasionally with the [[slo-core]] band, [[Bedhead (band)|Bedhead]].<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://ovrld.com/interviews/interview-underground-legend/ | title=Interview with Matt Kadane - Texan underground legend| date=November 22, 2013}}</ref>

==The Chicks==
[[File:Martie Maguire by ViVr.jpg|thumb|left| Maguire at [[Royal Albert Hall]], 2003]]
In 1989, Maguire and Strayer joined guitarist Robin Lynn Macy and [[Laura Lynch (musician)|Laura Lynch]] on double bass in the [[Dixie Chicks]], playing what was at the time predominantly [[bluegrass music]] and a mix of [[Country music|country]] standards. Originally listed as Martha, and then Martie Erwin, Maguire played [[fiddle]], [[mandolin]], [[viola]] and [[Harmony|harmonized]] with Strayer on backing vocals.<ref name="Superior">{{cite web |url=http://www.superiorpics.com/martie_maguire/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130203175101/http://www.superiorpics.com/martie_maguire/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 3, 2013 |title=The Martie Maguire Picture Pages |publisher=Superiorpics.com |access-date=2014-07-15 }}</ref>

Maguire had begun writing and recording songs on their debut independent album, ''[[Thank Heavens for Dale Evans]]'', and in 2001, one song co-written with Laura Lynch called "Pink Toenails" resurfaced. The song was featured in the film, ''[[Don't Say A Word]]'', with [[Skye McCole Bartusiak]] performing the song.<ref name="Yahoo review">(Retrieved March 22, 2008)[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1807438736/cast#Music Yahoo Movie Review for Don't Say a Word] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522135843/http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1807438736/cast#Music |date=May 22, 2011 }}</ref>

When their second album had a more polished sound, Maguire commented, "I hope our fans won't be disappointed [in ''The Little Ol' Cowgirl'']; it's got drums on every track; it's no longer bluegrass, but we have to make a living and you can't do that playing bluegrass."<ref name="Clark">Clark, Renee [http://www.dixie-chicks.com/dlife392.shtml Can the Dixie Chicks make it in the big time? Local Heroes (Transcribed from) ''Dallas Life Magazine'', ''Dallas Morning News'', March 1, 1992] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191833/http://www.dixie-chicks.com/dlife392.shtml |date=March 4, 2016 }}(Retrieved January 23, 2008)</ref>

Two albums later, after [[Natalie Maines]] became the lead vocalist of the Chicks, the band's commercial success skyrocketed. Maguire said of their music, "It's very rootsy, but then Natalie comes in with a rock and blues influence. That gave Emily and I{{sic}} a chance to branch out, because we loved those kinds of music but felt limited by our instruments."<ref name="Malkin">{{cite web|url=http://chickoholic.tripod.com/DixieChicks/id8.html |title=Martie Maguire |publisher=Chickoholic.tripod.com |access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref>

[[File:Martie Maguire in Austin, Texas.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Martie Maguire with the Dixie Chicks in Austin, TX, 2006]]
Maguire co-wrote the song, "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]" on the Chicks' album ''[[Fly (Dixie Chicks album)|Fly]]'' for her sister Emily. It was a tribute to Emily's [[courtship]] with [[country music]] writer/singer [[Charlie Robison]].<ref name="Ladies Home Journal" /> Maguire was singled out by [[Broadcast Music, Incorporated|BMI]] in 2000, and awarded Songwriter of the Year for writing and/or co-writing "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]", "Ready To Run" and "[[You Were Mine]]". "You Were Mine" was co-written by the sisters about their parents' divorce.<ref name="Hillman">Hillman, Chris [https://ew.com/article/1999/09/23/dixie-chicks-burn-billboard-pop-charts/ Entertainment Weekly]   (Retrieved April 21, 2008)</ref>

In 1999, the Dixie Chicks performed two songs, recording a [[Cover song|cover]] of the song, "[[You Can't Hurry Love]]" as well as Maguire's "[[Ready to Run (Dixie Chicks song)|Ready to Run]]" for the [[Julia Roberts]]/ [[Richard Gere]] film ''[[Runaway Bride (1999 film)|Runaway Bride]]''. In 2003, Maguire was nominated for a [[Tony Award]] for co-composing the [[film score]] to ''[[Urban Cowboy (musical)|Urban Cowboy]]''; the musical used her "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]".<ref name="Frontpage Publicity">[http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/content/careeroverview.html]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226165207/http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/content/careeroverview.html|date=February 26, 2008}}</ref>

After the band achieved massive commercial success with its first two [[Sony Music|Sony]] studio albums with Maines, they struggled with their record company over artistic direction on the third. Maguire commented, "I don't think any of us ever trusted Nashville. When you're in that town you know everybody is talking about everybody else. Everybody is wishing for the other guy to fail."<ref name="Flippo">Martie Maguire, to ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'', 5/21/06. Flippo, Chet (May 25, 2006) [http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1532532/nashville-skyline-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks.jhtml  CMT News Nashville Skyline: Dixie Chicks, Dixie Chicks, Dixie Chicks] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407062651/http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1532532/nashville-skyline-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks.jhtml |date=April 7, 2014 }}</ref>

Although Maguire and Strayer often appear quiet and demure compared to their animated bandmate Natalie Maines, the trio have stood united on controversial subjects since they banded together to play in 1995, even when their opinions have had the potential to serve them more harm than good. In 2006, Maguire said, "I'd rather have a smaller following of really cool people who get it, who will grow with us as we grow and are fans for life, than people that have us in their five-disc changer with [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Toby Keith]]. We don't want those kinds of fans. They limit what you can do."<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Tyrangiel |first1=Josh |title=Chicks in the Line of Fire |url=https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,1196419,00.html |magazine=Time |date=May 21, 2006 |publisher=Time Magazine |access-date=October 5, 2022}}</ref>

==Court Yard Hounds==
[[File:Martie-Maguire 2010.jpg|thumb|200px|Maguire performing at [[Clifford Antone|Antone's]] in Austin, with the [[Court Yard Hounds]]; March 18, 2010]]

With Natalie Maines taking a break from music, Maguire was working on a solo fiddle album; however, it was announced in January 2010 that she and sister [[Emily Strayer]] have formed a side project called the [[Court Yard Hounds (band)|Court Yard Hounds]], with Strayer on lead vocals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dixiechickshenhouse.com/ |title=Dixie Chicks Henhouse |publisher=Dixiechickshenhouse.com|access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2485 |title=Dixie Chicks Martie Maguire records |publisher=Countrystandardtime.com |date=2007-10-23 |access-date=2014-07-15}}</ref> The band made their live debut in March at [[South by Southwest]] with an album released in May 2010.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/01/15/dixie-chicks-plan-album-tour-with-court-yard-hounds-side-project/ |title=Which Band Will Reunite Next? Placing Odds on 14 Groups, from Led Zeppelin to N'Sync Pictures |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=2014-07-15}}{{dead link|date=August 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Maguire married [[pharmaceutical]] [[sales representative|representative]] Ted Seidel on June 17, 1995, and changed her last name to Seidel. She also was stepmother to his son, Carter. However, her marriage did not last, and she and Ted Seidel were divorced in November 1999.<ref name="Ladies Home Journal"/>

At bandmate [[Natalie Maines]]' sister Kim's wedding, Martie met Gareth Maguire, a [[Roman Catholic]] teacher and actor from [[Carnlough]], [[Northern Ireland]]. The couple became engaged in June 2001 and married on August 10, 2001, in a civil ceremony in Hawaii; as explained at one of their concerts, the Dixie Chicks' song "[[White Trash Wedding]]" is based on Martie's relationship with Gareth.<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/EshGQDYBKyE Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150110122700/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EshGQDYBKyE Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EshGQDYBKyE |title=An evening with The Dixie Chicks - White Trash Wedding |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-11-25 |access-date=2014-07-15}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Later they had a Catholic "blessing" ceremony in the groom's hometown, [[Carnlough]] in [[County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland]], on March 9, 2002, for all the guests that were not able to attend the first wedding. Maguire said of the ceremony that the [[Catholic Church]] would not permit a wedding service due to her prior divorce. Maguire said that there were many "special" people that they had wanted to include, but that they just could not wait to marry.<ref name="CMT Online">CMT Online [http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1449170/09252001/dixie_chicks.jhtml CMT Online  (Retrieved 25 September, 2005)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212233741/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1449170/09252001/dixie_chicks.jhtml |date=February 12, 2009 }}</ref> Another reason for the rush was Gareth's need to keep flying back and forth between the United States and Ireland because of visa considerations.<ref name="Minchin">Minchin III, James R. and Lieberman, Ellen InStyle Magazine; February 2003, Vol. 10 Issue 2, pg. 244 Retrieved September 25, 2005</ref> After her second marriage, Maguire changed her name to that of her new husband, which is why in her musical career she has been credited by all three of her [[surnames]]: Erwin, Seidel, and Maguire.

Maguire and her second husband had three daughters together: [[fraternal twins]] Eva Ruth and Kathleen 'Katie' Emilie were born April 27, 2004. Katie was named after Gareth's late sister, Kathleen.<ref>Martie Maguire's twin daughters and Natalie Maines' sons [http://celebritybabies.people.com/2007/01/01/martie_maguires/][[People (magazine)|People]] (Retrieved June 28, 2012) {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011231842/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2007/01/01/martie_maguires/|date=October 11, 2016}}</ref> Their third daughter, Harper Rosie Maguire was born July 25, 2008. The couple divorced in 2013.<ref>[http://moviepilot.com/posts/3946327 On Tour Again Today, But What Do They Look Like Now?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011225726/http://moviepilot.com/posts/3946327 |date=October 11, 2016 }}</ref> In February 2022, it was revealed Maguire is married to Clem Moore.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/food/wine/article/The-newest-celebrity-wine-actually-tastes-good-a-16822825.php | title=The newest celebrity wine actually tastes good: A Sonoma rosé from country band the Chicks | newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle | date=February 2022 | last1=Mobley | first1=By Esther }}</ref>

Maguire has been frank about using [[in vitro fertilization]] to conceive their daughters. In an interview in ''[[Conceive (magazine)|Conceive]]'', she said, "All my paperwork said 'unspecified origin.'  We spent three years of active trying before we went to IVF. First I went on [[Clomid]]. Then I had some dye tests and found I had a collapsed tube, so I had [[laparoscopic surgery]]; the tube wasn't blocked, just spasming." After three attempts at [[intrauterine insemination]], she said, she and her husband didn't think it was worth continuing in that manner, and switched to [[IVF]].<ref name="common1">{{cite web|url=http://www.conceiveonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=71&Itemid=22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206171500/http://www.conceiveonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=71&Itemid=22 |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 6, 2009 |title=The Dixie Chicks: Taking the Long Way ... to Motherhood |last=Weinhouse |first=Beth |date=Fall 2007 |publisher=Conceive Magazine Online |access-date=2008-07-27 }}</ref> In August 2007, Maguire began IVF again, resulting in their third daughter Harper. In 2008, regarding the number of children the Dixie Chicks had produced in the past seven years, (Maines had two; Strayer had four in addition to Maguire's twins and newborn) Maguire told ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' "We'll have to move over and let the little chicks take over! We've got a new band!"<ref name="People">''People Magazine'' (accessed January 28, 2008) [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20174066,00.html  Dixie Chick Martie Maguire Is Expecting]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914183801/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20174066%2C00.html |date=September 14, 2016 }}</ref>

Maguire and Strayer co-wrote a song, "So Hard", about their own personal experiences with infertility and their need to rely on other methods to conceive. They speak out about the difficulties they faced, but also their good fortune; both having options that for many women are financially prohibitive. Mentioning the [[social stigma|stigma]] attached to IVF, Maguire said, "I think we feel a responsibility to break down some barriers. It's much more of a common problem than people realize."<ref name="FrontpagePublicity">Frontpage Publicity [http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/bio.html  Dixie Chicks Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017015925/http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/bio.html |date=October 17, 2015 }}</ref> A final concern Maguire mentioned was the question of what to do with all the unused frozen [[embryos]].<blockquote>Now that I have children, I see those embryos as possible children. So I have to think about what my options are if there are leftovers again. I could keep them in storage, and maybe they will help my children some day. Or I can try to donate them to [[stem cell research]]. I don't think I could give them to another family. I would always worry: what if it's an abusive family? What if they don't get enough love?<ref name="common1"/>{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</blockquote>

Natalie Maines has noted that she and Maguire learned [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=Dixie Chicks, Russell Simmons Meditate on Rick Rubin's Greatness at David Lynch Foundation Event|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=February 28, 2014 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dixie-chicks-russell-simmons-meditate-684492|access-date=April 27, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304083118/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dixie-chicks-russell-simmons-meditate-684492|archive-date=March 4, 2014|url-status=live|quote=Maines is a TM-er, it turns out. Eighteen years ago, she told the crowd, she and fiddler Martie Erwin went to learn TM together}}</ref>

==Discography==
{{main|The Chicks discography}}
* Maguire played fiddle on the song, "Somewhere Down The Road" on the [[eponymous]] album, ''[[Deryl Dodd]]'' by [[Deryl Dodd]] on Sony.
* Maguire also played fiddle on [[The Flatlanders]]' adaptation of [[Woody Guthrie]]'s "Sowing on the Mountain" on their 2009 album ''Hills and Valleys.''
* As part of the [[Court Yard Hounds]], Maguire played fiddle and provided harmony vocals on the song "She Sang Hymns Out Of Tune" on the ''[[Cass County (album)|Cass County]]'' album by [[Don Henley]].

{{Infobox musical artist
| name              = Micky & the Motorcars
| image             = Micky and the Motorcars blacksheep 2017 7933.jpg
| image_upright     = 1.2
| caption           = Micky & the Motorcars at the 2017 Blacksheep Festival
| origin            = [[Challis, Idaho]], United States
| genre             = [[Alternative country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Texas country]], [[roots rock]], [[country rock]]
| years_active      = 2002–present
| label             = Smith Music Group, [[Thirty Tigers]]
| associated_acts   = [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]]<br/>[[Reckless Kelly (band)|Reckless Kelly]]<br/>[[Mike McClure]]<br />[[Jason Boland & the Stragglers]]
| current_members   = Micky Braun<br/>Gary Braun<br/>Bobby Paugh<br/>Pablo Trujillo<br/>Andrew Carrell
| past_members      = {{unbulleted list|Mark McCoy (2001–2011)| Travis Hardy (2001–2003)| Ken Smith (2001–2002)|Joseph Deeb (2002–2007)| Kris Farrow (2007-2011)| Shane Vannerson (2004–2013)| Dustin Schaefer (2011–2016) | Joe Fladger (2011-2021)}}
| website           = {{URL|https://mickyandthemotorcars.com/}}
| background        = group_or_band
}}
'''Micky & the Motorcars''' is a [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt]] band formed in [[Stanley, Idaho]], now based in [[Austin, Texas]]. They have released nine albums, including two live albums.

==Background==
[[File:Micky and the Motorcars blacksheep 2017 7872.jpg|thumb|Micky Braun 2017]]

The two founding members, Micky and Gary Braun, are the sons of [[outlaw country]] and western swing musician Muzzie Braun of [[Stanley, Idaho]], and the brothers of Cody Braun and Willy Braun of the [[Texas]]-based [[roots rock]] band [[Reckless Kelly (band)|Reckless Kelly]]. Both were part of Muzzie Braun & the Little Braun Brothers band, but formed their own band after Cody and Willy left to form Reckless Kelly.<ref name="allmusic bio">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/micky-the-motorcars-mn0000123988/biography |title=Micky & the Motorcars |first= Steve|last= Leggett |work=AllMusic}}</ref> 

The band originated in Idaho. The other founding members were childhood friends Travis Hardy on [[Drum|drums]] and Mark McCoy on [[Bass guitar|bass]]. They moved to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas, where Joseph Deeb joined the band as their lead guitarist.<ref name="allmusic bio" /> The band has undergone a number of personnel changes since its founding. Mark McCoy left the band in 2011 and died in 2012 in a rafting accident.<ref name="the boot">{{cite web |url=https://theboot.com/micky-and-the-motorcars-hold-this-town-together/ |title=Micky and the Motorcars, 'Hold This Town Together' |work=The Boot|date= October 7, 2019 |first= Angela |last=Stefano}}</ref> 

The band currently consists of Micky Braun ([[acoustic guitar]], [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]]), Gary Braun (lead & [[harmony vocals]], guitars, [[mandolin]], [[harmonica]]), Pablo Trujillo ([[lead guitar]], [[Pedal steel guitar|pedal steel]]), Andrew Carrell (bass), and Bobby Paugh (drums & percussion).

The band is also tied to the Texas music movement and, to a lesser extent, the [[Oklahoma]]-based Red Dirt music scene. Every year, the band, in conjunction with their brothers and fellow musicians in Reckless Kelly, host the Braun Brothers Reunion in Idaho to celebrate the music and different artists from the genre.

{{Infobox musical artist 
| name                = Mike  McClure
| image               = Mike McClure (1).jpg
| birth_place         =

| origin              = [[Tecumseh, Oklahoma]], United States
| genre               = {{flatlist|

}}
| years_active        = 1992-present
| label               = None
| associated_acts     = {{flatlist|
*[[The Great Divide (band)|The Great Divide]]
*[[Cross Canadian Ragweed]]
*[[Jason Boland & the Stragglers]]
*[[Stoney LaRue]]
*[[Turnpike Troubadours]]

*[[Evans Blue]]
}}
| website                 = http://www.mikemcclureband.com - http://mikemcclureband.net
| background=solo_singer
}}
'''Mike McClure''' (born July 6, 1971) is an American singer, songwriter, and producer from [[Tecumseh, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mike McClure Myspace Blog|url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.ListAll&friendId=39123011|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306074423/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.ListAll&friendId=39123011|archivedate=2010-03-06}}</ref> He is currently the frontman for the Mike McClure Band. McClure is a founding member of [[The Great Divide (band)|The Great Divide]], and was a member until he and the band parted ways in 2002. The Mike McClure Band consists of McClure (guitar, vocals), and Caleb Shirtum (bass).<ref>{{cite news |title=Mike McClure Band|url=http://www.myspace.com/mikemcclureband}}</ref>

McClure got his start in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]], and would hang out and play music at the notorious "Farm" with other [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt]] artists such as [[Bob Childers]], Tom Skinner, and Scott Evans. After forming The Great Divide with J.J. Lester, Scotte Lester, and Kelley Green in 1992 and contributing to six studio albums and one live two-part album, McClure set out to do his own thing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mike McClure: The Red Dirt Rockstar|url=http://www.texasmusictimes.com/articles/0609/0609-Stricklan-McClure.php}}</ref>

In 2002, while still a member of The Great Divide, he released [[Twelve Pieces]], his first solo album. First there was Les Paul Clanton on bass and Rodney Pyeatt on guitar. Both went to do other projects. After recruiting Tom Skinner (bass) and Eric Hansen (drums), McClure had his band together. In 2004, The Mike McClure Band released their first album [[Everything Upside Down]], a hard-hitting rock album. McClure often uses the quote that his new band is "twice as loud, and half as popular."<ref>{{cite news |title=Mike McClure rocks the Iron Horse with Red Dirt music|url=http://www.timesrecordnews.com/news/2008/jun/21/mike-mcclure-rocks-iron-horse-red-dirt-music/}}</ref> Since the first album, the band has put out seven more albums, including the 2004 collaboration with the Burtschi Brothers of [[Norman, Oklahoma]].  After the death of Tom Skinner in July 2015 and the departure of Hansen, the band took on its current look.

As a songwriter and producer, McClure has collaborated with many other Red Dirt artists. He has become the permanent producer for [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]]. Usually contributing also as a songwriter, he has produced five of their seven studio albums, jokingly earning him the title of "prodouchebag."<ref>{{cite news|title=prodouchebag hits billboard|url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=39123011&blogId=510193607|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207065936/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view|archivedate=2009-02-07}}</ref> McClure has also produced albums by other artists around the scene such as [[Stoney LaRue]], [[Jason Boland & the Stragglers]], [[Scott Copeland]], Johnny Cooper, [[Whiskey Myers]], and the [[Turnpike Troubadours]].

In 2011 McClure Produced and Recorded with  [http://www.damnquails.com The Damn Quails], releasing "Down the Hatch"  in October 2011.

In 2014, McClure produced and recorded [http://www.chrisbrazealband.com The Chris Brazeal Band], releasing their 3rd album "A Heart Like Yours" in September 2014. He appears on their cover of Hal Ketchum's "Small Town Saturday Night"

On February 27, 2022 he was inducted into the Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame.

==Notable appearances==

"I'd Rather Have Nothing", written by McClure and originally recorded by [[The Great Divide (band)|The Great Divide]]
was recorded by [[Garth Brooks]] for his 2005 Limited Series Box Set on the album ''[[The Lost Sessions]]''.
It has sold over 2 million copies.

"Fighting For", written by McClure and [[Cody Canada]] reached number 39 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. It
was recorded by [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]] for their album ''[[Garage (album)|Garage]]''.

McClure has been working with Joe Hardy since "Foam".
