'''Miranda Leigh Lambert''' (born November 10, 1983) is an American [[country music|country]] singer, songwriter and guitarist. Born in [[Longview, Texas]], she started out in early 2001 when she released her self-titled debut album independently. In 2003, she finished in third place on the television program ''[[Nashville Star]]'', a singing competition which aired on the [[USA Network]]. Outside her solo career, she is a member of the [[Pistol Annies]], a group she formed in 2011 alongside [[Ashley Monroe]] and [[Angaleena Presley]]. Lambert has been honored by the [[Grammy Awards]], the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] and the [[Country Music Association Awards]]. Lambert has been honored with more [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] than any artist in history and was named by the Chicago Tribune as the "greatest country music artist of all time" in 2019. <ref>{{cite web |last1=Chapman |first1=Steve |title=The greatest country music artist ever ... is not a dude |date=June 14, 2019 |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/columns/steve-chapman/ct-perspec-chapman-miranda-lambert-greatest-country-artist-20190614-story.html |publisher=Chicago Tribune |access-date=6 January 2024}}</ref>

Lambert's second and major-label debut album ''[[Kerosene (album)|Kerosene]]'' (2005) was certified [[Music recording certification|Platinum]] in the United States and produced the singles "Me and Charlie Talking", "Bring Me Down", "[[Kerosene (song)|Kerosene]]" and "New Strings". All four singles reached the top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]]. Her second album, ''[[Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (album)|Crazy Ex-Girlfriend]]'', was released in early 2007. Three of its singles ("[[Famous in a Small Town]]", "[[Gunpowder & Lead]]" and "[[More Like Her]]") peaked within the top 20 on the country songs chart, with "Gunpowder & Lead" becoming her first top 10 entry in July 2008. Her third album, ''[[Revolution (Miranda Lambert album)|Revolution]]'', was released in September 2009. Two of its songs – "[[The House That Built Me]]" and "[[Heart Like Mine]]" – topped the Hot Country Songs chart. 

2011's ''[[Four the Record]]'' included the singles "[[Baggage Claim]]", "[[Over You (Miranda Lambert song)|Over You]]", "[[Fastest Girl in Town]]", "[[Mama's Broken Heart]]" and "[[All Kinds of Kinds]]". Lambert released her fifth album, ''[[Platinum (Miranda Lambert album)|Platinum]]'', in 2014.<ref name="ReferenceA">"Miranda Lambert preps fifth album", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune|Salt Lake Tribune]]'', March 13, 2014, p. B6</ref> The record won the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album]], and the album's lead single "[[Automatic (Miranda Lambert song)|Automatic]]" reached the top five on the Country charts.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/311433/miranda-lambert/chart?f=357 |title=Miranda! – Chart history |magazine=Billboard |access-date=November 19, 2016 |archive-date=November 25, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161125220527/http://www.billboard.com/artist/311433/miranda-lambert/chart?f=357 |url-status=live }}</ref> Her sixth studio album, ''[[The Weight of These Wings]]'', was released on November 18, 2016, and subsequently certified [[RIAA certification|Platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).<ref name="RIAA Certification">{{cite web |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&ar=MIRANDA+LAMBERT |title=Gold & Platinum - RIAA |publisher=RIAA |access-date=July 13, 2017 |archive-date=June 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603003703/http://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&ar=MIRANDA+LAMBERT |url-status=live }}</ref> Her seventh studio album, ''[[Wildcard (Miranda Lambert album)|Wildcard]]'', was released on November 1, 2019, and went on to win the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album]] in early 2021. Three singles from the album ("[[It All Comes Out in the Wash|It All Comes out in the Wash]]", "[[Bluebird (Miranda Lambert song)|Bluebird]]", "[[Settling Down]]") reached the top 20 of the country music charts, and the album's second official single "[[Bluebird (Miranda Lambert song)|Bluebird]]" became Lambert's first song to top the Billboard Country Airplay Chart as a solo artist since 2012.

She later collaborated with singer-songwriters [[Jon Randall]] and [[Jack Ingram]] for the album ''[[The Marfa Tapes]]'', departing from her usual sound and opting for an acoustic, stripped-back feel. It was released on May 7, 2021 to acclaim from critics. Lambert released her eighth solo album ''[[Palomino (Miranda Lambert album)|Palomino]]'' on April 29, 2022. The same year she was listed on [[100 Most Influential People]] by [[Time (magazine)|Time]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Bowenbank |first=Starr |date=2022-05-23 |title=Adele, Mary J. Blige, Miranda Lambert & More Musicians Make Time's 100 Most Influential People of 2022 List |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/time-100-most-influential-list-2022-adele-mary-j-blige-miranda-lambert-1235074177/ |access-date=2022-05-26 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |language=en-US}}</ref>

==Early life==
Miranda Leigh Lambert was born November 10, 1983,<ref name="dob"/> to Rick and Bev (née Hughes) Lambert in [[Longview, Texas]],<ref name="Miranda Lambert Biography"/> and was raised in [[Lindale, Texas]]. She was named after her great-grandmother, Lucy Miranda.<ref name="usmagazine.com">''Us Weekly'', March 30, 2011, "[http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/25-things-you-dont-know-about-me-miranda-lambert-2011303 25 Things You Don't Know About Me: Miranda Lambert] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605052934/http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/25-things-you-dont-know-about-me-miranda-lambert-2011303 |date=June 5, 2014 }}". Accessed June 1, 2014.</ref> She has one younger brother.<ref>{{cite web |last=Carey |first=Stacy |url=https://www.axs.com/miranda-lambert-s-look-alike-brother-luke-joins-sis-for-fun-evening-ou-20133 |title=Miranda Lambert's look-alike brother: Luke joins sis for evening out |date=June 23, 2014 |access-date=April 2, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402163323/https://www.axs.com/miranda-lambert-s-look-alike-brother-luke-joins-sis-for-fun-evening-ou-20133 |archive-date=April 2, 2018 }}</ref>

Her parents met while Bev was attending camp at [[Southern Methodist University]] and Rick was an on-campus undercover narcotics officer, and they got together a few years later. Rick is a former [[Dallas]] police officer who played in a country-rock group called Contraband in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/11/14/singles-going-steady-2|title=Singles Going Steady|date=November 14, 2005|magazine=The New Yorker|access-date=April 5, 2016|archive-date=August 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810092724/http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/11/14/singles-going-steady-2|url-status=live}}</ref> Rick and Bev later became [[Private investigator|private detectives]] and even worked on the high-profile case of the impeachment of President [[Bill Clinton]]. After the oil crisis dampened the economy in Texas, her family lost everything.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/amp43217/miranda-lambert-parents-private-detectives/ |title= Miranda Lambert's Parents Were Private Detectives in the Clinton Impeachment Investigation |date= May 23, 2017 |access-date= April 2, 2018 |archive-date= April 2, 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180402163534/https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/amp43217/miranda-lambert-parents-private-detectives/ |url-status= live }}</ref>

After the downturn, things got better and her parents began a faith-based ministry and offered their home as a shelter for the victims of domestic violence and their children. Miranda has said that this experience fueled her music and that her song "Gunpowder & Lead" is a reflection of that.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://amp.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/28/miranda-lambert-country-renegade-interview |title=Miranda Lambert: 'Im not just that girl with fire in my head' |date=March 28, 2016 |access-date=April 2, 2018 |archive-date=April 2, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402163436/https://amp.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/28/miranda-lambert-country-renegade-interview |url-status=live }}</ref>

While still in high school, Lambert made her professional singing debut with "The Texas Pride Band".<ref name="Maerz, Melissa 2011">Maerz, Melissa. "Country's Rebel Girl Grows Up". ''Entertainment Weekly'' 1180 (2011): 32. MasterFILE Complete. Web. September 14, 2012</ref> She also fronted the [[house band]] at the Reo Palm Isle<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/xdr03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150922165113/http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/xdr03|url-status=dead|title=REO PALM ISLE|first=HEATHER|last=MILLIGAN|date=August 7, 2010|archive-date=September 22, 2015|website=Tshaonline.org}}</ref> in [[Longview, Texas]], a long-running venue that had presented legends such as [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Willie Nelson]], and the place where [[Brooks & Dunn]] started out as the house band.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}

==Music career==
===2000–2003: Career beginnings, self-titled debut album, and ''Nashville Star''===
[[File:Miranda Lambert at Laughlin AFB.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Lambert performing at Laughlin AFB in 2006]]
At 16, Lambert appeared on the Johnnie High Country Music Revue in [[Arlington, Texas]], the same talent show that had helped launch the career of [[LeAnn Rimes]]. Lambert then acquired a recording session in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], but left the studio after she became frustrated with the "pop" type of music presented to her. She went back to Texas in 2000 and asked her father to teach her how to play guitar, so she could write her own songs.<ref name=wrangler>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/14/AR2007051401683_2.html Texas Wrangler, Page 3] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714042708/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/14/AR2007051401683_2.html |date=July 14, 2017 }}, Washington Post May 15, 2007. Retrieved November 28, 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/lambert/index.html|title=Nashville Star Show and Television Series – Miranda Lambert Musician – USA Network -Character Profile: Miranda Lambert|publisher=USA Network|access-date=July 29, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908233303/http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/lambert/index.html|archive-date=September 8, 2011}}</ref> In 2001, she released her self-titled debut album which consisted of 10 tracks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Miranda-Lambert-Miranda-Lambert/release/6020210|title=Miranda Lambert – Miranda Lambert (2001, CD)|access-date=May 8, 2021|website=Discogs.com|archive-date=February 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210223151526/https://www.discogs.com/Miranda-Lambert-Miranda-Lambert/release/6020210|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2002, Dusty Meador hired Lambert to perform at Tye Phelps' country music restaurant and venue Love and War in Texas. Lambert continued to perform around the Texas Music Scene opening for Cooder Graw, Kevin Fowler, and Jack Ingram. In 2003, she auditioned for the talent competition ''[[Nashville Star]]'', where she earned a third-place finish behind [[Buddy Jewell]] and John Arthur Martinez.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bonaguro |first1=Alison |title=Buddy Jewell: Life After Nashville Star |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1716082/buddy-jewell-life-after-nashville-star/ |website=CMT News |access-date=18 July 2019 |archive-date=July 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190718100418/http://www.cmt.com/news/1716082/buddy-jewell-life-after-nashville-star/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> During her 9-week stay on ''Nashville Star'', Lambert caught the attention of the show's judge and Sony Music executive, Tracy Gershon, who later convinced the label to sign her.

===2004–2008: ''Kerosene'' and ''Crazy Ex- Girlfriend''===
On September 15, 2003, she signed with [[Epic Records]].<ref name="about1">Fabian, Shelly. [http://countrymusic.about.com/od/news/a/blbuddymiranda.htm "'Nashville Star' Gave Buddy Jewell and Miranda Lambert Big Career Boosts"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224212457/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/news/a/blbuddymiranda.htm |date=February 24, 2009 }}. ''[[Dotdash Meredith|About.com]]''.</ref> Her debut single, "Me and Charlie Talking", co-written by her father and Heather Little, was released in summer of 2004 as the lead single to her debut album, titled ''[[Kerosene (album)|Kerosene]]''. The album comprised 12 songs, 11 of which she wrote or co-wrote. The album debuted at number one on the ''Billboard'' [[Billboard charts|Top Country Albums]] charts,<ref>Whitmire, Margo. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63594/50-squeaks-out-another-week-at-no-1 "50 Squeaks Out Another Week At No.&nbsp;11"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150608023900/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63594/50-squeaks-out-another-week-at-no-1 |date=June 8, 2015 }}. ''Billboard''. March 23, 2005.</ref> and eventually gained a Platinum certification by the RIAA for shipments of over one million copies,<ref>Draper, Jimmy. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/08/26/PKP2R9I4H.DTL "Miranda Lambert's one tough country singer on 'Crazy Ex-Girlfriend'"]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''. August 26, 2007.</ref> selling more than 930,000 copies up to July 2008.<ref>Tucker, Ken. [https://www.reuters.com/article/musicNews/idUSN1943097320080719 "Miranda Lambert's revenge tale shoots up chart"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210829055932/https://www.reuters.com/article/musicNews/idUSN1943097320080719 |date=August 29, 2021 }}. ''[[Reuters]]''. July 19, 2008.</ref> Overall, the album produced four Top 40 singles on the ''Billboard'' country charts, including the title track which was a Top 20 hit. Lambert also toured with [[Keith Urban]]<ref>Cohen, Jonathan. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/62796/billboard-bits-foos-montgomery-gentry-lambert "Billboard Bits: Foos, Montgomery Gentry, Lambert"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150608023848/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/62796/billboard-bits-foos-montgomery-gentry-lambert |date=June 8, 2015 }}. ''Billboard''. May 24, 2005.</ref> and [[George Strait]]<ref>Fabian, Shelly. [http://countrymusic.about.com/od/concertreviewsm1/a/straittour06.htm "On the Road with George Strait – Well, Kinda..."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524172740/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/concertreviewsm1/a/straittour06.htm |date=May 24, 2008 }}. ''About.com''.</ref> in early 2006. In 2007, she toured with [[Dierks Bentley]] and [[Toby Keith]]. On Thursday, August 7,2007 
Miranda played at the famous Sikeston Jaycee Bootheel Rodeo in Sikeston, Missouri. <ref>Cohen, Jonathan. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1052950/toby-keith-pencils-new-album-tour-in-for-june "Toby Keith Pencils New Album, Tour In For June"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140919110506/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1052950/toby-keith-pencils-new-album-tour-in-for-june |date=September 19, 2014 }}. ''Billboard''. April 10, 2007.</ref>

[[File:Miranda Lambert 3.jpg|200px|thumb|Lambert on stage, in [[Pontiac, Michigan]], March 31, 2007]]
Lambert's second album, ''[[Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (album)|Crazy Ex-Girlfriend]]'', was released on May 1, 2007. She wrote eight of the album's 11 tracks,<ref>Cohen, Jonathan. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1055860/miranda-lambert-not-withholding-on-second-cd "Miranda Lambert Not Withholding On Second CD"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140914025610/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1055860/miranda-lambert-not-withholding-on-second-cd |date=September 14, 2014 }}. ''Billboard''. January 19, 2007.</ref> including its four singles. Much of the track "Gunpowder & Lead", the album's third single and her highest-charting single, was written while she was taking a concealed-carry handgun class in her home town.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/14/AR2007051401683.html Texas Wrangler, Page 1] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714061516/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/14/AR2007051401683.html |date=July 14, 2017 }}, Washington Post May 15, 2007. Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref> Fady Joudah of ''The New Yorker'' said the album proved "she has talent and charisma on a par with [[Dolly Parton]], another blond beauty who was once underestimated."<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/01/07/instant-replay-3|title=Instant Replay|date=January 7, 2008|magazine=The New Yorker|access-date=April 5, 2016|archive-date=August 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810095929/http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/01/07/instant-replay-3|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2005, at the 40th Annual [[Academy of Country Music]] Awards in Las Vegas, Lambert won the [[CoverGirl]] "Fresh Face of Country Music Award". She was also nominated for the [[Country Music Association]]'s Horizon Award in 2005; in 2007, Lambert also received a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for Best Female Country Vocal Performance for her single "Kerosene". She also won the Top New Female Vocalist award at the 2007 ACM (Academy of Country Music) Awards. At the 2008 ACM (Academy of Country Music) Awards, ''Crazy Ex-Girlfriend'' won Album of the Year.

===2009–2011: ''Revolution''===
Lambert released her third album, ''Revolution'', on September 29, 2009. She co-wrote 11 of the album's 15 tracks; the album also includes co-writes from [[Dave Haywood]] and [[Charles Kelley]] of [[Lady Antebellum]] and Blake Shelton.<ref name="musicrow.com">[http://www.musicrow.com/2009/08/lambert-planning-a-revolution-at-the-ryman/ Lambert Planning A "Revolution At The Ryman"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810053109/http://www.musicrow.com/2009/08/lambert-planning-a-revolution-at-the-ryman/ |date=August 10, 2009 }}. MusicRow (August 6, 2009). Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref>

''Revolution'' received significant critical praise on its release.<ref name="Metacritic">{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/revolution|title=Revolution reviews at Metacritic.com|work=Metacritic|access-date=November 30, 2010}}</ref> At [[Metacritic]] the album received an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 85, based on 11 reviews, which indicates "universal acclaim".<ref name="Metacritic"/> The album also received positive reviews from ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Boston Globe]]'' and ''[[Slant Magazine]]''. ''Entertainment Weekly'' called the release "the best mainstream-country album so far this year".

Lambert debuted her new single, "[[Dead Flowers (Miranda Lambert song)|Dead Flowers]]", at the 44th annual Academy of Country Music Awards on April 5, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirandalambert.com/community/viewtopic.php?t=24437|title=Forum|publisher=Miranda Lambert|access-date=July 29, 2011|archive-date=July 23, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723175408/http://www.mirandalambert.com/community/viewtopic.php?t=24437|url-status=live}}</ref> It was released on May 4, 2009, and was a minor Top 40 hit on the charts. The album's second single, "[[White Liar]]", was released on August 17, 2009,<ref>[http://www.musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ Singles Calendar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304160303/http://www.musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ |date=March 4, 2015 }}. MusicRow. Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref> and debuted at No.&nbsp;50 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart. In February 2010, "White Liar" became Lambert's first Top Five hit, reaching a peak of No.&nbsp;2 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart.

[[The House That Built Me]], the album's third single, was released on March 8, 2010, and became a No.&nbsp;1 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart. It stayed there for four weeks, and received platinum certification from the [[RIAA]] on July 8, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Miranda%20Lambert&format=SINGLE&go=Search&perPage=25 |title=Recording Industry Association of America |publisher=RIAA |access-date=July 29, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225031458/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |archive-date=February 25, 2013}}</ref> "[[Only Prettier]]" followed as the album's fourth single in July 2010, and its accompanying music video went viral. The music video for "Only Prettier" featured cameo appearances by fellow country artists [[Kellie Pickler]], [[Laura Bell Bundy]], and [[Hillary Scott]] of Lady Antebellum. In December 2010, "Only Prettier" reached a peak of number 12 on the U.S. Billboard Hot Country Songs chart, giving Lambert her seventh Top 20 hit. "Heart Like Mine" was released in January 2011 as the fifth and final single from ''Revolution''. It became Lambert's second Number One hit on the country charts for the chart dated May 28, 2011.

In promotion of ''Revolution'', Lambert launched a headlining tour; ''Roadside Bars & Pink Guitars'' in March 2010, with stops in 22 cities and a performance at the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]].<ref name="headlining tour">[http://www.mirandalambert.com/news/article.php?article=190 Miranda Lambert News: Roadside Bars & Pink Guitars – The Stops] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723175229/http://www.mirandalambert.com/news/article.php?article=190 |date=July 23, 2011 }}. Mirandalambert.com. Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref>

On September 1, 2010, it was announced that Lambert had received a record-setting 9 CMA award nominations. She performed at the 44th Annual Country Music Association Awards on November 10, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/miranda-lambert/196877|title=Miranda Lambert|date=November 2, 2010|website=TVGuide.com|access-date=November 2, 2010|archive-date=November 3, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101103044513/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/miranda-lambert/196877|url-status=live}}</ref> She won the CMA Award for Female Vocalist of the Year, and her ''Revolution'' won Album of the Year.<ref>Orloff, Brian. (November 10, 2010) [http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20316530_20441129,00.html Miranda Lambert, Brad Paisley Win Big at CMA Awards] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112171348/http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20316530_20441129,00.html |date=November 12, 2010 }}. People.com. Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref> Lambert and [[Sheryl Crow]] performed "[[Coal Miner's Daughter (song)|Coal Miner's Daughter]]" as a tribute to country legend [[Loretta Lynn]] who also entered the stage to join them and finished the song with Crow and Lambert as backup. Later that night, Lynn presented the Female Vocalist of the Year CMA award to Lambert. On February 13, 2011, Lambert won a Grammy Award in the ''Best Female Country Vocal Performance'' category for "The House That Built Me".<ref>Barrett, Annie. (February 13, 2011) [http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/02/13/2011-grammys-winners-list/ Grammys 2011: The winners so far... (updated throughout the show)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215063550/http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/02/13/2011-grammys-winners-list/ |date=February 15, 2011 }}. Music-mix.ew.com. Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref>

===2011–2013: ''Four the Record'' and the Pistol Annies===
[[File:Miranda Lambert.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Miranda Lambert performing in [[Dallas]], Texas, July 1, 2007]]

On April 4, 2011, during the taping of the Academy of Country Music's 'Girls' Night Out' television special in [[Las Vegas]], Lambert debuted her new project, girl group [[Pistol Annies]]. The group consists of Lambert, [[Ashley Monroe]], and [[Angaleena Presley]]. They released their single, "Hell on Heels", in May 2011,<ref>{{cite web |first=Donna |last=Hughes |url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/04/05/pistol-annies-miranda-lambert-ashley-monroe-angaleena-presley/ |title=Miranda Lambert Forms an All-Girl Trio, Pistol Annies |website=The Boot |date=April 11, 2011 |access-date=July 29, 2011 |archive-date=July 21, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721063928/http://www.theboot.com/2011/04/05/pistol-annies-miranda-lambert-ashley-monroe-angaleena-presley |url-status=live }}</ref> and released their debut album, ''[[Hell on Heels]]'', on August 23, 2011, which debuted at No.&nbsp;1 on Billboard's country chart. Sasha Frere-Jones of ''The New Yorker'' said the trio "is good enough to recall those transcendent moments of vocal harmony the Dixie Chicks used to hit every few months".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/best-music-2011-lists-of-lists-and-endings-of-endings|title=Best Music 2011: Lists of Lists and Endings of Endings|date=December 28, 2011|magazine=The New Yorker|access-date=April 5, 2016|archive-date=April 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160411021448/http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/best-music-2011-lists-of-lists-and-endings-of-endings|url-status=live}}</ref>

Lambert's fourth studio album, ''[[Four the Record]]'', was released on November 1, 2011;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatis11111.com/ |title=Miranda Lambert's New Album |website=Whatis11111.com |date=June 6, 2011 |access-date=July 29, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713112907/http://www.whatis11111.com/ |archive-date=July 13, 2011 }}</ref> her first album for [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]], after Sony Music Nashville announced a corporate restructuring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1669904/miranda-lambert-moves-to-rca-nashville.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103204436/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1669904/miranda-lambert-moves-to-rca-nashville.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 3, 2011|title=Miranda Lambert Moves to RCA Nashville|date=August 29, 2011|work=CMT|access-date=August 29, 2011}}</ref> ''Four the Record'' produced five singles: "[[Baggage Claim]]", "[[Over You (Miranda Lambert song)|Over You]]", "[[Fastest Girl in Town]]", "[[Mama's Broken Heart]]" and "[[All Kinds of Kinds]]". "[[Over You (Miranda Lambert song)|Over You]]", which Lambert and Shelton co-wrote, reached number 1 in early 2012.

On February 8, 2012, Lambert made her acting debut on [[NBC]]'s long-running [[legal drama]], ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' in an episode titled "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (season 13)#ep13|Father's Shadow]]".<ref>{{cite news|last=Bryant|first=Adam|title=Exclusive: Miranda Lambert to Make Acting Debut on Law & Order: SVU|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Law-Order-SVU-Miranda-Lambert-1041342.aspx|access-date=February 8, 2012|newspaper=TV Guide|date=January 7, 2012|archive-date=January 9, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109092153/http://www.tvguide.com/News/Law-Order-SVU-Miranda-Lambert-1041342.aspx|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Stanhope|first=Kate|title=Exclusive: Miranda Lambert Previews Her "Nerve-Racking" SVU Acting Debut|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Miranda-Lambert-SVU-Video-1042888.aspx|access-date=February 8, 2012|newspaper=TV Guide|date=February 8, 2012|archive-date=February 10, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210202230/http://www.tvguide.com/News/Miranda-Lambert-SVU-Video-1042888.aspx|url-status=live}}</ref> Lambert later told ''[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT News]]'' she was a big fan of the show: "I never wanted to act. I still don't. I don't want to be an actress. I just wanted to be on that show mainly so I could be a groupie [for their autographs]."<ref name=LambertSVUCMT>{{cite news|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|title=OFFSTAGE: Miranda Lambert Nervous to Watch Law & Order Tonight|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/cmt-offstage/1678767/offstage-miranda-lambert-nervous-to-watch-law-order-tonight.jhtml|access-date=February 9, 2012|newspaper=County Music Television News|date=February 8, 2012|archive-date=February 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211074134/http://www.cmt.com/news/cmt-offstage/1678767/offstage-miranda-lambert-nervous-to-watch-law-order-tonight.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Late in 2012, Lambert appeared on Shelton's Christmas album ''[[Cheers, It's Christmas]]'', to which she contributed guest vocals on a version of "[[Jingle Bell Rock]]". The soundtrack was released on October 2, 2012.  On October 23, 2012, Lambert and [[Dierks Bentley]] announced the co-headlined 33-show Locked & Reloaded Tour, which began on January 17, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-dierks-bentley-2013-locked-reloaded-tour/|title=Miranda Lambert, Dierks Bentley Announce 2013 Locked & Reloaded Tour|publisher=Taste of Country|date=October 23, 2012|access-date=December 20, 2012|archive-date=January 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130110143313/http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-dierks-bentley-2013-locked-reloaded-tour/|url-status=live}}</ref>

On May 7, 2013, a second Pistol Annies album, ''[[Annie Up]]'', was released.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-the-pistol-annies-reunite-for-barn-burning-hush-hush-61242/|title=See the Pistol Annies Reunite for Barn-Burning 'Hush Hush'|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=2015-10-06|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-26|archive-date=March 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190326180304/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-the-pistol-annies-reunite-for-barn-burning-hush-hush-61242/|url-status=live}}</ref> This album produced the group's first country chart entry with "Hush Hush". The Pistol Annies are also one of many acts featured on Blake Shelton's 2013 single "[[Boys 'Round Here]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/blake-shelton-boys-round-here-video/|title=Blake Shelton Recruits Pistol Annies, RaeLynn + More for a Party in 'Boys 'Round Here' Video|last=Sciarretto|first=Amy|website=Taste of Country|date=May 3, 2013 |language=en|access-date=2019-03-26}}</ref> which went to number 1 on [[Country Airplay]]. They had previously accompanied Shelton on a rendition of "[[Blue Christmas (song)|Blue Christmas]]" on ''Cheers, It's Christmas''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1719213/blake-shelton-burning-miranda-lambert-up-on-christmas-tunes/|title=Blake Shelton Burning Miranda Lambert Up on Christmas Tunes|last=Bonaguro 12/17/2013|first=Alison|website=CMT News|access-date=2019-03-26|archive-date=March 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190326180304/http://www.cmt.com/news/1719213/blake-shelton-burning-miranda-lambert-up-on-christmas-tunes/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===2014–2015: ''Platinum''===
"[[Automatic (Miranda Lambert song)|Automatic]]", the [[lead single]] from Lambert's fifth studio album, ''[[Platinum (Miranda Lambert album)|Platinum]]'', was released on February 5, 2014, to praise from music critics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-new-single-automatic-february-5/ |title=Miranda Lambert Announces 'Automatic' as First Single From Fifth Album |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=February 1, 2014 |access-date=June 3, 2014 |archive-date=June 5, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605082109/http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-new-single-automatic-february-5/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jon |last=Freeman |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/miranda-lambert-prepares-new-single-automatic |title=Miranda Lambert Prepares New Single, "Automatic" |publisher=Country Weekly |date=January 31, 2014 |access-date=June 3, 2014 |archive-date=April 26, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426042009/http://www.countryweekly.com/news/miranda-lambert-prepares-new-single-automatic |url-status=live }}</ref> The album, containing 16 songs, was released on June 3, 2014.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The album's second single, "[[Somethin' Bad]]", is a duet with [[Carrie Underwood]] and was debuted on the [[2014 Billboard Music Awards|2014 ''Billboard'' Music Awards]] on May 18. The album's third single, "[[Little Red Wagon (Miranda Lambert song)|Little Red Wagon]]", was released to country radio on January 12, 2015. The album's fourth single, "[[Smokin' and Drinkin']]" released to country radio on June 22, 2015.

===2016–2018: ''The Weight of These Wings'' and third Pistol Annies album===
In March 2016, Lambert made her first ever performances outside the US and Canada as one of the headliners of [[C2C: Country to Country]], Europe's biggest country music festival, which saw Lambert play in England, Scotland and Ireland alongside [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Thomas Rhett]] and [[Ashley Monroe]]. On July 18, 2016, Lambert released "[[Vice (Miranda Lambert song)|Vice]]" to country radio and digital outlets. Written by Lambert, [[Shane McAnally]] and [[Josh Osborne]], it was her first song released since ''Platinum''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://muzwave.com/2016/07/miranda-lambert-shares-new-song-vice/|title=Miranda Lambert Shares New Song "Vice"|website=Muzwave.com|date=July 19, 2016|access-date=July 19, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817103616/https://muzwave.com/2016/07/miranda-lambert-shares-new-song-vice/|archive-date=August 17, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> In September, Lambert announced her sixth studio album, ''[[The Weight of These Wings]]'', which was released on November 18, 2016. She was selected as one of 30 artists to perform on "[[Forever Country]]", a [[Mashup (music)|mashup track]] of "[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]", "[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]" and "[[I Will Always Love You]]" which celebrated 50 years of the [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062|title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video|date=September 22, 2016|website=Abcnews.go.com|access-date=June 28, 2020|archive-date=November 15, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115165209/https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062|url-status=live}}</ref> Shortly after the release of ''The Weight of These Wings'', the [[Highway Vagabond Tour]] was announced<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-2017-highway-vagabond-tour-dates/|title=Miranda Lambert Announces 2017 Highway Vagabond Tour|website=Taste of Country|date=October 14, 2016 |access-date=November 4, 2018|archive-date=November 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181105012308/http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-2017-highway-vagabond-tour-dates/|url-status=live}}</ref> and began on January 24, 2017. These were Lambert's first live shows since she was put on mandatory [[vocal rest]] and was forced to cancel her [[Keeper of the Flame Tour]] in 2016. The tour visited the US, Canada and were her first solo shows in Europe, seeing her return to England, Ireland, Scotland and, for the first time, the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chriscountry.co.uk/music/news/country-news/miranda-lambert-announces-2017-uk-tour/|title=Miranda Lambert announces 2017 UK Tour|website=Chriscountry.co.uk|access-date=November 4, 2018|archive-date=November 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181105062013/http://www.chriscountry.co.uk/music/news/country-news/miranda-lambert-announces-2017-uk-tour/|url-status=live}}</ref>

After promotion and touring for ''The Weight of These Wings'' ended, the Pistol Annies reformed and released their third studio album ''[[Interstate Gospel]]'' on November 2, 2018, which subsequently reached number 1 on the Billboard Country Albums Chart.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/pistol-annies|title=Pistol Annies Chart History|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2019-03-26|archive-date=March 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190329054533/https://www.billboard.com/music/pistol-annies|url-status=live}}</ref>

===2019–2020: ''Wildcard''===
Lambert announced that the lead-off single from her seventh studio album would be "[[It All Comes Out in the Wash]]", which was released on July 18, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/new-miranda-lambert-single-it-all-comes-out-in-the-wash-coming/|title=New Miranda Lambert single "It All Comes Out In The Wash" Coming|date=July 9, 2019|access-date=July 18, 2019|archive-date=July 18, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190718095033/https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/new-miranda-lambert-single-it-all-comes-out-in-the-wash-coming/|url-status=live}}</ref> The song was co-written by Lambert with [[Hillary Lindsey]], [[Lori McKenna]], and [[Liz Rose]] ("Love Junkies") and produced by [[Jay Joyce]], marking the first time she had worked with the producer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8520492/miranda-lambert-interview-new-single-it-all-comes-out-in-the-wash|title=Miranda Lambert Says New Single 'It All Comes Out in the Wash' Is 'Classic Me': Exclusive|first=Annie|last=Reuter|date=July 18, 2019|work=Billboard.com|access-date=July 20, 2019|archive-date=July 19, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190719093559/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8520492/miranda-lambert-interview-new-single-it-all-comes-out-in-the-wash|url-status=live}}</ref> The song was released alongside "Locomotive", another track intended for the upcoming album that she had previously debuted on the [[CMA Music Festival]] in June 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2019/07/18/miranda-lambert-drops-high-speed-bonus-track-locomotive-listen/|title=Miranda Lambert Drops High-Speed Bonus Track, "Locomotive" [Listen]|date=2019-07-18|website=Nash Country Daily|language=en-US|access-date=2019-08-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190801195205/http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2019/07/18/miranda-lambert-drops-high-speed-bonus-track-locomotive-listen/|archive-date=August 1, 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref> Two other tracks—"Mess with My Head" and "Bluebird"—were also previewed ahead of the album in August 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1810459/miranda-lambert-deals-wildcard-as-new-album/|title=Miranda Lambert Deals Wildcard as New Album|first=Craig|last=Shelburne|date=August 15, 2019|publisher=CMT.com|access-date=August 15, 2019|archive-date=August 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190815185050/http://www.cmt.com/news/1810459/miranda-lambert-deals-wildcard-as-new-album/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/nz/album/mess-with-my-head-single/1475189944|title=Mess with My Head – Single by Miranda Lambert|website=Apple Music|access-date=August 8, 2019|archive-date=August 8, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190808145516/https://music.apple.com/nz/album/mess-with-my-head-single/1475189944|url-status=live}}</ref>

Lambert's seventh studio album, ''[[Wildcard (Miranda Lambert album)|Wildcard]]'', was released on November 1, 2019.<ref name="Track Listing">{{cite magazine|last1=Freeman|first1=Jon|title=Miranda Lambert Announces New Album 'Wildcard'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/miranda-lambert-new-album-wildcard-872208/|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=August 15, 2019|access-date=August 15, 2019|archive-date=August 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190815183422/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/miranda-lambert-new-album-wildcard-872208/|url-status=live}}</ref> In promotion of the album, Lambert announced the 27-date [[Wildcard Tour]], which was set to begin on January 16, 2020, and run through May 9, 2020, but which had to be cancelled due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]]. Several solo acoustic live performances of "Bluebird" premiered on her Instagram and YouTube channels during this time, and she performed the song at the belated and socially-distanced 2020 [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACMs]],<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=Miranda Lambert Brings 'Bluebird' to the 2020 ACM Awards|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/awards/9450495/miranda-lambert-bluebird-2020-acm-awards|access-date=2021-05-11|magazine=Billboard|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091604/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/awards/9450495/miranda-lambert-bluebird-2020-acm-awards|url-status=live}}</ref> at which she won an award for [[Academy of Country Music Awards|Music Event of the Year]] for her collaboration with other female country artists, "[[Fooled Around and Fell in Love]]".

On the chart dated August 1, 2020, "Bluebird" became Lambert's first number 1 single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard charts|Country Airplay chart]] as a solo artist since 2012's "[[Over You (Miranda Lambert song)|Over You"]], and her fifth career number 1 on the chart. "Bluebird" was also a critical success, nominated for three [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA awards]], two [[Grammy Awards]], and three [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM awards]], winning the [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA Award]] for Best Music Video.<ref>{{Cite web|date=November 11, 2020|first=Angela|last=Stefano|title=Miranda Lambert's 'Bluebird' Is 2020's CMA Awards Music Video of the Year|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-2020-cma-music-video-of-the-year/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Taste of Country|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091604/https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-2020-cma-music-video-of-the-year/|url-status=live}}</ref>

"[[Settling Down]]" was released as the third official single from ''[[Wildcard (Miranda Lambert album)|Wildcard]]'' on September 21, 2020,<ref>{{Cite web|date=August 31, 2020|first=Billy|last=Dukes|title=Hear Miranda Lambert's 'Settling Down,' a Poetic New Single|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-settling-down/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Taste of Country|language=en|archive-date=May 5, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210505020915/https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-settling-down/|url-status=live}}</ref> and Lambert performed the song live at the 2020 [[Country Music Association Awards|CMAs]] with just two guitarists backing. As of May 10, 2021, the song had reached the top 10 of both the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] Chart and the Billboard Country Airplay Chart, making it her 14th career top 10 hit on the Country Airplay Chart and her 16th on the Hot Country Songs Chart.

The album ''[[Wildcard (Miranda Lambert album)|Wildcard]]'' went on to be nominated for both [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM]] and [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA]] Album of the Year, and won the 2021 [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]] for the Best Country Album on 15 March.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-03-14|title=Miranda Lambert Wins Best Country Album|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/miranda-lambert-wins-best-country-album-2021-winner|access-date=2021-05-11|website=GRAMMY.com|language=en|archive-date=May 9, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210509133332/https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/miranda-lambert-wins-best-country-album-2021-winner|url-status=live}}</ref> She performed "Bluebird" at the awards ceremony.

===2021–2022: ''The Marfa Tapes'', ''Palomino'', and Pistol Annies Christmas Album===
Lambert hinted at an upcoming project with longtime friends and collaborators [[Jon Randall]] and [[Jack Ingram]] via her social media accounts on March 2, 2021, before announcing their upcoming collaborative acoustic record ''The Marfa Tapes'' in the following days, to be released on May 7. The tracklist was announced, with Lambert's previously recorded songs "[[Tin Man (Miranda Lambert song)|Tin Man]]" and "[[Wildcard (Miranda Lambert album)|Tequila Does]]" both set to be featured on the album, and the first new song ''In His Arms'' was premiered with a video on March 5.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Listen: Miranda Lambert Releases 'In His Arms' From Upcoming Album 'The Marfa Tapes'|url=https://popculture.com/country-music/news/miranda-lambert-releases-in-his-arms-upcoming-album-the-marfa-tapes/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Country Music|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091606/https://popculture.com/country-music/news/miranda-lambert-releases-in-his-arms-upcoming-album-the-marfa-tapes/|url-status=live}}</ref> The album was recorded in Marfa, Texas towards the end of 2020 with just two microphones and two acoustic guitars, and was said to have an unpolished feel, with one-take recordings retaining mistakes and snapshots of conversations between the three, and the sound of the campfire and the desert in the background. It would contain 15 songs the three singer-songwriters had written together over a period of six years, beginning in July 2015.

''In His Arms'' was performed live by Lambert, Randall and Ingram at the 2021 [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Awards]], and at the awards show Lambert also performed "[[Drunk (And I Don't Wanna Go Home)]]" with [[Elle King]], and she also stood in last-minute for [[Chris Stapleton]]'s wife [[Morgane Stapleton]] to sing harmony on Stapleton's performance of ''Maggie's Song.''

The new recording of [[Tin Man (Miranda Lambert song)|"Tin Man]]", alongside previously unheard tracks "Am I Right or Amarillo"<ref>{{Cite magazine|last1=Freeman|first1=Jon|date=2021-03-26|title=Miranda Lambert Harmonizes With Jon Randall, Jack Ingram on 'Am I Right or Amarillo'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/marfa-tapes-miranda-lambert-am-i-right-or-amarillo-1147465/|access-date=2021-05-11|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091604/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/marfa-tapes-miranda-lambert-am-i-right-or-amarillo-1147465/|url-status=live}}</ref> and "Geraldene"<ref>{{Cite web|last=Zisman|first=Erica|date=2021-04-28|title=Miranda Lambert Releases "Geraldene" with Jack Ingram and Jon Randall|url=https://nycountryswag.com/miranda-lambert-geraldene-the-marfa-tapes/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=NYCS|language=en-US|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511212020/https://nycountryswag.com/miranda-lambert-geraldene-the-marfa-tapes/|url-status=live}}</ref> were also pre-released before the album's release on May 7, and the trio performed "Geraldene" live on ''[[The Ellen Show]]'' later in the month.<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 28, 2021|first=Billy|last=Dukes|title=WATCH: Miranda Lambert Brings G-G-G-Geraldene to 'Ellen'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-geraldene-ellen-video/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Taste of Country|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511133924/https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-geraldene-ellen-video/|url-status=live}}</ref> Around this time, Miranda Lambert replied to a comment regarding her band the [[Pistol Annies]] in the comments section of her Instagram post, fuelling speculation that a new [[Pistol Annies]] project might be in the works for 2021. Lambert subsequently revealed that she "didn't do much in the beginning of 2020. [She] just sort of enjoyed the break... And then in the last six months or so [she] kind of worked overtime to make up for lost time",<ref name="tasteofcountry.com">{{Cite web|date=May 7, 2021|first=Billy|last=Dukes|title=Miranda Lambert Says Songs From 'The Marfa Tapes' Will Make Her Next Solo Album|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-the-marfa-tapes-will-make-her-next-solo-album/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Taste of Country|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091605/https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-the-marfa-tapes-will-make-her-next-solo-album/|url-status=live}}</ref> and that an upcoming solo record was therefore in the works. She commented in the same article that she was considering re-recording several tracks from ''The Marfa Tapes'' for this record, including "In His Arms" and "Geraldene", and potentially other personal favourites, such as "Waxahachie"''.''<ref name="tasteofcountry.com"/>

The trio announced that alongside the record, they would be released 'The Marfa Tapes' film on Lambert's [[Facebook]] page to be available for 24 hours from May 8, which would feature acoustic performances from the record alongside interviews and behind-the-scenes footage from the recording process of the album.<ref>{{Cite web|last=lafferlauren|date=2021-04-29|title=Miranda Lambert, Jack Ingram and Jon Randall Announce 'The Marfa Tapes' Film|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/miranda-lambert-marfa-tapes-film/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Sounds Like Nashville|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511103307/https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/miranda-lambert-marfa-tapes-film/|url-status=live}}</ref>

The Marfa Tapes album was released to critical acclaim on May 7, with critics applauding Lambert's musical risk-taking and the simple but effective songwriting. [[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] commented, "Somewhere between a demo collection, a live album with no audience, and a lo-fi left turn, this music is a joy to hear, like a vacation on record",<ref>{{Cite web|title=Jack Ingram / Miranda Lambert / Jon Randall: The Marfa Tapes|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jack-ingram-miranda-lambert-jon-rand-the-marfa-tapes/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Pitchfork|language=en|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511091604/https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/jack-ingram-miranda-lambert-jon-rand-the-marfa-tapes/|url-status=live}}</ref> and [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] questioned whether this might even be Lambert's best record so far, "And like her bigger, broader sounding albums, she gives as good as she gets, quietly, while sounding as grand as if she had a studio band's excess at work."<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Amorosi|first1=A. D.|date=2021-05-08|title=Miranda Lambert Takes It Home to Texas With Jack Ingram and Jon Randall on 'The Marfa Tapes': Album Review|url=https://variety.com/2021/music/album-reviews/miranda-lambert-marfa-tapes-jon-randall-jack-ingram-1234969181/|access-date=2021-05-11|website=Variety|language=en-US|archive-date=May 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210511115649/https://variety.com/2021/music/album-reviews/miranda-lambert-marfa-tapes-jon-randall-jack-ingram-1234969181/|url-status=live}}</ref> The film premiered on Lambert's Facebook page on May 8, featuring original songs not previously seen and not included on ''[[The Marfa Tapes]]'', the first of which was "Tornado" — co-written by Lambert, Randall and Ingram — and also a Lambert solo-written piece, "They've Closed Down the Honky-Tonks".

In the week following the album's release, the trio performed lead single "In His Arms" once more, on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]''.

On October 15, she released the lead single from her upcoming studio album, "[[If I Was a Cowboy|If I Was A Cowboy]]", on October 15. The song's first video was uploaded to YouTube on October 15, and a later official video was uploaded to YouTube on January 12, 2022. The single has been a moderate hit on the country singles charts, so far reaching the top 20 of both the Country Airplay Chart and the Hot Country Songs Chart.

The Pistol Annies announced the release of their first Christmas album, ''Hell of a Holiday,'' which was released October 22, 2021.<ref name="Price">{{Cite web |last=Price |first=Jason |date=2021-10-27 |title=Pistol Annies Ring In The Festive Season With 'Hell of a Holiday' Album |url=https://www.iconvsicon.com/2021/10/27/pistol-annies-ring-in-the-festive-season-with-hell-of-a-holiday-album/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Icon Vs. Icon |language=en-US}}</ref> It contains 10 original songs, a cover of Merle Haggard's "If We Make It Through December", popular Christmas classic "Sleigh Ride", and traditional New Year's song "Auld Lang Syne".<ref name="Price"/> The album was well-received for its original content, and Billboard praised their cover of "If We Make It Through December" as "One of the most striking moments on ''Hell of a Holiday"''.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Bernstein |first=Jonathan |date=2021-10-22 |title=Pistol Annies Bring Melancholy Harmony to Merle Haggard's 'If We Make It Through December' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/pistol-annies-cover-merle-haggard-if-we-make-it-through-december-1246414/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> They performed many of the songs and discussed the album on December 15's "The Pistol Annies Hell of a Holiday Special", which was made available on Facebook.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-12-01 |title=Pistol Annies Aim to Serve Up Hell of a Holiday Christmas Special |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/pistol-annies-aim-to-serve-up-hell-of-a-holiday-christmas-special/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref>

On December 30, 2021, Lambert released "Y'all Means All" in support of the LGBTQ community. The song was used in the trailer for the sixth season of [[Queer Eye (2018 TV series)|''Queer Eye'']].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Strauss|first=Matthew|title=Miranda Lambert Shares New Queer Eye Song "Y'all Means All": Listen|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/miranda-lambert-shares-new-queer-eye-song-yall-means-all-listen/|date=December 30, 2021|access-date=January 1, 2022|website=Pitchfork|archive-date=January 1, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220101085429/https://pitchfork.com/news/miranda-lambert-shares-new-queer-eye-song-yall-means-all-listen/|url-status=live}}</ref>
In March 2022 she won Entertainer of the Year at the American Country Music Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/noms |title=Winners |publisher=Academy of Country Music |access-date=March 14, 2022}}</ref>

Lambert and [[Elle King]]'s 2021 collaboration "[[Drunk (And I Don't Wanna Go Home)]]" was certified platinum in February, and the two performed the song together at the Ryman Auditorium on Feb 28th to celebrate.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-01 |title=Elle King and Miranda Lambert Surprised as 'Drunk (And I Don't Wanna Go Home)' Goes Platinum |url=https://countrynow.com/elle-king-and-miranda-lambert-surprised-as-drunk-and-i-dont-wanna-go-home-goes-platinum/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Country Now |language=en-US}}</ref> The single has so far reached the top 10 of the country charts.

Lambert released a teaser for a new song titled "Strange" ahead of the [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Awards]], which were held on March 7 in [[Las Vegas|Vegas]]. She was nominated for 5 awards, marking her record-breaking 16th nomination for Female Vocalist of the Year, and she won Video of the Year for "Drunk (And I Don't Wanna Go Home)", and as well as the top prize of the night, Entertainer of the Year, for the first time in her career.<ref>{{Cite web |title=ACM Awards 2022: See the full list of winners |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/07/entertainment/acm-awards-2022/index.html |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=CNN |date=March 7, 2022 }}</ref> This brings her tally of total ACM Awards won to 37, the most of all time, and also meant that she is eligible for the ACM's rare and coveted Triple Crown Award.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-08 |title=Miranda Lambert's ACM Entertainer of the Year Win Qualifies Her For Coveted Triple Crown Award |url=https://countrynow.com/miranda-lamberts-acm-entertainer-of-the-year-win-qualifies-her-for-coveted-triple-crown-award/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Country Now |language=en-US}}</ref>

On March 10, Lambert released "Strange" alongside a video on her YouTube channel, and announced her ninth solo studio album, ''[[Palomino (Miranda Lambert album)|Palomino]]'', which was released on April 29.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-10 |title=Miranda Lambert Announces New Album Palomino, Shares Video for New Song "Strange" |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/miranda-lambert-announces-new-album-palomino-shares-video-for-new-song-strange-watch/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref> The album includes "[[If I Was a Cowboy]]" and "Strange", alongside three re-recorded tracks from her 2021 ''[[The Marfa Tapes|Marfa Tapes]]'' album with [[Jon Randall]] and [[Jack Ingram]]: "Geraldene", "In His Arms", and "Waxahachie".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dukes |first=Billy |title=JUST IN: Miranda Lambert Announces New Album, 'Palomino' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-palomino-album/ |access-date=2022-03-12 |website=Taste of Country |date=March 10, 2022}}</ref>

Lambert headlined Europe's largest country music festival, [[C2C: Country to Country|C2C: Country 2 Country]], from March 11–13, 2022, marking her first performances in the UK/Europe since her headlining tour there in 2017. She performed two songs from ''Palomino'' live for the first time ever at her London show on March 11, her single "If I Was a Cowboy" and "Actin' Up".<ref>{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Young |title=Miranda Lambert Debuts New Song From 'Palomino' At C2C Fest, "Actin' Up" |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/03/12/miranda-lambert-debuts-new-song-from-palomino-at-c2c-fest-actin-up/ |website=Whiskey Riff |date=March 12, 2022 |access-date=March 14, 2022}}</ref>

===2023–present: ''Postcards from Texas'' and label change===
In March 2023, Lambert announced that she was leaving [[Sony Music Nashville]] after nineteen years.<ref>{{cite tweet |url=https://twitter.com/mirandalambert/status/1636098741089325058 |title=Since I was 19-years-old, Sony has been my home in Nashville. |user=mirandalambert |last=Lambert |first=Miranda |number=1636098741089325058 |date=March 15, 2023 |access-date=December 29, 2023}}</ref>

In April 2024, Lambert announced that she had signed a joint deal with [[Republic Records]] and [[Big Loud]], with the latter set to handle country radio promotion and marketing.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willman |first=Chris |date=2024-04-23 |title=Miranda Lambert Signs With Republic, With Partner Label Big Loud Set to Handle Country Promotion |url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/miranda-lambert-signs-republic-big-loud-1235978751/ |access-date=2024-04-24 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref> She also announced the first single under the new contract, "[[Wranglers (song)|Wranglers]]", which was released on May 3, 2024. It serves as the lead single to her tenth studio album, [[Postcards from Texas]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Newman |first=Melinda |date=2024-04-23 |title=Miranda Lambert Signs with Republic Records |url=https://www.billboard.com/business/record-labels/miranda-lambert-signs-republic-records-1235663401/ |access-date=2024-04-24 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> Promotional single "Dammit Randy" was released on June 28, 2024, a song she co-wrote with her husband, Brendan McLoughlin.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-dammit-randy-lyrics-brendan-mcloughlin/|title=Miranda Lambert's "Dammit Randy" Has a Very Special Co-Writer|author=Carena Liptak|date=July 2, 2024|website=Taste of Country|accessdate=July 4, 2024}}</ref>

==Endorsements and business ventures==
In 2009, Lambert and two other singers became the new faces of [[Cotton Incorporated|Cotton Inc.'s]] revived "The Touch, The Feel of Cotton" campaign.<ref>[http://www.the9513.com/miranda-lambert-cozies-up-with-cotton/ Miranda Lambert Cozies Up with Cotton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608012707/http://www.the9513.com/miranda-lambert-cozies-up-with-cotton/ |date=June 8, 2009 }}. The9513.com (June 1, 2009). Retrieved November 28, 2011</ref> She has appeared in ads to promote cotton, and the website features a free download of the full version of her song "Fabric of My Life".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100202014444/http://www.thefabricofourlives.com/TheFabricOfMyLife/music.html Cotton: The Fabric of My Life]. Thefabricofourlives.com</ref>

[[Gypsy Rose Blanchard]], while in control of her mother who was [[Murder of Dee Dee Blanchard|murdered by her boyfriend in June 2015]], would occasionally be given backstage passes and tickets to Lambert's concerts through the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]], even getting a photograph with both Lambert and her spouse at the time Blake Shelton. In 2013; Lambert donated an estimated $6,000 check to the mother to help with Gypsy's medical needs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2023/12/28/miranda-lambert-gave-checks-totaling-6000-to-gypsy-rose-and-her-mom-after-meeting-them-backstage-at-a-concert/|title=Miranda Lambert Donated $6,000 To Gypsy Rose And Her Mom After Meeting Them Backstage In 2013|author=Whiskey Riff|date=2023-12-28|access-date=2024-09-17}}</ref>

In December 2014, Lambert's line of shoes and boots was released through [[Designer Brands|DSW]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/miranda-lambert-launches-line-shoes-and-boots |title=Country Music News &#124; Nash Country Daily |website=Countryweekly.com |access-date=November 19, 2016 |archive-date=April 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419025105/http://www.countryweekly.com/news/miranda-lambert-launches-line-shoes-and-boots |url-status=live }}</ref> In November 2014, Lambert's partnership with [[Chrysler]]'s [[Ram Trucks|Ram trucks]] was announced. Under the partnership, Ram gave Lambert a customized 1500 Laramie Longhorn which she auctioned off, with proceeds going to Lambert's MuttNation Foundation which betters the lives for shelter animals.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://theboot.com/miranda-lambert-muttnation-foundation-truck-auction/| title=Miranda Lambert Auctions Custom Truck, Raises $66,000 for MuttNation Foundation| first=Gayle| last=Thompson| website=Theboot.com| date=November 21, 2014| access-date=November 6, 2015| archive-date=January 13, 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113043733/http://theboot.com/miranda-lambert-muttnation-foundation-truck-auction/| url-status=live}}</ref>

In May 2021, Lambert became the first female artist to open her own bar in the [[Broadway (Nashville, Tennessee)|Lower Broadway]] entertainment district of downtown Nashville, Tennessee.<ref name="casa rosa tennesseean">{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/05/28/miranda-lambert-casa-rosa-nashville-broadway-opening/7487114002/|title=Tacos, two step and tequila: Miranda Lambert's Casa Rosa honky-tonk is now open on Broadway|first=Daniella|last=Medina|date=May 28, 2021|publisher=Nashville Tennessean|access-date=May 29, 2021}}</ref> Named Casa Rosa (Spanish for "Pink House") and opened in partnership with TC Restaurant Group, the 17,400-square-foot Tex-Mex-themed establishment features live music on three  of its four stories, plus a rooftop bar, and is decked out in mostly pink decor and various memorabilia from Lambert's career (including the giant birdcage from the "Bluebird" music video).<ref name="casa rosa tennesseean"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-miranda-lamberts-nashville-bar-casa-rosa/|title=10 Things You Need To Know About Miranda Lambert's Nashville Bar 'Casa Rosa'|author=Boot Kickin' Mayhem|date=March 19, 2021|work=Music Mayhem Magazine|access-date=May 29, 2021|archive-date=June 2, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210602214603/https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-miranda-lamberts-nashville-bar-casa-rosa/|url-status=live}}</ref> At the bar's opening night party on May 25, 2021, Lambert performed a duet of "[[Summer Nights (Grease song)|Summer Nights]]" from ''Grease'' with her husband Brendan McLoughlin, amidst a star-studded lineup of performances from other country singers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-brendan-mcloughlin-grease-duet-video/|title=Miranda Lambert, Husband Brendan McLoughlin Try Out a 'Grease' Duet at Casa Rosa VIP Party|first=Billy|last=Dukes|date=May 26, 2021|publisher=Taste of Country|access-date=May 29, 2021|archive-date=May 29, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210529150531/https://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-brendan-mcloughlin-grease-duet-video/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Lambert also has her own clothing line titled ''Idyllwind'',<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://idyllwind.com/ |title=Idyllwind Fueled by Miranda Lambert |access-date=May 30, 2021 |archive-date=May 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210528000449/https://idyllwind.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref> a brand of wine with the ''Red 55 Winery'' imprint,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://red55winery.com/ |title=Red 55 Winery - the Signature Wine Line of Miranda Lambert |access-date=May 30, 2021 |archive-date=June 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210602212319/https://red55winery.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and owns The Pink Pistol boutique in her hometown of Lindale, Texas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://shop.thepinkpistol.com/ |title=The Pink Pistol |access-date=May 30, 2021 |archive-date=June 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210602215001/https://shop.thepinkpistol.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== ''Y’all Eat Yet? Welcome to the Pretty B*tchin’ Kitchen ''===
In 2023, Lambert co-authored a cookbook titled ''Y’all Eat Yet? Welcome to the Pretty B*tchin’ Kitchen'' with [[Holly Gleason]] for Dey Street Books, an imprint of [[HarperCollins]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.harpercollins.com/pages/miranda-lambert |title=''Y'All Eat Yet?''}}</ref> It includes 50 recipes inspired by "important women in Lambert's life"<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/product-recommendations/books/miranda-lambert-cookbook-yall-eat-yet-1234634685/amp/ |title='Pretty Bitchin' Kitchen': Miranda Lambert Unveils New Country Cookbook |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=August 20, 2024 |archive-date=November 23, 2022 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20221123003917/https://www.rollingstone.com/product-recommendations/books/miranda-lambert-cookbook-yall-eat-yet-1234634685/amp/ |url-status=live }}</ref> as well as her native East Texas. In addition to these recipes, the 288-page book contains personal anecdotes alongside photography featuring the farm she shares with husband Brendan McLoughlin.

==MuttNation Foundation==
In 2009, Lambert opened MuttNation Foundation, with her mother, Bev. The organization focuses on rescue animals and shelters, and Lambert has been vocal about the cause being very close to her heart. The core issues MuttNation works on are:<ref>{{cite web |url=https://muttnation.com/foundation/ |title=MuttNation Foundation website |website=Muttnation.com |access-date=April 18, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190120001307/https://muttnation.com/foundation/ |archive-date=January 20, 2019 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

* Adoption drives – held by Lambert at her concerts, CMA music awards, and the Grand Ole Opry
* Fill the little red wagon – donation drives
* Special circumstances – emergency disaster relief or instances of hoarding
* Cause for the Paws – annual fundraising concerts
* Mutts Across America – provides funds and support to shelters in all 50 US states.
* Ran's Animal Care Express – pet transports
* Mutt March – an annual 5k with proceeds going to MuttNation causes

In 2017, in the wake of [[Hurricane Harvey]]'s devastation, MuttNation rescued dozens of animals as a part of its emergency/natural disasters objective.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/amp/Entertainment/miranda-lambert-mobilizes-muttnation-animals-hurricane-harvey/story?id=49516759 |title=Miranda Lambert helps animals after Hurricane Harvey |website=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |date=August 30, 2017 |access-date=April 18, 2018 |archive-date=April 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419121122/https://abcnews.go.com/amp/Entertainment/miranda-lambert-mobilizes-muttnation-animals-hurricane-harvey/story?id=49516759 |url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2014, Lambert opened Redemption Ranch, a shelter in [[Tishomingo, Oklahoma]], her adopted home town where she lived with Shelton.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/miranda-lambert-discusses-pet-charity-interview-20141104|title=Miranda Lambert Talks Pet Charity, Latest Hometown Project|first=Deborah Evans|last=Price|date=November 4, 2014|website=Rollingstone.com|access-date=November 4, 2018|archive-date=June 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180619140802/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/miranda-lambert-discusses-pet-charity-interview-20141104|url-status=live}}</ref>

To support the foundation, Lambert released a line of pet products in 2019 that are sold inside [[Tractor Supply Company]] stores.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Thompson|first=Gayle|date=2019-08-05|title=Miranda Lambert Announces Partnership With Tractor Supply Company and Her MuttNation Foundation|url=https://popculture.com/country-music/news/miranda-lambert-announces-partnership-tractor-supply-company-muttnation-foundation/|access-date=2022-02-08|website=Popculture|language=en}}</ref>

In September 2022, MuttNation partnered with Greater Good Charities via the global nonprofit's GOODS Program to provide 2 million pet meals to help families going through economic challenges to stay with their beloved pets.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=Miranda Lambert's MuttNation Foundation Is Providing 2 Million Meals for Needy Pets|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/miranda-lambert-helping-provide-2-million-meals-needy-pets-1235142396/|date=September 21, 2022|access-date=September 22, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

==Personal life==
In 2006, Lambert began dating singer [[Blake Shelton]]. They got engaged in May 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalledger.com/artman/publish/article_272631749.shtml|title=Miranda Lambert's Engagement Ring (Photo) Blake Shelton Pops the Question|work=National Ledger|date=May 12, 2010|access-date=May 19, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515120056/http://www.nationalledger.com/artman/publish/article_272631749.shtml|archive-date=May 15, 2010}}</ref><ref name="peoplem"/> and were married on May 14, 2011, at the Don Strange Ranch in [[Boerne, Texas]].<ref name="peoplem">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20489773,00.html|title=Miranda Lambert and Blake Shelton Marry!|last=Bartolomeo|first=Joey|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=May 15, 2011|access-date=May 15, 2011|archive-date=October 18, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018222754/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20489773,00.html|url-status=live}}</ref> On July 20, 2015, the couple announced that they were divorcing after four years of marriage.<ref name=freep>''Detroit Free Press''; "Lambert-Shelton News Real This Time"; July 21, 2015; page 3C</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/07/20/miranda-lambert-and-blake-shelton-announce-divorce/|title=Miranda Lambert and Blake Shelton announce divorce|work=Fox News|access-date=July 21, 2015|archive-date=July 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721011147/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/07/20/miranda-lambert-and-blake-shelton-announce-divorce/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In December 2015, it was confirmed that Lambert was dating R&B singer [[Anderson East]]; they met at Nashville's [[Live on the Green Music Festival]] in September of that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.people.com/article/miranda-lambert-dating-anderson-east |title=Miranda Lambert Is Dating Anderson East|access-date=December 29, 2015}}</ref> In 2016, Lambert paid $3.4&nbsp;million for a 400-plus acre farm, with three residences, near [[Primm Springs, Tennessee]].<ref name="variety.com">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/dirt/real-estalker/miranda-lambert-tennessee-compound-1201691030/|title=Miranda Lambert: Tennessee Compound Bought by Country Star|first=Mark|last=David|work=Variety|date=February 3, 2016|access-date=December 11, 2017|archive-date=December 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212152509/http://variety.com/2016/dirt/real-estalker/miranda-lambert-tennessee-compound-1201691030/|url-status=live}}</ref> In April 2018, it was confirmed that Lambert and East had broken up months earlier after two years of dating.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/music/acms-2018-miranda-lambert-solo-after-anderson-east-split/amp/ |title=Miranda Lambert Is Ravishing in Red as She Hits the ACMs Solo After Anderson East Split |date=April 15, 2018 |access-date=April 18, 2018 |archive-date=April 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419121134/http://people.com/music/acms-2018-miranda-lambert-solo-after-anderson-east-split/amp/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Lambert started dating [[Turnpike Troubadours]] frontman [[Evan Felker]] in February 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-dating-evan-felker-turnpike-troubadours/amp/ |title=Miranda Lambert Dating Turnpike Troubadours Singer Evan Felker After Anderson East Split: Report |date=April 24, 2018 |access-date=April 24, 2018 |archive-date=April 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180425040410/http://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-dating-evan-felker-turnpike-troubadours/amp/ |url-status=live }}</ref> His estranged wife, Staci, has alleged that he left her suddenly to be with Lambert.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/04/25/blake-shelton-tweets-about-karma-after-reports-ex-miranda-lambert-is-dating-married-man.html|title=Blake Shelton tweets about 'karma' after reports ex Miranda Lambert is dating a married man|last=Savitsky|first=Sasha|date=April 25, 2018|work=Fox News|access-date=July 25, 2018|language=en-US|archive-date=July 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726071830/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/04/25/blake-shelton-tweets-about-karma-after-reports-ex-miranda-lambert-is-dating-married-man.html|url-status=live}}</ref> They broke up in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-reveals-split-from-evan-felker-happily-single/amp/|title=Miranda Lambert Reveals Split from Evan Felker: I'm 'Happily Single'|date=August 25, 2018|website=People|access-date=November 4, 2018|archive-date=September 6, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906063220/https://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-reveals-split-from-evan-felker-happily-single/amp/|url-status=live}}</ref>

On February 16, 2019, Lambert announced on social media that she married [[New York City Police Department]] Officer Brendan McLoughlin on January 26, 2019, in [[Davidson County, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/music/miranda-lambert-married-brendan-mcloughlin/|title=Miranda Lambert Reveals She Secretly Married Brendan Mcloughlin: 'My Heart Is Full'|date=2019-02-16|website=People|language=en|access-date=2019-02-16|archive-date=February 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190217012206/https://people.com/music/miranda-lambert-married-brendan-mcloughlin/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-new-husband-brendan-mcloughlin-what-to-know/amp/ |title=What to Know About Miranda Lambert's New Husband Brendan McLoughlin |last=Rubenstein |first=Janine |date=2019-02-16 |access-date=2019-02-16 |archive-date=February 17, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190217072323/https://people.com/country/miranda-lambert-new-husband-brendan-mcloughlin-what-to-know/amp/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://eonline.com/news/1015921/miranda-lambert-got-married-see-other-top-secret-celebrity-weddings |title=Miranda Lambert Got Married! See Other Top-Secret Celebrity Weddings |last=Grossman |first=Janine |date=2019-02-17 |access-date=2019-02-18 |archive-date=February 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190218040832/https://www.eonline.com/news/1015921/miranda-lambert-got-married-see-other-top-secret-celebrity-weddings |url-status=live }}</ref>

Lambert has nine tattoos of various objects and symbols, and the word "tumbleweed." In October 2018, she added a queen of hearts tattoo on her forearm.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/g30428263/miranda-lambert-tattoos/|title=Miranda Lambert Has a Ton of Tattoos and We Need to Discuss Them|last=Bonner|first=Mehera|date=2020-01-07|work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|language=en-US|access-date=2020-01-14|archive-date=January 14, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200114221606/https://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/g30428263/miranda-lambert-tattoos/|url-status=live}}</ref>

==Discography==
{{Main|Miranda Lambert discography}}
'''Studio albums'''

==Awards==
{{main|List of awards and nominations received by Miranda Lambert}}
In April 2018, Lambert won the [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Award]] for Female Vocalist of the Year for the ninth consecutive year, surpassing [[Reba McEntire]] as the most awarded in the category in 2017.<ref name="hdd4-3-17">{{cite web|author=Grein, Paul|title=10 FACTS ABOUT THE ACM AWARD WINNERS THAT YOU NEED TO KNOW|work=[[Hits (magazine)|Hits]]|url=http://hitsdailydouble.com/news&id=305749|date=April 3, 2017|access-date=April 4, 2017|archive-date=April 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404215522/http://hitsdailydouble.com/news%26id%3D305749|url-status=live}}</ref> In November 2015 she became the first woman to have won the [[Country Music Association Awards]]' Album of the Year twice.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/miranda-lambert-platinum-album-of-the-year-cma-awards-20141105|title=Miranda Lambert Wins CMA Album of the Year – Rolling Stone|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=November 6, 2014|access-date=November 7, 2014|archive-date=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618025644/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/miranda-lambert-platinum-album-of-the-year-cma-awards-20141105|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chi-cma-awards-20141105-story.html|title=Miranda Lambert, Luke Bryan win big at country music awards|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 6, 2014|access-date=November 7, 2014|archive-date=November 6, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106115945/http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chi-cma-awards-20141105-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref> She has won three [[Grammy Award]]s out of 27 nominations. and was the ninth female artist in the show's history to win Entertainer of the Year at the 2022 ACM Awards.
