===EPs===
* ''Vegas'' (out of print)  **Cassette only
* ''Troubles Up and Down the Road'' (2001) (out of print)
* ''The Webcor Sessions'' (2002) (out of print)
* ''NapsterLife 09/29/2004'' (2004)
* ''Down Home Girl'' (2006) Three-track single featuring previously unreleased song "Fall on my Knees"
* ''World Cafe Live from iTunes'' (2006) Broadcast on NPR's ''World Cafe'' October 25, 2006
* ''Caroline'' (2008) Nettwerk – Three track single featuring previously unreleased song "Back to New Orleans"
* ''Carry Me Back to Virginia'' (2013) Three track single featuring a cover of "[[Dixieland Delight]]" by [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]
* ''Brushy Mountain Conjugal Trailer'' (2015) Four track single featuring the previously unreleased "Mother Church", a live version of "The Warden", and "I Done Wrong Blues" (previously released as a B-Side on the "Sweet Amarillo" 7").

===Contributions===
*Old Crow Medicine Show performed "Take 'Em Away" (by Fuqua) and "We're All in This Together" (by Secor and Watson) on the [[Transamerica (soundtrack)|soundtrack for the film]] ''[[Transamerica (film)|Transamerica]]'' (2005). The film was nominated for a number of awards — including two [[Academy Award|Oscars]] — winning several worldwide.<ref name=Soundtrack group=w>{{cite web|title=Transamerica (2005): Soundtracks|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407265/soundtrack?ref_=tt_trv_snd|publisher=IMDb.com|access-date=18 October 2013}}</ref>
*They perform [[Woody Guthrie]]'s "[[Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)]]" (Disc 2/Track 15) on ''[[Song of America (album)|Song of America]]'' (2007), a 3-CD set tracing the history of the U.S. through new versions of songs by major artists. Produced by Split Rock Records/Thirty One Tigers. Proceeds benefit the [[Center for American Music]], [[National History Day]], and [[Folk Alliance]].<ref name="Official Website" group=w/>
*Secor wrote, arranged, and performs "Send No Angels" with Lani Marsh on ''Our Christmas Present: 2008'', a fundraising album for [[Our Community Place]] in Harrisonburg, Virginia as a favor to founder/director Ron Copeland, who was owner of Little Grill when/where his and Fuqua's music careers began.<ref name=Farrand>{{cite news|last=Farrand|first=Michael J.|title=Hometown Boys Make Good|url=http://www.ourcommunityplace.org/media/newsletters/2012/02_February.pdf|newspaper=Our Community Place Newsletter|date=February 2012|issue=23}}{{Dead link|date=July 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>{{rp|4b}}<ref name=Mateer group=i>{{cite news|last=Mateer|first=Chris|title=Interview: Ketch, Critter, & Morgan of Old Crow Medicine Show Discuss "Carry Me Back"|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-ketch-critter-morgan-of-old-crow-medicine-show-discuss|access-date=26 October 2013|newspaper=No Depression|date=16 July 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.today/20131026154326/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-ketch-critter-morgan-of-old-crow-medicine-show-discuss|archive-date=October 26, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
*The group recorded "[[Angel From Montgomery]]" for ''[[Broken Hearts & Dirty Windows: Songs of John Prine]]'' (2010), an album celebrating Prine's rich and influential catalog, joining other artists contributing such as [[Justin Vernon]] of [[Bon Iver]], [[My Morning Jacket]], [[Josh Ritter]], [[The Avett Brothers]], [[Conor Oberst & The Mystic Valley Band]], [[Drive-By Truckers]], [[Lambchop (band)|Lambchop]], and [[Justin Townes Earle]].<ref name=Prine group=w>{{cite web|title=Broken Hearts & Dirty Windows: Songs of John Prine|url=http://www.brokenheartsanddirtywindows.com/about.html|work=About|publisher=Oh Boy Records|access-date=27 October 2013}}</ref>
*The group appear on "veteran roots/Americana band" [[Marley's Ghost]] album ''Jubilee'', released June 2012 on [[Sage Arts]], celebrating their 25th anniversary. Recorded at Nashville's [[Sound Emporium]] and produced by [[Cowboy Jack Clement]], the album features other "full-on collaborations between the band and their friends" such as [[Emmylou Harris]], [[John Prine]], [[Marty Stuart]], and [[Larry Campbell]]. The album cover a wide variety of classic American songwriters including [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Levon Helm]], [[Bobby Womack|Bobby and Shirley Womack]], and [[John Prine]] "alongside a half-dozen original compositions."<ref>"[http://www.jambands.com/news/2012/03/29/new-marley-s-ghost-album-features-emmylou-harris-john-prine-old-crow-medicine-show-larry-campbell-and-more New Marley's Ghost Album Features Emmylou Harris, John Prine, Old Crow Medicine Show, Larry Campbell and More]" posted 2012/03/29 at jambands.com.</ref>
*The group performs "[[Back Home Again (song)|Back Home Again]]" (track 6) on ''[[The Music Is You: A Tribute to John Denver]]'' (2013) on ATO Records, an album spotlighting "Denver's folky, sentimental songs done by popular and generally fashionable artists", including [[My Morning Jacket]], [[Brandi Carlile]], Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros, Dave Matthews, [[Lucinda Williams]], and [[Josh Ritter]].<ref name=Oksenhorn>{{cite news|last=Oksenhorn|first=Stewart|title=Stars line up for John Denver tribute album|url=http://www.aspentimes.com/article/20121105/NEWS/121109923/1077&ParentProfile=1058|access-date=5 November 2012|newspaper=The Aspen Times|date=November 5, 2012}}</ref>
*They have a song about how all creatures talk called "Creature Talks"<ref>{{Citation |title=Old Crow Medicine Show {{!}} Creature Talk {{!}} PBS KIDS |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QDQB7b1FHaQ |language=en |access-date=2022-06-28}}</ref> and "Wonder Why"<ref>{{Citation |title=Old Crow Medicine Show {{!}} Wonder Why {{!}} PBS KIDS |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BEARfy9ZW9k |language=en |access-date=2022-06-28}}</ref> about some of the world's biggest questions to [[PBS Kids]].
*The group collaborated with [[Marty Stuart]] on a cover of "I Can See For Miles" for his album ''Compadres: An Anthology of Duets'' in 2007.<ref>{{Citation |title=Marty Stuart - Compadres: An Anthology of Duets Album Reviews, Songs & More {{!}} AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/compadres-an-anthology-of-duets-mw0000777125 |language=en |access-date=2022-06-28}}</ref>
*They contributed a cover of "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)" to the ''Song of America'' folk music compilation album.<ref>{{Citation |last1=The Blind Boys of Alabama |title=Song of America |date=2007 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Song-America-Blind-Boys-Alabama/dp/B000T3GK8O |publisher=Thirty One Tigers |language=English |access-date=2022-06-28 |last2=Elizabeth Cook and The Grascals |last3=The Del McCoury Band |last4=Martha Wainright}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Reno Collects the History of America Through Song |language=en |work=NPR.org |url=https://www.npr.org/2007/07/06/11783231/reno-collects-the-history-of-america-through-song |access-date=2022-06-28}}</ref>
*The group contributed two songs to the 2013 album ''Woody Guthrie: at 100! Live At The Kennedy Center'', including "Howdi Do" and "Union Maid."<ref>{{Citation |title=Woody Guthrie: At 100! Live At The Kennedy Center |date=2013 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Woody-Guthrie-Live-Kennedy-Center/dp/B00CBG9SHM |publisher=Legacy Recordings |access-date=2022-06-28}}</ref>
*For ATO Records' 2013 compilation album ''Divided & United: The Songs of the Civil War'', the group contributed the track "Marching Through Georgia."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divided & United: The Songs of the Civil War |url=https://atorecords.com/releases/divided-united-the-songs-of-the-civil-war/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=ATO RECORDS}}</ref>
*In 2013, Old Crow contributed a cover of "Dixieland Delight" for the 40th Anniversary tribute album for country group [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2013-07-24 |title=Jason Isbell, Old Crow Medicine Show & More Pay Tribute to Alabama on High Cotton |url=https://americansongwriter.com/jason-isbell-old-crow-medicine-show-more-pay-tribute-to-alabama-on-high-cotton/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=American Songwriter |language=en-US}}</ref>
*The group contributed the song "Short Life Of Trouble" to the 2015 Ralph Stanley & Friends album ''Man of Constant Sorrow''.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2015-01-19 |title=Man Of Constant Sorrow - Ralph Stanley & Friends |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/man-of-constant-sorrow-ralph-stanley-friends/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=Bluegrass Today |language=en-US}}</ref>
*[[Keb' Mo']] and Old Crow Medicine Show teamed up for the song "Medicine Man" in 2021, which was inspired by the pandemic.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Paulson |first=Dave |title=Keb' Mo' and Old Crow Medicine Show team up for pandemic-inspired song, 'Medicine Man' |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/03/24/keb-mo-and-old-crow-medicine-show-team-up-pandemic-inspired-song-medicine-man/6982971002/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}}</ref>
*In 2020, Old Crow were featured on the new [[Sara Evans]] album ''Copy That'' for the cover of "I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Moore |first=Bobby |date=2020-03-20 |title=Sara Evans Announces New Album 'Copy That,' Featuring Old Crow Medicine Show + More |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/sara-evans-copy-that/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=Wide Open Country |language=en-US}}</ref>
*The group was featured on the song "Big Backyard" on [[Molly Tuttle]]'s 2022 album ''Crooked Tree''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Sacher |first=Andrew |title=Molly Tuttle preps LP ft. Margo Price, Gillian Welch, Old Crow Medicine Show & more, touring |url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/molly-tuttle-preps-lp-ft-margo-price-gillian-welch-old-crow-medicine-show-more-touring/ |access-date=2022-06-28 |website=BrooklynVegan |date=March 21, 2022 |language=en}}</ref>

===Solo===

*In 2007, Gill Landry released a solo album titled ''[[The Ballad of Lawless Soirez]]'' on Nettwerk.<ref name=pmatters group=r>{{cite web|last=Danielsen|first=Aarik|title=Gill Landry: The Ballad of Lawless Soirez|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/gill-landry-the-ballad-of-lawless-soirez|work=[[PopMatters]]|access-date=4 April 2011}}</ref>
*In Spring/Summer of 2010, Landry released his second solo album titled ''[[Piety & Desire]]'', which features the [[Felice Brothers]], [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Jolie Holland]], Ketch Secor, and Samantha Parton (of the [[Be Good Tanyas]]).<ref name=Ritter group=r>{{cite web|last=Ritter|first=Mitch|title=Gill Landry, Piety & Desire|url=http://driftwoodmagazine.wordpress.com/2011/10/18/feature-review-gill-landry-piety-desire/|work=Feature Review (18 October 2011)|date=October 18, 2011|publisher=Driftwood|access-date=20 October 2013}}</ref>
*On March 3, 2015 Landry released a self-titled album through ATO Records, his third solo effort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://atorecords.shop.musictoday.com/content/mlp/154/gilllandry/index.html |title=Gill Landry Pre-Order |publisher=Atorecords.shop.musictoday.com |date=2015-03-03 |access-date=2015-04-30}}</ref>

{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name = Robbie Fulks
| background = solo_singer
| image = Robbie-fulks.jpg
| image_size  = 
| caption = Fulks in 2011
| birth_name = Robert William Fulks<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/890366043 |title=A MIRACLE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023 |archive-date=March 30, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330145422/https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/890366043 |url-status=live }}</ref>
| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|03|25|mf=y}}
| birth_place = [[York, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States|U.S.]]
|origin = [[North Carolina]]
| genre = Singer-songwriter<br/>Neo-traditionalist country<br/>[[Alternative country]]<br/>[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]
| occupation = Singer-songwriter
| instrument = Guitar, vocals, banjo
| years_active = 1986–present
| label = Boondoggle Records<br/>[[Bloodshot Records]]<br/>[[Yep Roc Records]]<br/>[[Geffen Records]]
| associated_acts = [[Nora O'Connor]]
| website = {{URL|robbiefulks.com|RobbieFulks.com}}
| current_members = Chris Scruggs<br/>Jenny Scheinman<br/>Robbie Gjersoe
}}

'''Robert William "Robbie" Fulks''' (born March 25, 1963) is an American [[alternative country]] singer-songwriter, instrumentalist and long-time resident of [[Chicago, Illinois]].<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001>{{cite journal|last1=Margasak|first1=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks: Country Without Borders|journal=Journal of Country Music|date=5 June 2003|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]]|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160503175907/http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=HuffPo-GoneAwayBackward-2013>{{cite news|last1=Bellware|first1=Kim|title=Robbie Fulks Talks Dinner Guests, Baseball Bullies And Making Country Music As A City-Dweller|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=6 September 2013|access-date=27 December 2013|archive-date=28 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228061723/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|url-status=live}}</ref> He has released 15 albums over a career spanning more than 30 years.<ref name=LastCall-GoneAwayBackward-2013>{{cite news|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|work=[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]|date=12 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122202334/http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|archive-date=22 January 2014}}</ref> His 2016 record ''[[Upland Stories]]'' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] and the song "Alabama at Night" was nominated for a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]].<ref name=LATimes-GrammyAwardNominees-2016>{{cite news|title=2017 Grammy Awards: Complete list of nominees|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=6 December 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=14 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170114165448/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Early life ==
Fulks was born in [[York, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Pennsylvania]], the son of a school teacher father. He grew up in small towns in southeastern [[Pennsylvania]], the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] area of [[Virginia]], and the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] region of [[North Carolina]]. Fulks's family moved often when he was young, eventually settling in North Carolina when he was 12, and Fulks considers North Carolina his childhood home.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Shannon|title=A Chat with Robbie Fulks: Country's Kingpin of Clever|url=http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|work=Outlaw Magazine|date=24 June 2012|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220131127/http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|url-status=live}}</ref> He has a younger brother named Jubal.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 />

Fulks was exposed to music through his family in which everyone played a different musical instrument, from his Aunt Stella on banjo, his Aunt Mildred on violin and his mother on autoharp, to his father playing guitar.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /><ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012 /><ref name=ChiTonight-2014>{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|work=WTTW Chicago Tonight|format=TV interview|date=9 January 2014|access-date=10 January 2014|archive-date=10 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110214253/http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|url-status=live}}</ref>  Fulks picked up his aunt's banjo when he was six and started playing guitar at age 11.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /><ref name=IndyWeek-UplandStories-2016>{{cite news|last1=Schram|first1=Dan|title=Video: Robbie Fulks Returns to Durham with New Autobiographical Songs|url=http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|work=[[Indy Week]]|date=23 June 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220113134/http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|url-status=live}}</ref>

He graduated from [[Carolina Friends School]]<ref name=IndyWeek-UplandStories-2016 /> in 1980 at the age of 17 and moved to New York City, where he attended [[Columbia College, Columbia University]] with the class of 1984.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012/><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2020-08-06 |title=Take Five with Adam Van Doren '84, GSAPP'89 |url=https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |access-date=2022-06-01 |website=Columbia College Today |language=en |archive-date=2022-06-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601091632/https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Career ==
While at [[Columbia University]], Fulks often played at [[Gerdes Folk City]] and other places in [[Greenwich Village]].<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012/> He also performed on campus in places such as the [[Postcrypt Coffeehouse]].<ref name=":0" /> He eventually dropped out of college after two years to pursue music full time.<ref name=NYT-2000 />

=== Chicago ===
Fulks moved to Chicago in 1983 and started teaching at Chicago's [[Old Town School of Folk Music]].<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /> In 1987, he joined [[The Special Consensus]] Bluegrass Band, where he showcased his unique guitar flatpicking style. In the early 1990s he performed in the musical ''Woody Guthrie's American Song''.<ref name=allmusic-bio>{{cite web|last=Huey|first=Steve|title=Robbie Fulks – Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|work=All Music|publisher=All Media Network, LLC.|access-date=December 28, 2013|archive-date=November 23, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123013204/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|url-status=live}}</ref>

He also recorded his original compositions. Many of his early tracks were engineered by [[Steve Albini]], and the Chicago punk-country label [[Bloodshot Records]] began releasing them in 1993.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012 /><ref name=Trib-2011-Honest /><ref name=NoDep-LindaRay1997>{{cite journal|last=Ray|first=Linda|title=The Long Way Around – Feature: Robbie Fulks|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606041414/http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-date=June 6, 2013|journal=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|issue=11|date=September–October 1997}}</ref>

=== Nashville ===
While living in Chicago, Fulks worked for four years as a country songwriter, mainly for Music Row publisher API.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /> His solo debut album, ''Country Love Songs'', engineered by [[Steve Albini]],<ref name="allmusic-bio" /> was released on Bloodshot Records in 1996 and received positive reviews. The Skeletons, members of whom later formed the band [[The Morells]], played on most of the tracks<ref name="NoDep-LindaRay1997" /> and [[Tom Brumley]] and [[Buck Owens]] also featured. ''Country Love Songs'' was followed in 1997 by ''South Mouth'', which confirmed Fulks's retro-alternative image.

Fans had grown used to his rough and sparse sound, but his third album, 1998's ''Let's Kill Saturday Night'', on [[Geffen Records]],<ref name="Soundbite-2000">{{cite web|last=Walker|first=Jesse|title=Soundbite: Music Man|url=http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|work=Reason.com|publisher=Reason Foundation|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=May 2000|archive-date=November 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111103225/http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NYT-Dresden">{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Neil|title=A Major Merger Shakes Up the World of Rock|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 21, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116152111/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}}</ref> was different. Fulks recorded it during the spring of 1998 in Nashville with producer Rick Will, and the album included performances by [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Bill Lloyd (country musician)|Bill Lloyd]], and [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]], as well as guitarist Rob Gjersoe ([[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]), bassist Lorne Rall, and drummer Dan Massey.<ref name="CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001" />

Geffen Records disbanded shortly after the release of the record and Fulks, finding himself without a label, started his own company, Boondoggle Records, and released an album of previously unreleased material called ''The Very Best of Robbie Fulks''. He also licenses his music for distribution by Bloodshot.<ref name="CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001" />

== Output ==
{{Quote box
 |quote  = I called it ''Gone Away Backward'' because it's a phrase from the Bible… I stumbled on the phrase later in the evolution of the record when I was looking around for a title. I think it's a nice piquant phrase that has three good, strong, mellifluous words in it. As far as the backwardness of the record, I think it goes backward in terms of nostalgia for the past – bittersweet nostalgia for the past – as well as the recession having knocked everything backwards for people. In that sense, it's not an album about the past, it's an album about now.
 |source = "Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'"<br/>by Kim Ruehl, ''No Depression Magazine'' (September 18, 2013)
 |width  = 30%
 |align  = right
}}
In 2001 he released ''Couples in Trouble'', a dark, brooding, and decidedly non-country album, and ''13 Hillbilly Giants'', a collection of covers of classic country numbers, both obscure and well known. Both records were released by Bloodshot Records. Also in 2001, Fulks was an inaugural member of the judging panel for the Independent Music Awards, which supported independent artists.<ref name=IMA-judges>{{cite web|title=Past Judges for the Independent Music Awards|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|work=Independent Music Awards|access-date=December 27, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|archive-date=July 13, 2011}}</ref>

Fulks did not release another album until 2005. ''Georgia Hard'' on [[Yep Roc Records]] was a return to his county roots, and was notable for its use of long-time Nashville talent such as [[Lloyd Green]], Hank Singer, [[Dennis Crouch (bassist)|Dennis Crouch]], and [[Dallas Wayne]].<ref name=Pure2005 /> He also released a novelty single called "Fountains of Wayne Hotline," in which he imagined the power pop band [[Fountains of Wayne]] having a hotline that struggling songwriters could call for help with their song structure.

In April 2007, Fulks released a 2-CD album, ''Revenge!'' (also on Yep Roc Records), which consisted mainly of live concert recordings of older songs and included some new material. One disc, labeled ''Standing'', featured a full-band sound, while the second disc, ''Sitting,'' consisted of Fulks solo with little or no musical accompaniment. ''Standing'' opens with the tongue-in-cheek studio track "We're on the Road", which describes life on tour and simulates a telephone call to Fulks from Yep Roc Records President Glenn Dicker, demanding a new record and denigrating the sales performance of the "path-breaking, not chart-breaking" album ''Georgia Hard.''

In 2009, Fulks released an alphabetically organized collection of 50 songs via his website, a compilation called ''50-Vc. Doberman.''<ref name="NYTimes-50">{{cite news|last=Ratliff|first=Ben|title=Playlist: Expansive Pop, Hypnotic Jazz, Surprising Metal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 4, 2009|archive-date=April 13, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230413203308/https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|url-status=live}}</ref> He noted that this method, and electronic-only release in general, was not typical of musicians who worked in his genre.<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014" /> In 2010, Fulks released his next album, ''Happy: Robbie Fulks Plays the Music of Michael Jackson,'' on Yep Roc Records, in which he covered some of Jackson's songs as a tribute. He had been working on the album since 2005.<ref name="ChicagoMag-Happy">{{cite web|last=Guarino|first=Mark|title=Robbie Fulks Reinterprets Michael Jackson's Music in New Album, "Happy"|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|work=Chicago Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=May 28, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235756/http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NoDep-Happy">{{cite web|last=Fontenot|first=Elvis|title=Robbie Fulks – "Happy"|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=April 8, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234311/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2013, Fulks released ''Gone Away Backward,'' an acoustic album recorded and mixed by [[Steve Albini]] and released on Bloodshot Records. It was his first release on that label since 2001's ''13 Hillbilly Giants.'' The album featured banjo, mandolin, fiddle, and upright bass.<ref name="Spin-2013stream">{{cite web|last=McGovern|first=Kyle|title=Stream Robbie Fulks' Small-Town Folk Epic 'Gone Away Backward':Newest full-length from 50-year-old tunesmith arrives August 27|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|work=Spin magazine|publisher=Spin Music, a division of SpinMedia|access-date=December 27, 2013|format=audio stream|date=August 20, 2013|archive-date=April 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405042017/http://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|url-status=live}}</ref> He said one of the songs, "That's Where I'm From", was autobiographical.<ref name="NoDep-GoneAway">{{cite web|last=Ruehl|first=Kim|title=Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|work=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=September 18, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235818/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}}</ref> Four songs from ''50-Vc Doberman'' were the genesis of ''Gone Away Backward:''<ref name="NoDep-Dec2013-int">{{cite web|last=Mateer|first=Chris|title=Robbie Fulks Spins His Tale Of "Gone Away Backward" (Interview)|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|archive-url=https://archive.today/20131228182602/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 28, 2013|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=December 4, 2013}}</ref> the title came from the [[Book of Isaiah]].<ref name="Bible-Isaiah-GAB">{{cite web|title=Isaiah: Isa.1|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|work=Bible, King James Version|access-date=January 10, 2014|archive-date=November 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127171900/http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|url-status=live}}</ref> Fulks said that ''Gone Away Backward'' went back to his roots as a musician.<ref name="ChiTonight-2014" /> The stylistic choice was a good fit with the other musicians who appeared on the recording, Robbie Gjersoe, Jenny Scheinman, and Mike Bub. They recorded live without any overdubbing or elaborate production and laid down around 25 songs in three days.<ref name="NPR-WorldCafe-2014">{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks on World Cafe|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|work=WXPN|publisher=NPR|access-date=January 23, 2014|date=January 21, 2014|archive-date=January 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122060318/http://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2014, Fulks joined members of [[The Mekons]], dubbed "mini-Mekons", on a trip to write and record on the island of [[Jura, Scotland|Jura]] in Scotland. The resulting record, ''Jura'', was released in November 2015 and consisted of traditional songs and original songs written on the trip.<ref name="RStone-Jura-2015">{{cite news|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=Hear Robbie Fulks and Cowpunkers the Mekons' Wild 'Beaten and Broken'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|access-date=November 21, 2015|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=November 5, 2015|archive-date=November 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107194607/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|url-status=live}}</ref> In April 2016, he released ''[[Upland Stories]],''<ref name="FunnyOrDie-Odenkirk-2016">{{cite web|last1=Odenkirk|first1=Bob|title=The First Bob Odenkirk Interview Quiz Challenge Show: Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|website=[[Funny or Die]]|access-date=March 10, 2016|date=March 9, 2016|archive-date=March 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311064656/http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|url-status=live}}</ref>  and the album was nominated for a 2017 Grammy Award for best folk album. The opening track, "Alabama at Night", was nominated for best American roots song.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|title=Wilmette's Robbie Fulks up for first two Grammy Awards on Sunday|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en-US|archive-date=2017-03-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316113742/http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Musical style ==
[[File:Robbie Fulks - December 2013.jpg|thumb|Robbie Fulks playing a house concert on December 14, 2013]]
As a songwriter, Fulks is difficult to categorize.<ref name=NPR-FA-2013>{{cite web|last=Tucker|first=Ken|title=Robbie Fulks: Exhilarating And Bitter On 'Gone Away Backward'|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|work=NPR (Fresh Air)|publisher=National Public Radio|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=September 19, 2013|archive-date=December 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226205410/http://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}}</ref> Nathan Rabin of A.V. Club says he "has a genius for twisting and subverting country tropes," and "there's more to Fulks than tomfoolery and glibly satirical lyrics."<ref name=AV-2010genius>{{cite web|last=Rabin|first=Nathan|title=Week 37: Robbie Fulks, The Alternative|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|work=AV Club|publisher=The Onion|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=June 29, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232858/http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|url-status=live}}</ref> Many of his compositions are silly, funny or spoof songs, such as "Godfrey" ("the sickly, unemployed, amateur children's magician") on the compilation children's album ''The Bottle Let Me Down'', while others are serious country songs.<ref name=MemeFirst-Godfrey>{{cite web|title=Godfrey, the sickly unemployed amateur children's magician|url=http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|work=MemeFirst|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=January 13, 2006|archive-date=March 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302090138/http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

His music is widely described as either alternative country or folk. Fulks's songwriting often includes humor.<ref name=AltC-funny-RegGuard2013>{{cite web|last=Varriano|first=Jackie|title=Alt country is funny for Fulks: The longtime musician finally got some recognition with a hard jab at Nashville|url=http://www.registerguard.com/rg/entertainment/30837292-67/fulks-song-music-songs-really.html.csp|work=The Register Guard (Eugene, OR)|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=December 13, 2013}}</ref> Peter Applebome of ''The New York Times'' describes his work as "one part artful country, one part artful sendup of country, and one part a little of everything else."<ref name=NYT-2000>{{cite news|last=Applebome|first=Peter|title=MUSIC; It's Off the Map, but It's His Country, Right or Wrong|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 15, 2000|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144852/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}}</ref>

Fulks has an encyclopedic knowledge of country and pop music<ref name=ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014 /> and has produced a critically lauded tribute to [[Johnny Paycheck]] called ''Touch My Heart: A Tribute to Johnny Paycheck,'' which was released by [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] in 2004.<ref name=Billboard-Paycheck>{{cite magazine|title=Tributes rarely get better than this, a country music masterpiece.|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=August 21, 2004|archive-date=September 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921102403/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|url-status=live}}</ref> He considers himself adventurous, and is always willing to try new things and experiment. "Why not push the envelope and see what you are capable of doing rather than recycle the same old ideas over and over again," he said.<ref name=ChiTonight-2014 /> His musicianship has been called "impeccable".<ref name="NYT-impeccable">{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|title=POP REVIEW; Heartbreak and Wordplay|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 5, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144708/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Jim Fusilli of the ''Wall Street Journal'' suggested that "a world in which Fulks isn't a household name is somehow upside down."<ref name="WSJ-Artistry">{{cite news|last=Fusilli|first=Jim|title=Robbie Fulks Goes Back to His Acoustic Roots|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 27, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232003/http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Fulks often plays at [[The Hideout Inn|The Hideout]], a bar and club in Chicago, and has worked long-term residencies there,<ref name="Trib-2011-Honest">{{cite news|last=Gendron|first=Bob|title=Fulks honest, unpredictable|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2011/07/01/fulks-honest-unpredictable/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=July 1, 2011|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228015028/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-07-01/entertainment/ct-ott-0701-in-the-works-20110701_1_robbie-fulks-folk-music-irish-fare|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="UBee-2010-Hideout">{{cite web|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|title=Robbie Fulks at the Hideout|url=http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|work=Underground Bee|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=February 9, 2010|archive-date=December 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227175711/http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Reader-Margasak2013">{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks revisits a scorned gem by Bob Dylan|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=May 16, 2013|archive-date=December 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229074626/http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|url-status=live}}</ref> performing anything from current popular hits to jazz to obscure country masterpieces. He says he rarely performs his own compositions at these shows, preferring to explore other contemporary music that has caught his attention.<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014" /> His live performances feature improvised rearrangements of his own songs, off-the-cuff musical humor, and covers of songs by [[Michael Jackson]], [[Cher]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[The Bangles]], among others.

Fulks has co-written with [[Dallas Wayne]] and [[NRBQ]]'s [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]] and others.<ref name="Pure2005" /> He has a long-time association with engineer [[Steve Albini]] ([[Big Black]], [[Shellac (band)|Shellac]]).<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014">{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Artist on Artist: Robbie Fulks talks to Steve Albini|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|access-date=January 10, 2014|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=January 6, 2014|archive-date=January 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109020636/http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Fulks has three children, sons Nicolas, Preston, and Tennessee; and two grandsons, Logan and Miles.<ref name=ChiTonight-2014 /><ref name=Pure2005>{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Frank|title=A Conversation with Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|work=PureMusic.com|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=July 2005|archive-date=May 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511153127/http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> His wife is actress [[Donna Jay Fulks]]. Fulks's oldest son, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Nicolas Fulks]], and father-in-law, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Donald Jerousek]], were contestants on [[The Amazing Race 12|season 12]] of ''[[The Amazing Race (American TV series)|The Amazing Race]]'' and were placed third.<ref name=Trib-AmazingRace2008>{{cite news|last=Pang|first=Kevin|title=Amazing relatives: Locals on 'Race' related to alt-country's Fulks|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2008/01/10/amazing-relatives/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=January 10, 2008|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228031015/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-01-10/features/0801080316_1_robbie-fulks-amazing-race-video|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Awards ==
* 2016: [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination, [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]], for ''[[Upland Stories]]''<ref name=LATimes-GrammyAwardNominees-2016 /> 
* 2016: [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination, [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]], for "Alabama at Night" on ''[[Upland Stories]]''<ref name=LATimes-GrammyAwardNominees-2016 />

* 1994: "Cigarette State" – ''For a Life of Sin: A Compilation of Insurgent Chicago Country'' (Bloodshot)

* 1999: "Call of the Wrecking Ball" – ''Poor Little Knitter on the Road: A Tribute to The Knitters'' (Bloodshot)

* 2004: "Shakin' The Blues" (with Gail Davies) – ''Touch My Heart: a Tribute to Johnny Paycheck'' ([[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]); Fulks produced this record also

* 2015: ''Jura'' with the mini-[[Mekons]] (Bloodshot) – [[Record Store Day]] vinyl-only release on [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]]; subsequently in general release<ref name=RecordStoreDay-Jura-2015>{{cite web|title=Mekons & Robbie Fulks: Jura|url=http://www.recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/8208|website=[[Record Store Day]]|access-date=November 21, 2015|archive-date=November 30, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151130093952/http://www.recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/8208|url-status=live}}</ref>
* 2018: ''Wild! Wild! Wild!'' with [[Linda Gail Lewis]] (Bloodshot)
* 2019: "Lonely Ain’t Hardly Alive" - ''Too Late to Pray: Defiant Chicago Roots'' (Bloodshot)<ref name=WTTW_25th>{{cite web |publisher=[[WTTW]] |title=Chicago's Bloodshot Records Celebrates 25th Anniversary |author=Vitali, Marc |date=November 7, 2019 |url=https://news.wttw.com/2019/11/07/chicago-s-bloodshot-records-celebrates-25th-anniversary |access-date=2019-11-26 |archive-date=2019-11-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191108035340/https://news.wttw.com/2019/11/07/chicago-s-bloodshot-records-celebrates-25th-anniversary |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher=Bloodshot Records |title=Too Late to Pray: Defiant Chicago Roots |date=2019 |url=https://www.bloodshotrecords.com/album/too-late-to-pray |access-date=2019-11-26 |archive-date=2020-04-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200428124135/https://www.bloodshotrecords.com/album/too-late-to-pray |url-status=dead }}</ref>

'''Robert Earl Keen''' (born January 11, 1956)<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rose |first=Mike|date=January 11, 2023 |title=Today's famous birthdays list for January 11, 2023 includes celebrities Mary J. Blige, Amanda Peet |url=https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2023/01/todays-famous-birthdays-list-for-january-11-2023-includes-celebrities-mary-j-blige-amanda-peet.html |access-date=January 10, 2023 |website=[[Cleveland.com]]}}</ref> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer-songwriter and entertainer. Debuting with 1984's ''No Kinda Dancer'', the Houston native has recorded 20 full-length albums for independent and major record labels.  His songs been [[Cover version|covered]] by artists including [[George Strait]], [[Joe Ely]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|The Highwaymen]] and [[Nanci Griffith]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Lyle Lovett – Anthology Volume One Cowboy Man |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/8995236-Lyle-Lovett-Anthology-Volume-One-Cowboy-Man |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs – Music Database}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=George Strait – One Step At A Time |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/3611380-George-Strait-One-Step-At-A-Time |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs – Music Database}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Joe Ely – Love And Danger |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/9026871-Joe-Ely-Love-And-Danger |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs – Music Database}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Highwaymen – The Road Goes On Forever |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/4378780-Highwaymen-The-Road-Goes-On-Forever |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs – Music Database}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Nanci Griffith – Lone Star State of Mind |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/1882329-Nanci-Griffith-Lone-Star-State-Of-Mind |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs – Music Database}}</ref> Keen has toured in the U.S. and abroad.

== Early life and education ==
Keen was born and grew up in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], United States.<ref name="LarkinCountry">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=214}}</ref> As a teenager, he was an avid reader who excelled in writing and literature classes. Keen was a fan of the British rock band [[Cream (band)|Cream]], and was influenced by country music by artists [[Willie Nelson]], [[Norman Blake (American musician)|Norman Blake]], [[Jesse Winchester]], [[Foggy Mountain Boys|Flatt and Scruggs]], [[Bill Withers]], [[Gary Stewart (singer)|Gary Stewart]], and [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]].<ref name="skanse">{{Cite news|last=Skanse|first=Richard|title=Robert Earl Keen: A Man Apart|newspaper=Lone Star Music Magazine|access-date=January 4, 2013|url=http://www.lonestarmusic.com/magazine/mag_html/septoct11/coverstore.html}}</ref>

After graduation from Sharpstown High School, Keen started playing guitar himself shortly thereafter, learning to play classic country covers out of a songbook the summer before starting college at [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]].<ref name="LarkinCountry" /> He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in English in 1978 and began writing songs and playing [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and folk music with friends, including his childhood friend (and future longtime [[fiddle]] player in his band) Bryan Duckworth. During his college years Keen lived with future musician [[Lyle Lovett]].<ref name="LarkinCountry" />

== Career ==
[[File:Robert Earl Keen (2).jpg|thumb|Keen performing in 2007]]
In 1978, Keen graduated from Texas A&M and moved to [[Austin, Texas]].<ref name="LarkinCountry" /> He performed in nightclubs and live music venues in Austin, including [[Cactus Cafe]], Emma Joe's, Alamo Lounge and [[Liberty Lunch]], [[Anderson Fair Retail Restaurant|Anderson Fair]] in Houston, and [[Gruene Hall]] in [[New Braunfels]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hodson |first=Christy |date=July 8, 2014 |title=Cactus Cafe & Bar |url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/entries/cactus-cafe-bar |access-date=May 30, 2022 |website=Handbook of Texas Online |publisher=Texas State Historical association}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Weber |first=Andrew |date=July 17, 2020 |title=PHOTOS: Here's A Look Back At Austin Through The Lens Of Photographer Lisa Davis |work=KUT |url=https://www.kut.org/austin/2020-07-17/photos-heres-a-look-back-at-austin-through-the-lens-of-photographer-lisa-davis |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=June 4, 2020 |title=Robert Earl Keen to Play Social-Distanced Shows at Texas Club |magazine=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/robert-earl-keen-gruene-hall-coronavirus-1010093/ |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref> In 1983, Keen won the New Folk competition at the Kerrville Folk Festival in [[Kerrville, Texas]].<ref name="davis">{{Cite news|last=Davis|first=John T.|title=Robert Earl Keen: Can you patch together a feeling that's going to stick with somebody ten years from now?|newspaper=No Depression|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/2005/05/can-you-patch-together-a-feeling-thats-going-to-stick-with-somebody-ten-years-from-now|access-date=January 10, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122100717/http://archives.nodepression.com/2005/05/can-you-patch-together-a-feeling-thats-going-to-stick-with-somebody-ten-years-from-now/|archive-date=November 22, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Erwin |first=Hank |date=May 20, 2022 |title=A Culture 50 Years in the Making: The Kerrville Folk Festival Experience |work=The Austin Chronicle |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2022-05-20/a-culture-50-years-in-the-making-the-kerrville-folk-festival-experience/ |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> That same year, he began making his self-produced first album, ''[[No Kinda Dancer]]''.<ref name="LarkinCountry" />

Following the release of this album in 1985, Keen moved to Nashville with his future wife, Kathleen Gray. He signed a publishing deal, a new independent label deal, and signed with a national booking agent.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sale |first=Anna |date=May 20, 2015 |title=Robert Earl Keen Quit Nashville and Stayed Married |work=Death, Sex & Money |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/deathsexmoney/episodes/death-sex-money-robert-earl-keen |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> While in Nashville, Keen and Gray worked at [[Hatch Show Print]] shop.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Sherraden |first=Jim |title=Hatch Show Print: The History of a Great American Poster Shop |publisher=Country Music Foundation |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-8118-2856-7 |pages=109}}</ref>

Keen returned to Texas in 1987 and released his second album, ''[[The Live Album]]'', in 1988, followed by his third album, ''[[West Textures]]'' in 1989.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sale |first=Anna |date=May 20, 2015 |title=Robert Earl Keen Quit Nashville and Stayed Married |work=Death, Sex & Money |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/deathsexmoney/episodes/death-sex-money-robert-earl-keen |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> ''West Textures'' featured the first recording of Keen's signature song, "The Road Goes on Forever."<ref name="LarkinCountry" /> Fellow Texan [[Joe Ely]] recorded the song on his 1993 album ''Love and Danger'', along with another Keen song, "Whenever Kindness Fails".<ref name="mcleese">{{Cite news |last=McLeese |first=Don |title=Straight outta Bandera: For Robert Earl Keen, music and business coexist at home, deep in the heart of Texas |newspaper=No Depression |access-date=January 5, 2013 |url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1998/11/straight-outta-bandera/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719130938/http://archives.nodepression.com/1998/11/straight-outta-bandera/ |archive-date=July 19, 2013 }}</ref> Keen's own version of "Whenever Kindness Fails" appeared on his fourth album, 1993's ''A Bigger Piece of Sky.'' In 1994, he released ''[[Gringo Honeymoon]]'' followed by ''[[No. 2 Live Dinner]] in 1996''.<ref name="mcleese" />

Keen has continued to write and record music, while also maintaining a prodigious tour schedule.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news |date=June 27, 2022 |year=2022 |title=Live 75 |pages=8–9 |work=Pollstar}}</ref> His 1997 album, ''[[Picnic (album)|Picnic]]'', marked the beginning of his on-again, off-again relationship with major labels (both that album and 1998's ''[[Walking Distance (album)|Walking Distance]]'' were issued on Arista Records, and 2001's ''[[Gravitational Forces]]'', 2009's ''[[The Rose Hotel]]'' and 2011's ''Ready for Confetti'' were released on Lost Highway Records). Keen's other albums include 2003's ''[[Farm Fresh Onions]]'' (Audium/Koch Records) and 2005's ''[[What I Really Mean]]'' and 2006's ''[[Live at the Ryman]]'' (both on E1 Music). The producers with whom he has worked on those albums have included [[John Keane (record producer)|John Keane]], [[Gurf Morlix]], Gary Velletri, and [[Lloyd Maines]]. In 2022, his concert tour was listed as one of the most successful in the world.<ref name=":8" />

His band includes:
*Bill Whitbeck — bass, upright bass, vocals
*Tom Van Schaik — drums, vocals
*Brian Beken — fiddle, acoustic guitar, electric guitar

In August of 2011, Keen was contacted by a member of U.S. Navy about a fan of his, Petty Officer First Class Jason Workman of Seal team 6, who had been killed on August 6, 2011, with 29 other Brave Americans in Wardak Province, Tanji Valley, Afghanistan. Keen went to the memorial service for POFC. Workman and played his signature song I’m coming home. Keen covered all of his own expenses for travel and only wanted to show a token of his gratitude to a fan who made the ultimate sacrifice for his country. {{cn|date=December 2023}}

In January 2022, Keen announced that he would stop touring and performing publicly after September 2022.<ref>{{cite web |title="Time Flies" – A message from Robert Earl Keen |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |date=January 14, 2022 |website=robertearlkeen.com |url=https://www.robertearlkeen.com/news/time-flies |access-date=March 26, 2022}}</ref> His final tour was named the "I'm Coming Home Farewell Tour" and the final leg was played September 1, 3 and 4 at [[John T. Floore Country Store|Floore's Country Store]] in [[Helotes, Texas]]. Approximately 3,000 people attended the last show on September 4 for nearly two-and-a-half hours.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Robert Earl Keen has played his final show. He's not kidding. |first=Josh |last= Crutchmer |date=September 5, 2022 |magazine=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/robert-earl-keen-retires-final-concert-1234586837/ |access-date=September 7, 2022}}</ref> Despite the claims of playing his final shows and farewell tour, Keen proceeded to do several shows in 2023<ref>{{cite web |title=Robert Earl Keen Isn't Un-Retiring, But He Is Re-Appearing |date=July 17, 2023 |website=savingcountrymusic.com |url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/robert-earl-keen-isnt-un-retiring-but-he-is-re-appearing/ |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref> and lists a 2024 tour on his website<ref>{{cite web |title="Robert Earl Keen" |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |website=robertearlkeen.com |url=https://www.robertearlkeen.com/tour |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref> with a dozen stops. Instagram posts on Keen's account containing photos from his "I'm Coming Home Farewell Tour" were later edited to remove reference to the "farewell" part of the tour.<ref>{{cite web |title="Robert Earl Keen" |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |website=instagram.com |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Ch-G10grelV/ |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref>

'''Rosie Flores''' (born '''Rosalie Flores'''; September 10, 1950)<ref name=Manheim/> is an American singer, songwriter and musician. She currently resides in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas, where August 31 was declared Rosie Flores Day by the Austin City Council in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austintexas.gov/search404|title=Search Results – AustinTexas.gov – The Official Website of the City of Austin|website=Austintexas.gov|access-date=February 28, 2019}}</ref>

==Biography==
Rosie Flores was born in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], United States,<ref name=Manheim/> where she lived until the age of twelve, when her family moved to [[San Diego]].<ref name=Manheim/> In interviews, Flores has recalled that growing up, she loved to watch musical television shows like ''[[The Dick Clark Show]]'' and ''[[Hit Parade]]''. She began singing as a young child, and her brother, Roger, taught her to play rhythm guitar when she was a teenager.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hudson|first1=Kathleen|title=Women in Texas Music: Stories and Songs|date=2013|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0292752863|pages=69–73}}</ref>

Flores formed her first band, Penelope's Children, while still in high school in California.<ref name=AustinWoman>{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=John T.|title=Rosie Flores Still Rockin'|url=http://www.austinwomanmagazine.com/articles/rosie-flores-still-rockin|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402161755/http://www.austinwomanmagazine.com/articles/rosie-flores-still-rockin|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 2, 2015|website=Austin Woman Magazine|access-date=March 7, 2015}}</ref> In the 1970s, Flores played the San Diego nightclub circuit and was the namesake of the [[alt country]]/[[cowpunk]] band Rosie and the Screamers.<ref name=Manheim/> After leaving the Screamers, she joined a cowpunk [[all-female band]] called [[Screamin' Sirens]] in the 1980s.<ref>Gary Indiana, "Screamin' Sirens," Flipside, whole no. 49 (Summer 1986), pp. 18–19.</ref> The latter band produced a series of 7-inch singles and tracks for compilation albums before releasing an album in 1987, ''Voodoo.''

Flores's self-titled solo debut came out on [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]/[[Reprise Records|Reprise]] in 1987.<ref name=Manheim/> The single, "Crying Over You", put her on the ''Billboard'' chart for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Arnold|first1=Thomas K|title=TWO SINGERS HOPE ALL IS 'ROSIE' ON THE COMEBACK TRAIL : Flores Comes Full Circle, Returns to Traditional Country|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1987-09-16-ca-5220-story.html|access-date=March 7, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 16, 1987}}</ref> Since then, Flores has recorded ten additional solo albums.

Flores has toured widely, appearing in the United States, Europe, Asia, and Australia, and also performing frequently in Austin, continuing into 2019.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Rosie Flores |title=Rosie Flores: Tour |url=https://rosieflores.com/wp/tour/ |year=2019 |access-date=January 6, 2019}}</ref> In 1995, she joined [[Wanda Jackson]] on a coast-to-coast North American tour,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rosieflores.com/influenc.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909221520/http://www.rosieflores.com/influenc.html|url-status=dead|title=Rosie Flores Official Web Site<!-- Bot generated title -->|archive-date=September 9, 2007|access-date=August 6, 2021}}</ref> and she toured as a member of [[Asleep at the Wheel]] in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2213&dat=19970412&id=JagkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bjoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2228,1441285|title=Calhoun Times and Gordon County News – Google News Archive Search|access-date=February 28, 2019}}</ref> She has also traveled with a concert tribute she created to honor [[Janis Martin]], a program which she performed at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum]] among other places.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rosie Flores: A Tribute to Janis Martin|url=http://rockhall.com/event/rosie-flores--a-tribute-to-janis-martin/|website=Rockhall.org|access-date=March 7, 2015}}</ref> In 2012, she was part of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's tribute to Chuck Berry.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yarborough|first1=Chuck|title=Rock Hall's Chuck Berry American Music Masters tribute: Range of performers paying homage to '50s pioneer|url=http://www.cleveland.com/music/index.ssf/2012/10/rock_and_roll_hall_of_fames_ch.html|access-date=March 7, 2015|work=Cleveland Plain Dealer|date=October 26, 2012}}</ref> Her media appearances include ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' and ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', and she had a cameo role in the 1993 film ''[[The Thing Called Love]]''.

In addition to her work as a performer and songwriter, Flores has helped to revive the careers of female rockabilly musicians from previous generations and to create new interest in their music. Her album ''Rockabilly Filly'', released on Hightone Records in 1995, included vocals from early rock and roll musicians [[Janis Martin]] and [[Wanda Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rockabilly Filly Overview|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rockabilly-filly-mw0000177263|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=March 7, 2015}}</ref> In 2007, Flores brought Janis Martin to a recording studio in Blanco, Texas, to record what would be both Martin's first solo album in thirty years as well as her last before her death of cancer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Janis Martin, 'The Female Elvis,' Returns|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/09/30/161968431/janis-martin-the-female-elvis-returns|publisher=NPR|access-date=March 7, 2015}}</ref> After the project was turned down by a number of record labels, Flores raised more than $16,000 on Kickstarter to release the album, which was titled ''Janis Martin: The Blanco Sessions''. Flores is credited as a producer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Flores|first1=Rosie|title=JANIS MARTIN " The Female Elvis", Final Recording Sessions|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1383637978/janis-martin-the-female-elvis-final-recording-sess|website=Kickstarter.com|access-date=March 7, 2015}}</ref>

Flores's current (as of 2013–2018) guitar of choice is her James Trussart SteeltopCaster.  She uses [[Fender amplifier]]s, and has also played [[Fender Telecaster]]s, [[Gretsch]] electrics, [[Gibson Les Paul]]s, and various acoustic guitars.<ref name=premier>{{cite web |date=January 9, 2013 |author=Charupakorn, Joe |title=Interview: Rosie Flores – Rockabilly Road Doggie 
|publisher=[[Premier Guitar]] |url=https://www.premierguitar.com/articles/Interview_Rosie_Flores_Rockabilly_Road_Doggie |access-date=January 6, 2019}}</ref>

== Musical style==
{{Expand section|date=January 2023}}
According to ''[[AllMusic]]'', Flores's "talent for [[alternative country]] and [[rockabilly]] made her a favorite with both audiences and critics."<ref name=Manheim>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/rosie-flores-mn0000851550/biography |title=Rosie Flores Biography |last=Manheim |first=James |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-01-05}}</ref> ''Nashville Scene'' defined Flores as a "[[New wave music|New Wave]] [[country rock|country-rock]]er".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/music/chris-hillman-rosie-flores-and-many-more-celebrate-the-story-of-country-rock/article_59eb7b22-4340-11ed-9bb2-4b3e1e763e22.html |title=Chris Hillman, Rosie Flores and Many More Celebrate the Story of Country-Rock |last=Hurt |first=Edd |date=October 3, 2022 |publisher=Nashville Scene |access-date=2022-01-05}}</ref> ''San Diego Tribune'' described Flores as a "dynamo of rockabilly and [[cowpunk|cow-punk]]" who is "equally gifted as a singer, songwriter, guitarist and band leader [and] shines whether performing country, rock, swing or any of the other earthy American styles she has made her own."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/sd-et-artscal-rosie-flores-20170626-story.html |title=Rosie Flores, San Diego-bred dynamo of rockabilly and cow-punk, returns |last=Varga |first=George |date=July 2, 2017 |publisher=San Diego Tribune |access-date=2022-01-05}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Flores has revealed that, under pressure from her manager, she had an abortion in 1986, shortly after signing with Warner Bros. She later regretted the decision.<ref name=AustinWoman /> She has never been married, and has said that her lifestyle, which involves frequent touring, makes it difficult to maintain long-term relationships.<ref name=premier />

'''Ruston Samuel Kelly''' (born July 31, 1988) is an American singer-songwriter. After signing with the music publisher [[BMG Rights Management|BMG Nashville]] in 2013, his song "Nashville Without You" appeared on [[Tim McGraw]]'s album ''[[Two Lanes of Freedom]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McKenna|first1=Brittney|title=Ruston Kelly on New Album 'Dying Star' and Why Women Are Superior Songwriters|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/ruston-kelly-on-new-album-dying-star-and-why-women-are-superior-songwriters-720670/|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=February 22, 2019|date=2018-09-07}}</ref> Following a record deal with [[Razor & Tie]]'s Washington Square, he released his debut EP, ''Halloween'', produced by [[Mike Mogis]] in 2017.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|last1=Erlewine|first1=Stephen Thomas|title=Ruston Kelly - Biography|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/ruston-kelly-mn0003058280/biography |website=AllMusic|access-date=February 22, 2019}}</ref>

In 2018, Kelly signed with [[Rounder Records]] and released his debut studio album, ''[[Dying Star (album)|Dying Star]]'', to generally favorable critical reviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dying Star by Ruston Kelly|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/dying-star/ruston-kelly|website=Metacritic|access-date=February 22, 2019}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Ruston Kelly was born in South Carolina and comes from a musical family.<ref>{{Cite web|date=November 5, 2021|first=Rachel |last=DeSantis|title=Tim Kelly's New Album with Son Ruston Kelly Proves It's Never Too Late to Realize a Dream|url=https://people.com/country/tim-kelly-releases-ride-through-the-rain-son-ruston/|access-date=2021-11-08|website=people.com|language=en}}</ref> The family moved frequently because of his father's job, and he lived in [[Wyoming, Ohio]] for nearly eight years.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ruston Kelly Biography, Songs, & Albums|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/ruston-kelly-mn0003058280/biography|access-date=2021-11-08|website=AllMusic|language=en}}</ref> Kelly began playing music and writing songs when he was a teenager.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ruston Kelly|url=https://rounder.com/artist/ruston-kelly/|access-date=2021-11-08|website=Rounder Records|language=en-US}}</ref> Kelly attended [[Belmont University]] in Nashville, Tennessee.

Kelly struggled with drug addiction for years and decided to pursue a life of sobriety following an overdose in December 2015. Regarding his recovery he stated, "I went to [[Drug rehabilitation|rehab]] once, but it was all I could afford, so it was this kind of rehab in North Carolina."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gravley|first1=Garrett|title=Ruston Kelly Went Through Hell, and Made a Few Stops in California On the Way Back |url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/things-to-do-in-dallas-ruston-kelly-at-house-of-blues-on-jan-24-11466424 |website=Dallas Observer |access-date=March 4, 2019|date=2019-01-16}}</ref>

Kelly met singer [[Kacey Musgraves]] after performing at the [[Bluebird Café]] in Nashville in March 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Despres|first1=Tricia|title=Kacey Musgraves on Finding Love with Ruston Kelly|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/how-did-kacey-musgraves-ruston-kelly-meet/|website=Taste of Country|access-date=February 22, 2019}}</ref> They married in October 2017<ref>{{cite web|last1=Milano|first1=Marie|title=Kacey Musgraves Husband Ruston Kelly|url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a25048527/kacey-musgraves-husband-ruston-kelly/|website=Country Living|access-date=February 22, 2019}}</ref> and filed for divorce in July 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/tn-state-wire-music-us-news-ap-top-news-kacey-musgraves-a8974a1f092366423465c88f6237855b|title=Reps: Singers Kacey Musgraves, Ruston Kelly file for divorce|date=20 April 2021|website=Apnews.com|access-date=10 April 2023}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist

| image              = Ryan Adams, Clapham Common, Calling Festival, London (18991066273).jpg
| landscape          = yes
| alt                = A man with yellow sunglasses singing and playing guitar

| birth_name         = David Ryan Adams
