'''Steve Young''' (July 12, 1942 – March 17, 2016)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Betts|first1=Stephen L.|title='Seven Bridges Road' Singer Steve Young Dead at 73|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/steve-young-dead-died-20160318|access-date=August 30, 2016|agency=Rolling Stone|date=March 18, 2016}}</ref> was an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter and guitarist, known for his song "[[Seven Bridges Road]]" (on ''[[Rock Salt & Nails (album)|Rock Salt & Nails]]'' & ''[[Seven Bridges Road (album)|Seven Bridges Road]]''). He was a pioneer of the [[country rock]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], and [[alternative country]] sounds, and he was also a vital force behind the [[Outlaw country|outlaw movement]]. 

==Biography==
Born in [[Newnan, Georgia|Newnan]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States,<ref name="LarkinCountry">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=472/3}}</ref> he grew up in [[Texas]] and [[Gadsden, Alabama]], moving from place to place as his family looked for work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trevormcshanemusic.wordpress.com/2010/07/15/steveyoung/ |title=Interview with singer, songwriter and musician: Steve Young &#124; The Adventures of Trevor McShane |website=Trevormcshanemusic.wordpress.com |date=July 15, 2010 |access-date=March 27, 2016}}</ref> By the time he graduated high school, he was writing and playing songs that incorporated [[folk music|folk]], [[blues]], country, and gospel influences he absorbed while travelling throughout the South. In the late 1960s, he worked with [[Van Dyke Parks]] and was member of the psychedelic country band Stone Country.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

Young wrote many songs, including "[[Lonesome, On'ry and Mean]]" (covered by [[Waylon Jennings]]) and "Montgomery In the Rain" (covered by [[Hank Williams, Jr.]]).<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

During the late 1970s, Young became a Buddhist and a vegetarian.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/behind-the-song-seven-bridges-road-written-by-steve-young/david-freeland/|title=Behind the Song: The Eagles "Seven Bridges Road" « American Songwriter|date=December 13, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191213210243/https://americansongwriter.com/behind-the-song-seven-bridges-road-written-by-steve-young/david-freeland/|access-date=October 19, 2021|archive-date=December 13, 2019}}</ref>

His best-known composition is "[[Seven Bridges Road]]", which became a hit for [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] after including a cover of it on their 1980 live album.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>  Earlier covers of the song were done by [[Joan Baez]], [[Tracy Nelson (singer)|Tracy Nelson]] & [[Mother Earth (American band)|Mother Earth]], [[Iain Matthews]], [[Dolly Parton]], and [[Rita Coolidge]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

In 1984, Young charted the single "It's Not Supposed to Be That Way" on [[RCA Records]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> It peaked at No.&nbsp;84 on [[Hot Country Songs]].<ref name="whitburn">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=485|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> In 1989, Young did a mini-tour in the Northwest with singer-songwriter Tim Otto, performing in Portland and Seattle. In 1991, Otto took the cover shot for Steve Young's ''Solo/Live'' CD on Watermelon Records. Townes Van Zandt wrote the liner notes. The 1996 concert recording by [[Van Dyke Parks]] entitled ''[[Moonlighting: Live at the Ash Grove]]'' (released in 1998) was headlined by Young, although he did not appear on the recordings.

In 1993, Young played a show in [[Lichtenvoorde]], The Netherlands, with [[David Olney]]. This show then was recorded by SCR Productions. Olney's track were released on his ''Live in Holland'' album in 1994.  In 2019, an album of Young's tracks was released, also titled ''Live in Holland''. David Olney took care of the liner notes, and performed on a few tracks on harmonica.

Young suffered a head injury in an October 2015 fall and his health began to deteriorate. He died after a brief stay in a [[Nashville, Tennessee]] hospice, on March 17, 2016. He was 73.<ref name=TheTennessean>{{cite news|last= Thanki |first= Juli |date= March 20, 2016 |title= 'Seven Bridges Road' Songwriter Steve Young Dead at 73|url= http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/03/19/seven-bridges-road-songwriter-steve-young-dead-73/82010980/ |access-date= October 19, 2016|newspaper =[[The Tennessean]]}}</ref><ref name=theguardian>{{cite news|last= Sweeting|first= Adam |date= March 27, 2016 |title= Steve Young obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/27/steve-young-obituary |access-date= October 19, 2016|newspaper =[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>

'''John Sturgill Simpson''' (born June 8, 1978)<ref name=FamilySearch-KYBirthIndex-1978>{{cite web|title=John Sturgill Simpson - Kentucky, Vital Record Indexes|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QKHX-K29M|website=[[FamilySearch]]}}</ref><ref name=FamilySearch-USPR-1998>{{cite web|title=J Sturgill Simpson, United States Public Records, 1970–2009|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/QJ83-DWT2|website=[[FamilySearch]]}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter and actor.<ref name=GQ-3CountryBadasses-2016>{{cite news|last1=Welch|first1=Will|title=Meet Three Country Badasses Who Are Shaking Up the Nashville Establishment|url=https://www.gq.com/story/meet-the-country-badasses-from-nashville|work=[[GQ]]|date=January 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="the-hunt">{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/2053096/sturgill-simpson-the-hunt-blumhouse-horror-movie/video/|title=See Hollywood's Hottest New Star Sturgill Simpson In The Trailer For Horror Movie The Hunt|last=Helman|first=Peter|date=July 30, 2019|work=Stereogum}}</ref> As of June 2024, he has released eight albums as a solo artist.<ref name=Variety-sturgill-new-album-2024>{{cite news|last1=Willman|first1=Chris|url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/sturgill-simpson-new-album-tour-johnny-blue-skies-passage-du-desir-1236026114|title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album, Tour; Says He Will Only Record Under the Name 'Johnny Blue Skies' From Now On|work=Variety|date=June 5, 2024}}</ref> Simpson's style has been met with critical favor and frequent comparisons to [[outlaw country]].

His first two albums, ''[[High Top Mountain]]''<ref name=CountryWeekly-HightTop-2013>{{cite news|last1=Freeman|first1=Jon|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/music/edge-sturgill-simpson|title=On the Edge: Sturgill Simpson|work=[[Country Weekly]]|date=October 16, 2013}}</ref> and ''[[Metamodern Sounds in Country Music]]'', were independently released in the US<ref name=GQ-Warrior-2016>{{cite news|last1=Welch|first1=Will|title=The GQ&A: Sturgill Simpson, Country Music's Psychedelic Warrior-Philosopher|url=https://www.gq.com/story/sturgill-simpson-country-music-interview|work=[[GQ]]|date=January 7, 2016}}</ref> in 2013 and 2014 and in Europe, through the British record label [[Loose Music|Loose]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Rough Trade Shops |url=https://www.roughtrade.com/en-gb/search?artists.name=Sturgill+Simpson&labels.name=Loose+Music |website=Rough Trade |access-date=13 November 2023}}</ref> The latter album was nominated for a [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album]],<ref name=Grammy-NominationsList-2014>{{cite web|title=57th Grammy Awards: Final Nominations List|url=http://www.grammy.com/files/pages/57thpresslist12042014-with_aoy.pdf|website=[[Grammys]]|publisher=[[National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, Inc.]]|year=2014}}</ref> listed 18th on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s "50 Best Albums of 2014,"<ref name=RStone-50Best-2014>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-albums-of-2014-20141201/sturgill-simpson-metamodern-sounds-in-country-music-20141201|title=50 Best Albums of 2014. 18: Sturgill Simpson, 'Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=December 1, 2014}}</ref> and named among "[[NPR]]'s 50 Favorite Albums of 2014."<ref name=NPR-50Best-2014>{{cite news|last1=Hilton|first1=Robin|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/12/08/368731400/npr-musics-50-favorite-albums-of-2014|title=NPR Music's 50 Favorite Albums Of 2014|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=December 8, 2014}}</ref> Simpson's third album, ''[[A Sailor's Guide to Earth]]'', was released in April 2016 on [[Atlantic Records]] and was his first major-label release,<ref name=Pitchfork-SailorsGuide-2016>{{cite news|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/63936-sturgill-simpson-announces-new-album-a-sailors-guide-to-earth-shares-brace-for-impact-live-a-little/|last1=Strauss|first1=Matthew|title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album A Sailor's Guide to Earth, Shares "Brace for Impact (Live a Little)"|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> later earning him [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|59th Grammy Awards]] and also being nominated for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|title=Grammys 2017: Complete list of winners and nominees|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 12, 2017}}</ref> 

Simpson's fourth album, ''[[Sound & Fury (Sturgill Simpson album)|Sound & Fury]]'', was released on September 27, 2019, and was nominated for a [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Album]] at the [[63rd Annual Grammy Awards|63rd Grammy Awards]]. He released two albums in 2020 – ''[[Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 1: The Butcher Shoppe Sessions|Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 1]]'' and ''[[Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 2: The Cowboy Arms Sessions|Vol. 2]]'' – which feature [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] interpretations of songs from across his catalog, and marked his return to independent music. His seventh studio album, ''[[The Ballad of Dood and Juanita]]'' was released in August 2021. Having promised to release only five studio albums under his own name, not counting the ''Cuttin' Grass'' project, Simpson debuted the [[alter ego]] '''Johnny Blue Skies''' for his eighth album ''[[Passage du Desir]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/johnny-blue-skies-sturgill-simpson-passage-du-desir/|title=Sturgill Simpson/Johnny Blue Skies: Passage du Desir|last=Deusner|first=Stephen M.|date=July 12, 2024|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|access-date=July 14, 2024}}</ref>

==Early life==
John Sturgill Simpson was born in [[Jackson, Kentucky|Jackson]], [[Breathitt County, Kentucky|Breathitt County]], [[Kentucky]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sturgill-simpson-mn0003098721/biography|title=Sturgill Simpson {{!}} Biography & History {{!}} AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=March 3, 2017}}</ref> His father was  a [[Kentucky State Police]] Trooper who formerly worked undercover. Due to his father's work, Simpson's family moved to [[Versailles, Kentucky|Versailles]], outside [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]], where Simpson attended [[Woodford County High School (Kentucky)|Woodford County High School]].<ref name=Fader-Freewheeling-2014>{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Duncan|title=Another Country: A Freewheeling Hour with Sturgill Simpson|url=http://www.thefader.com/2014/07/15/another-country-interview-sturgill-simpson/|website=[[The Fader]]|date=July 15, 2014}}</ref> His mother's family were coal miners,<ref name=NPR-WEdition-MakeArt-2014>{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Rachel|title='I Wanna Make Art': Sturgill Simpson's Twisting Path To Nashville|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/05/25/315292234/i-wanna-make-art-sturgill-simpsons-twisting-path-to-nashville|website=[[Weekend Edition]] Sunday|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=May 25, 2014}}</ref> and he is the first male on her side of the family to not work in a strip mine or deep mine.<ref name=CharlieRose-SailorsGuide-2016>{{cite news|last1=Rose|first1=Charlie|title=Sturgill Simpson - Charlie Rose|url=https://charlierose.com/videos/29307|work=[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]|date=October 13, 2016}}</ref>

Simpson says of his educational career that he was "not a great student".<ref name = RS>{{cite magazine|last1=Ritz|first1=David|title=The Fighting Side of Sturgill Simpson|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/the-fighting-side-of-sturgill-simpson-w443513|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|date=October 6, 2016}}</ref>  His parents divorced when he was in the seventh grade. He only "barely graduated" from Woodford High, enlisting in the [[United States Navy]] in his senior year.<ref name = RS/> After three years in the Navy, where he worked in the [[Combat Information Center]] of a [[frigate]], Simpson spent some time in Japan. He later lived in [[Everett, Washington|Everett]] and Seattle, Washington, where he waited tables at [[IHOP]], before moving back home to [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]], [[Kentucky]].<ref name = RS/><ref name=Ky-LongRoad-2013>{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503041607/http://www.kentucky.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article44426604.html|archive-date=May 3, 2018|url=http://www.kentucky.com/2013/05/30/2658698/sturgill-simpson-took-a-long-road.html|title=Kentucky native Sturgill Simpson took long road, and railroad, to Nashville|last=Tunis|first=Walter|date=May 30, 2013|work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]}}</ref><ref name=Maron-WTFPodcast-2016>{{cite news|last1=Maron|first1=Marc|title=Episode 706 - Sturgill Simpson / John C. Reilly|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episode-706-sturgill-simpson-john-c-reilly|work=[[WTF with Marc Maron|WTF with Marc Maron Podcast]]|date=May 12, 2016}}</ref>

==Career==
===2004−2013: Early performances and recordings ===
Simpson formed the country rock band Sunday Valley in 2004,<ref name = RS/> which played at the Pickathon festival in [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref name=AllMusic-Bio>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sturgill-simpson-mn0003098721/biography|title=Sturgill Simpson: Biography|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> He later moved to Nashville, but says he "didn't have the foggiest notion of how to hustle my music ... [it] was a total bust."<ref name = RS/>

Setting his musical ambitions aside, Simpson focused on building a career at a [[Salt Lake City]] railroad freight-shipping yard for [[Union Pacific Railroad]], which he eventually ended up managing. He credits his wife and friends with changing what he characterized as a hobbyist focus on songwriting and playing to convincing him to get serious about music as a potential career.<ref name=CharlieRose-SailorsGuide-2016 /> After playing local [[open mic]]s and gigs, Simpson returned to Sunday Valley, touring and making an album with the band and producer [[Duane Lundy]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Powers |first=Brian |date=2017-07-22 |title=Duane Lundy's Crossfade Moment |url=https://undermain.art/performing-arts/duane-lundys-crossfade-moment/ |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=UnderMain |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rodgers |first=D. Patrick |date=2011-12-13 |title=Sunday Valley, 'Goodbye' [Fresh Vid + Fresh Track] |url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/music/sunday-valley-goodbye-fresh-vid-fresh-track/article_4fb244b8-7e71-5eab-8a52-3629146ad0f6.html |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=Nashville Scene |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=TwangNation.com |date=2011-03-12 |title=Music Review: Sunday Valley - To the Wind and On To Heaven [self-released] |url=https://www.nodepression.com/music-review-sunday-valley-to-the-wind-and-on-to-heaven-self-released/ |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=No Depression |language=en-US}}</ref> He and his wife moved to [[Nashville]] when the group disbanded in 2012.<ref name=WSJ-CountryMeta-2014>{{cite news|last1=Dougherty|first1=Steve|title=Sturgill Simpson Sings Country Metaphysics|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304101504579543640189785928|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>

After going solo, Simpson released his debut album ''[[High Top Mountain]]'' in 2013, which he self-funded, self-released, and had cut in Nashville.<ref name=AllMusic-Bio/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hughes|first1=Rob|title=Sturgill Simpson|journal=Uncut|date=March 2014|issue=202|page=83}}</ref><ref name=Fader-GenF-2014>{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Duncan|title=GEN F: Sturgill Simpson, the Cosmic Cowboy of the Digital Age Read|url=http://www.thefader.com/2014/05/12/gen-f-sturgill-simpson-interview/|website=[[The Fader]]|date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> The album was produced by [[Dave Cobb]]. Among the session musicians were [[Hargus "Pig" Robbins]] on piano and [[Robby Turner]], a former guitarist for [[Waylon Jennings]], on [[steel guitar]].<ref name="Ky-LongRoad-2013"/> The record is named after a cemetery near Jackson where many of Simpson's family members are buried.<ref name=AmSongwriter-ManHour-2013>{{cite web|last1=Inman|first1=Davis|title=Sturgill Simpson: Man Of The Hour|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2013/04/sturgill-simpson-man-of-the-hour/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106192932/http://www.americansongwriter.com/2013/04/sturgill-simpson-man-of-the-hour/|archive-date=November 6, 2018|website=[[American Songwriter]]|date=April 26, 2013}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[AllMusic]] rated ''High Top Mountain'' 3{{frac|1|2}} stars out of 5, comparing its sound favorably to Waylon Jennings.<ref name=AllMusic-HighTop_2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/high-top-mountain-mw0002529932|title=''High Top Mountain''|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> The album's style has also been compared to that of [[Merle Haggard]].<ref name=Fader-GenF-2014/> Erik Ernst of the ''[[Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel]]'' also compared it to Jennings, saying that it had "rich vintage sounds, heartbreaking ballads, and juke-joint ramblers".<ref name=MilwaukeeJournalSent-Review-2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/musicandnightlife/cd-reviews-jason-isbell-alison-moyet-walter-trout-sturgill-simpson-b9927487z1-211021241.html|title=CD reviews: Jason Isbell, Alison Moyet, Walter Trout, Sturgill Simpson|date=June 11, 2013|work=[[Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel]]|last=Ernst|first=Erik}}</ref>

===2014–2016: ''Metamodern Sounds in Country Music''===
In 2014, Simpson released his second album, again produced by Dave Cobb, ''[[Metamodern Sounds in Country Music]]'', to positive reviews.<ref name=Pitchfork-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web|last1=Deusner|first1=Stephen M.|title=Sturgill Simpson, Metamodern Sounds in Country Music|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19386-sturgill-simpson-metamodern-sounds-in-country-music/|website=[[Pitchfork Media]]|date=May 16, 2014}}</ref><ref name=NYTimes-CountryLament-2014>{{cite news|last1=Caramanica|first1=Jon|title=A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair: Sturgill Simpson's 'Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/15/arts/music/sturgill-simpsons-metamodern-sounds-in-country-music.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Esquire-BestDarkestWeirdest-2014>{{cite web|last1=Keohane|first1=Joe|title=The Best, Darkest, Weirdest Country Record of the Year|url=http://www.esquire.com/blogs/culture/sturgill-simpson-life-of-sin|website=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]|date=May 1, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Billboard-Shuns-2014>{{cite magazine|last1=Dauphin|first1=Chuck|title=Sturgill Simpson Shuns 'Tailgating and Spring Breaks' on New Album|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6091967/sturgill-simpson-shuns-tailgating-and-spring-breaks-on-new-album|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=May 16, 2014}}</ref> The lead single was "Living the Dream".<ref name=Paste-Dream-2014>{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106190534/http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/av/2014/02/song-premiere-sturgill-simpson---living-the-dream.html|archive-date=November 6, 2018|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/av/2014/02/song-premiere-sturgill-simpson---living-the-dream.html|title=Song Premiere: Sturgill Simpson – "Living The Dream"|last=Rowland|first=Sarah|date=February 20, 2014|work=[[Paste Magazine]]}}</ref> The album has been described as "flesh[ing] out a deep and unconventional relationship between traditionalism and new ways of thinking," and a departure from Simpson's more traditional hard country debut.<ref name=NPR-GodsDrugsLizardAliens-2014>{{cite web|last1=Powers|first1=Ann|title=God, Drugs And Lizard Aliens: Yep, It's Country Music|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2014/04/17/304075384/god-drugs-and-lizard-aliens-yep-its-country-music|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> Simpson said that "recording and mixing was done in five and a half days for about $4,000. I was pretty proud about that."<ref name=AmSongwriter-MysticQ&A-2014>{{cite web|last1=Trageser|first1=Stephen|title=Mystic Mind: A Q&A with Sturgill Simpson|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2014/07/mystic-mind-qa-sturgill-simpson/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706221912/http://www.americansongwriter.com/2014/07/mystic-mind-qa-sturgill-simpson/|archive-date=July 6, 2019|website=[[American Songwriter]]|date=July 23, 2014}}</ref> The album was ranked as one of the ten best of the year by ''[[The New York Times]]'' writer Nate Chinen.<ref name=NYTimes-ChinenTop-2014>{{cite news|last1=Chinen|first1=Nate|title=Nate Chinen's Top Albums of 2014, With Beyoncé, Fred Hersch Trio and More|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 11, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/14/arts/music/authoritative-albums-from-beyonc-fred-hersch-trio-and-more.html}}</ref> ''Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'' received a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]] in 2014.<ref name=Grammy-NominationsList-2014/>

Simpson made his US network television debut on July 14, 2014, on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', playing "Life of Sin".<ref name=RStone-Letterman-2014>{{cite web|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Sturgill Simpson Makes 'Letterman' Debut: Kentucky singer-songwriter wows Dave with "Life of Sin"|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/sturgill-simpson-makes-letterman-debut-20140715|website=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=July 15, 2014}}</ref> That year, he would go on to play "Living the Dream" on a September episode of ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'',<ref name=RollingStone-Conan-LivingDream-2014>{{cite magazine|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Live the 'Dream' With Conan O'Brien|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 11, 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/sturgill-simpson-living-the-dream-conan-video-20140911}}</ref> "[[Turtles All the Way Down (song)|Turtles All the Way Down]]" on an October episode of ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'',<ref name=RollingStone-Fallon-Turtles-2014>{{cite magazine|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Sturgill Simpson Explores Space and Time with 'Turtles' Performance on 'Fallon'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=October 29, 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/sturgill-simpson-performs-turtles-tonight-show-fallon-20141029}}</ref> and "[[The Promise (When in Rome song)|The Promise]]" on a December episode of ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]''.<ref name="RSMeyers">{{cite magazine|last=Moss|first=Marissa R.|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Perform a Lost Eighties Hit on 'Seth Meyers'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=December 11, 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-perform-a-lost-eighties-hit-on-seth-meyers-20141211}}</ref> In 2015, he returned to ''The Late Show'' and ''Conan'', respectively playing "Long White Line" in February and "Just Let Go" in April.<ref name="RSLetterman">{{cite magazine|last=Moss|first=Marissa R.|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Reincarnate 'Long White Line' on 'Letterman'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 13, 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-reincarnate-long-white-line-on-letterman-20150213}}</ref><ref name=RollingStone-Conan-JustLetGo-2015>{{cite magazine|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson 'Just Let Go' With Super-Sized Band on 'Conan'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=April 15, 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-just-let-go-with-super-sized-band-on-conan-20150415}}</ref> He played the [[Grand Ole Opry]],<ref name=NPR-WEdition-MakeArt-2014 /> and  he also opened for [[Willie Nelson]] at [[Austin City Limits]].<ref name=ACL-WillieNelson-2014>{{cite web|title=Willie Nelson 2014 - 12/30|url=http://acl-live.com/calendar/willie-nelson-2014-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106192157/http://acl-live.com/calendar/willie-nelson-2014-12-30|archive-date=November 6, 2018|website=[[Austin City Limits]] Live}}</ref> In late 2015, he was the opening act for Merle Haggard.<ref name="Boot">{{cite news|last=Vinson|first=Christina|title=Merle Haggard Praises Sturgill Simpson, Calls Modern Country Music 'Crap'|work=The Boot|date=September 4, 2015|url=http://theboot.com/merle-haggard-sturgill-simpson-modern-country-music-crap/}}</ref>

His cover of "The Promise" by 1980s band [[When in Rome (band)|When In Rome]] was featured in the Season 2 Episode 9 of the HBO series ''[[The Leftovers (TV series)|The Leftovers]]'' in November 2015. The first track from this album, "Turtles All The Way Down," was featured in the soundtrack for Season 1 Episode 5 of HBO's series ''[[Watchmen (TV series)|Watchmen]]'' in November 2019.<ref name=Watchmen-Soundtrack>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tunefind.com/show/watchmen/season-1/93019|title=Music from Watchmen S1E05|website=Tunefind.com}}</ref> Simpson also wrote and performed "Sugar Daddy", the theme song to the [[Martin Scorsese]]/[[Mick Jagger]]-produced TV show, ''[[Vinyl (TV series)|Vinyl]].''<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016>{{cite news|last1=McCarthy|first1=Amy|title=Sturgill Simpson Hasn't Betrayed Country Music Because He Never Was A Country Artist|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/sturgill-simpson-hasnt-betrayed-country-music-because-he-never-was-a-country-artist-8105852|work=[[Dallas Observer]]|date=March 9, 2016}}</ref> As of July 2015, Simpson's songs are represented by [[Downtown Music Publishing]]—an agreement that followed his record deal with [[Atlantic Records]]<ref name=Boot-DowntonMusic-2015>{{cite news|last=Allers|first=Hannahlee|title=Sturgill Simpson Signs With Downtown Music Publishing|work=The Boot|date=July 6, 2015|url=http://theboot.com/sturgill-simpson-downtown-music-publishing/}}</ref> in 2015.<ref name="Hyden" />

===2016–2017: ''A Sailor's Guide to Earth''===

In March 2016, Simpson released the first track from his third album, ''[[A Sailor's Guide To Earth]]'', a song called "Brace For Impact (Live a Little)", with the album itself released in April.<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016>{{cite news|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Sturgill Simpson on Staying Country, Covering Nirvana on New Album|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/sturgill-simpson-on-staying-country-covering-nirvana-on-new-album-20160321|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=March 21, 2016}}</ref> The album, which was recorded live,<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016 /> has been described as a "heartfelt"<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016 /> guide to living from Simpson to his infant son,<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016 /> and Simpson produced it himself, replacing Dave Cobb, the producer of his two previous records.<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016 /> It features work by [[Sharon Jones & The Dap-Kings|The Dap-Kings]] from [[Brooklyn]]'s [[Daptone Records]], as well as a cover of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana's]] "[[In Bloom]]."<ref name=NPR-BraceImpactLiveLittle-2016>{{cite news|last1=Boilen|first1=Bob|title=Hear Thrilling New Music From Sturgill Simpson|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2016/03/04/469088013/hear-thrilling-new-music-from-sturgill-simpson|work=[[NPR]] All Songs Considered|date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> ''Sailor's Guide'', which marked Simpson's major label debut,<ref name=Maron-WTFPodcast-2016 /> was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] and won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|59th Grammy Awards]].<ref name=Grammy-Noms-2016>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees|title=59th Annual GRAMMY Awards Nominees and Winners|work=The Grammys|date=December 6, 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, Simpson appeared on the [[Felicity Jones]]-hosted episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', playing "Keep It Between the Lines" and "Call to Arms."<ref name=SNL-KeepItBetweenTheLines-2017>{{cite news|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Keep It Between the Lines from Saturday Night Live|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/sturgill-simpson-keep-it-between-the-lines/3454415?snl=1|work=[[Saturday Night Live]]|date=January 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name=SNL-CallToArms-2017>{{cite news|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Call To Arms from Saturday Night Live|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/sturgill-simpson-call-to-arms/3454433?snl=1|work=[[Saturday Night Live]]|date=January 15, 2017}}</ref> On November 8, 2017, Simpson [[livestreaming|livestreamed]] himself [[busking]] and meeting fans outside the [[Bridgestone Arena]] in Nashville during the [[51st Annual Country Music Association Awards|Country Music Association Awards]] ceremony, as a tongue-in-cheek response to his not being nominated for or invited to that year's awards.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/watch-sturgill-simpson-busk-take-questions-slam-trump-outside-cma-awards-126215/|title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Busk, Slam Trump Outside CMA Awards|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=November 9, 2017}}</ref>

Simpson had planned to take a break from touring for the entirety of 2017 to focus on his family, but reconsidered after his Grammy nominations. He began touring again in May 2017 by playing a show at the Wharf Amphitheater in [[Orange Beach, Alabama]], with [[Margo Price]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alwharf.com/calendar/C25995805D~Sturgill+Simpson+in+Concert.htm|title=Sturgill Simpson in Concert 5.06.17|publisher=The Wharf at Orange Beach|access-date=January 15, 2018}}</ref> He also performed as the opening act for three shows during the [[Guns N' Roses]] "Not in this Lifetime" tour in the summer of 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/sturgill-simpson-guns-n-roses-2017-concerts/|title=Sturgill Simpson Joining Guns N' Roses for Three Summertime Shows|last=Stecker|first=Liv|work=[[Townsquare Media#Web publications and services|The Boot]]|date=May 25, 2017|access-date=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson later stated that he was "talked into" returning to touring, despite his family commitments and feelings of exhaustion. While on the road in 2017, he suffered from a relapse of [[substance abuse]] and [[Depression (mood)|depression]], though after the tour's conclusion, he reconnected with his wife "in a very profound and intense way" and also devoted more time to his children.<ref name="Hyden" />

Simpson helped produce fellow Kentucky singer/songwriter [[Tyler Childers]]' 2017 album ''Purgatory'' after being introduced to Childers by drummer Miles Miller.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-sturgill-simpson-protege-tyler-childers-new-song-w489192|title=Hear Sturgill Simpson Protege Tyler Childers' New 'Whitehouse Road'|last=Moss|first=Marissa R.|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=June 22, 2017|access-date=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson would work with Childers again as producer on his next album, 2019's ''[[Country Squire]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theboot.com/tyler-childers-new-music-album-2019/|title=Everything We Know About Tyler Childers' 'Country Squire' Album|last=Liptak|first=Carena|website=[[The Boot (website)|The Boot]]|date=July 29, 2019|access-date=August 2, 2019}}</ref>

===2018–2020: ''Sound & Fury'' and ''Cuttin' Grass''===
In a March 5, 2018, interview on ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'' podcast, Simpson revealed that he was working on his fourth studio album, and hinted that it would be a [[double album]], though this was ultimately not the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R0IqNaE513w|title=Joe Rogan Experience #1087 - Sturgill Simpson|last=PowerfulJRE|date=March 5, 2018|access-date=June 19, 2019|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> The title, ''[[Sound & Fury (Sturgill Simpson album)|Sound & Fury]]'', was announced on July 21, 2019, at [[San Diego Comic-Con]], with Simpson describing it as a "sleazy, steamy rock'n'roll record". A companion [[anime]] film bearing the same name was also released on [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-new-album-anime-film-sound-and-fury-netflix-861660/|title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album, Anime Film 'Sound & Fury'|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|date=July 21, 2019|magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref> The album was officially made available for pre-order on August 20, 2019, with the track "Sing Along" being released the same day. The album itself was released to positive reviews on September 27.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/sound-fury/sturgill-simpson|title=Sound & Fury by Sturgill Simpson Reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|access-date=October 9, 2019}}</ref> It was released under the [[Elektra Records]] label, which Simpson was transferred to in 2018 following his time at Atlantic Records.<ref name="Hyden" /> Breaking with Simpson's established country style, it featured a fuzzy [[hard rock]] sound augmented by extensive use of [[synthesizer]]s, influenced by psychedelia, funk, and electronic rock.<ref name="sing video">{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-sing-along-new-song-video-sound-and-fury-873939/ | title=Sturgill Simpson Embraces Distorted Guitars, Eminem Swagger in New Song 'Sing Along' | publisher=Rolling Stone Country | date=August 20, 2019 | access-date=July 23, 2020 | author=Joseph Hudak}}</ref> The tracks "Sing Along" and "A Good Look" both featured music videos which included clips from the anime.<ref name="sing video"/><ref name="look video">{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-a-good-look-video-944790/ | title=Sturgill Simpson Releases Anime Music Video for 'A Good Look' | publisher=Rolling Stone Country | date=January 29, 2020 | access-date=July 23, 2020 | author=Claire Shaffer}}</ref> [[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] praised the album as "synth-rock at its scuzziest".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Sturgill Simpson: Sound & Fury|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/sturgill-simpson-sound-and-fury/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Pitchfork|language=en}}</ref>

In a 2020 interview, Simpson described ''Sound & Fury'' as a record born from "burnout," especially in reaction to his 2017 tours, as well as the realization that he had become disillusioned with the music industry. He cut off contact with Elektra and refused to give them any material after the release of ''Sound & Fury''. Simpson claimed that Elektra "[did not] know what the fuck to do" with him, as he created ''Sound & Fury'' to be difficult to market, and left Elektra with a "giant un-recouped debt" upwards of a million dollars from costs relating to the album's companion film, which was similarly hard to promote. In the same interview, Simpson heavily criticized record labels, calling them overly controlling yet noncontributory, and claimed that he was manipulated into signing a record contract by people who were no longer in his life. He also claimed that his Grammy nominations for ''A Sailor's Guide To Earth'' were a scheme for the record labels to get a return on their investment, and had nothing to do with him or his music, referencing [[Grammy Awards#Criticism|frequent criticisms]] of bias and "secret committees" within the Grammys.<ref name="Hyden" />

Simpson was originally going to perform at the [[Woodstock 50]] music festival in August 2019, before the festival's cancellation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://consequence.net/2019/03/woodstock-50-lineup-leak/|title=Woodstock 2019: The Killers, Chance the Rapper, Imagine Dragons to headline 50th anniversary festival|website=COS|date=March 5, 2019|access-date=June 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/31/entertainment/woodstock-50-canceled/index.html|title=Woodstock 50 festival canceled|last=Gonzalez|first=Sandra|date=August 1, 2019|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

On October 16, 2020, Simpson released his first bluegrass album, titled ''Cuttin' Grass Vol. 1: The Butcher Shoppe Sessions''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://consequence.net/2020/10/sturgill-simpson-bluegrass-album-cuttin-grass-vol-1/ |title=Sturgill Simpson Announces First Bluegrass Album Cuttin' Grass Vol. 1 |work=Consequence of Sound |date=October 14, 2020 |access-date=November 21, 2020 |author=Graves, Wren}}</ref> The album features 20 songs, including bluegrass renditions of tracks culled from his first three albums, as well as songs dating back to his mid-2000s band Sunday Valley.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-bluegrass-album-cuttin-grass-vol-1-1075299/|title=Sturgill Simpson to Release First Bluegrass Album 'Cuttin' Grass Vol. 1′|first1=Daniel|last1=Kreps|website=Rollingstone.com|date=October 14, 2020|access-date=January 8, 2021}}</ref> The album was Simpson's first collaboration with [[Thirty Tigers]] (a distribution label for independent artists), whom he began to work with after ending his contract with Elektra.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/2102431/sturgill-simpson-cuttin-grass-vol-1-the-butcher-shoppe-sessions/music/|title=Stream Sturgill Simpson's New Bluegrass Album 'Cuttin' Grass Vol. 1 - The Butcher Shoppe Sessions'|website=Stereogum.com|date=October 16, 2020|access-date=January 8, 2021}}</ref> The album was officially released through High Top Mountain Records, a label that Simpson owns, and it was marketed and distributed by Thirty Tigers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/10/16/924343633/sturgill-simpson-new-surprise-bluegrass-album|title=Sturgill Simpson Raids His Own Catalog For Surprise Bluegrass Album|website=NPR.org|last=Powers|first=Ann|date=2020-10-16|access-date=2021-08-09}}</ref> On December 11, 2020, Simpson released ''Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 2'', consisting of 12 more bluegrass recordings that Simpson was "too afraid to do on volume 1."<ref>{{Cite web|title=Hear Sturgill Simpson's 'Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 2: The Cowboy Arms Sessions' Now|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/12/11/945088769/hear-sturgill-simpsons-cuttin-grass-vol-2-the-cowboy-arms-sessions-now|access-date=2020-12-11|website=NPR.org|date=December 11, 2020|language=en|last1=McKenna|first1=Lyndsey}}</ref> The ''Cuttin' Grass'' series marked a return to independent music for Simpson, who stated "I'm realizing more and more every day what I already knew, which is that I was always supposed to be an independent artist."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://outsider.com/news/country-music/sturgill-simpson-owning-record-label-always-supposed-independent-artist/|title=Sturgill Simpson on Owning Record Label: 'I Was Always Supposed to Be an Independent Artist'|website=Outsider.com|last=Blount|first=Quentin|date=2020-10-18|access-date=2021-08-09}}</ref>

===2021–2024: ''The Ballad of Dood and Juanita''===
Simpson released the concept album ''[[The Ballad of Dood and Juanita]]'' on August 20, 2021. He described the album as "traditional country, bluegrass and mountain music, including gospel and ''a cappella''."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-new-album-ballad-of-dood-and-juanita-1200072/ | title=Sturgill Simpson Readies New Concept Album 'The Ballad of Dood & Juanita' | last=Hudak | first=Joseph | date=July 21, 2021 | access-date=July 21, 2021 | website=Rollingstone.com | language=en}}</ref> It was written and recorded in less than one week, alongside the same musicians Simpson worked with for the ''Cuttin' Grass'' series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/sturgill-simpson-announces-new-album-the-ballad-of-dood-and-juanita/|title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album The Ballad of Dood and Juanita|work=Pitchfork|last=Strauss|first=Matthew|date=2021-07-21|access-date=2021-08-09}}</ref>

In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' released upon the album's debut, Simpson stated that ''The Ballad of Dood and Juanita'' would be the last record he wished to release under his own name, claiming "this is the last Sturgill record."<ref name="RS21">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/sturgill-simpson-new-album-dood-juanita-1214449/|title=Sturgill Simpson Is 'In the Head' of a Cowboy. He Likes What He Sees|last=Moss|first=Marina R.|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=2021-08-20|access-date=2021-08-20}}</ref> ''The Ballad of Dood and Juanita'' concluded a five-album "arc" he had envisioned and previously committed to, consisting of his five main albums and minus the ''Cuttin' Grass'' series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://uproxx.com/indie/sturgill-simpson-the-ballad-of-dood-and-juanita/|title=Is The Latest Sturgill Simpson Album Also The Last? An Investigation|last=Hyden|first=Steven|work=Uproxx|date=August 24, 2021|access-date=August 27, 2021}}</ref> However, Simpson also expressed a desire to form a proper band with several musicians he respects, believing that it would be more "democratic" in terms of creativity.<ref name="RS21" /> In September 2021, Simpson cancelled his remaining tour dates for the rest of the year after suffering a [[vocal cord hemorrhage]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sturgill-simpson-cancels-tour-vocal-cords-1234922/|title=Sturgill Simpson Says He's Hemorrhaged His Vocal Cords, Cancels Tour|last=Freeman|first=Jon|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=September 30, 2021|accessdate=December 19, 2021}}</ref>

===2024-present: Johnny Blue Skies and ''Passage du Desir''===
Simpson announced a new album and tour in 2024, both to be credited as "Johnny Blue Skies". The album, ''[[Passage du Desir]]'', was released on July&nbsp;12, 2024.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/sturgill-simpson-announces-album-name-135752130.html | title=Sturgill Simpson announces new album, new name, new tour that includes a stop at Rupp | publisher=Yahoo! Entertainment | date=June 5, 2024 | accessdate=June 5, 2024 | author=Janet Patton}}</ref>

==Acting career==
Simpson made his acting debut with a cameo in the 2011 indie film ''Orca Park''.<ref name="orca"/> In 2018, he also had a role in the short film ''Black Hog Gut''.<ref name="black hog"/> He secured his first substantial role the same year, appearing in several episodes of the [[CBS All Access]] television series ''[[One Dollar (TV series)|One Dollar]]'', in which he plays the part of Ken Fry, a laid-off [[steel mill]] worker who sells stolen goods.<ref name="orca"/> In 2019, he wrote and performed the theme song for [[Jim Jarmusch]]'s horror-comedy movie ''[[The Dead Don't Die (2019 film)|The Dead Don't Die]]'', in which he also appeared as "Sturgill Zombie".<ref name=ddd/> A short time later, he appeared as a police officer who is killed in a struggle with one of the protagonists in the movie ''[[Queen & Slim]]'',<ref name=q&s/> and in 2020, he appeared in the horror movie ''[[The Hunt (2020 film)|The Hunt]]''.<ref name=hunt/> That same year, Simpson had a supporting role in the drama film ''Materna''.<ref name="p4k">{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/pharrell-migos-more-produce-documentaries-for-tribeca-film-festival-2020/|title=Pharrell, Migos, More Produce Documentaries for Tribeca Film Festival 2020|work=Pitchfork|last=Torres|first=Eric|date=2020-03-03|access-date=2021-04-07}}</ref>

In 2021, Simpson was cast in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s epic Western crime drama film ''[[Killers of the Flower Moon (film)|Killers of the Flower Moon]]'' (2023) as bootlegger [[Henry Grammer]], who was involved in the [[Osage Indian murders]]. Simpson's role in the film was announced on April 6, 2021; fellow country singer [[Jason Isbell]] was also announced as being part of the cast.<ref name="nme">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/en_asia/news/music/jason-isbell-and-sturgill-simpson-cast-in-scorseses-killers-of-the-flower-moon-2915534|title=Jason Isbell and Sturgill Simpson cast in Martin Scorsese's 'Killers Of The Flower Moon'|work=NME|last=Triscari|first=Caleb|date=2021-04-07|access-date=2021-04-07}}</ref>

In 2023, Simpson joined the cast for the third season of the HBO crime comedy ''[[The Righteous Gemstones]]'' playing Marshall, a member of a doomsday prepping militia.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-05-31 |title=Sturgill Simpson Appears in The Righteous Gemstones Season 3 |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/sturgill-simpson-appears-in-the-righteous-gemstones-season-3/ |access-date=2023-08-03 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref> He sang a cover of "[[All the Gold in California]]" that was later released on the season's soundtrack under the name of his character Brother Marshall and the Choir of Fire.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Legaspi |first=Althea |date=2023-07-24 |title=Hear Sturgill Simpson's Song From 'The Righteous Gemstones' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/sturgill-simpson-the-righteous-gemstones-all-the-gold-in-california-1234794169/ |access-date=2023-08-03 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>

Simpson has also expressed an interest in [[screenwriting]]; during a 2020 interview, he stated that he was working on a "punk rock" [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the 1981 film ''[[An American Werewolf in London]]'', as well as a script based on his experiences in the Navy.<ref name="Hyden">{{Cite web|url=https://uproxx.com/indie/sturgill-simpson-interview-sound-and-fury-tour/|title=Sturgill Simpson Has A Lot To Get Off His Chest|work=Uproxx|last=Hyden|first=Steven|date=2020-02-20|access-date=2021-08-09}}</ref> Speaking on his acting career, Simpson said he did not consider himself an actor, "just a creative person seeking expression wherever that may come from."<ref name="RS21" />

==Musical style==
Simpson's overall sound was described by [[Indiewire]] as "a mesmerizing and sometimes bewildering mix of traditional country sounds, contemporary philosophy, and psychedelic recording-studio wizardry."<ref name=Indiewire-Interview-2014>{{cite news|last=Abramson|first=Seth|title=Metamericana: Outlaw Country Goes Psychedelic: An Interview with Sturgill Simpson on His Music Videos|work=[[Indiewire]]|date=August 14, 2014|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/pressplay/outlaw-country-goes-psychedelic-an-interview-with-sturgill-simpson-on-his-music-videos-20140814|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818134639/http://www.indiewire.com/2014/08/metamericana-outlaw-country-goes-psychedelic-an-interview-with-sturgill-simpson-on-his-music-videos-133361/|archive-date=August 18, 2017}}</ref> Simpson cites [[Merle Haggard]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Keith Whitley]], and [[Marty Robbins]] as large influences on his music.<ref name="RSInterview">{{cite magazine|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|title=5 Things We Learned From Sturgill Simpson's Interview With Foos Guitarist|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 31, 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/5-things-we-learned-from-sturgill-simpsons-interview-with-foos-guitarist-20150731}}</ref> However, Simpson is also frequently compared to [[Waylon Jennings]],<ref name=Paste-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web|last1=Lore|first1=Mark|title=Sturgill Simpson: Metamodern Sounds In Country Music Review|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2014/05/sturgill-simpson-metamodern-sounds-in-country-musi.html|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|date=May 21, 2014}}</ref> and his style to the [[outlaw country]] genre of country music.<ref name=Grantland-NewAgeOutlaw-2014>{{cite web|last1=Hyden|first1=Steven|title=The New-Age Outlaw Country of Lydia Loveless and Sturgill Simpson|url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/the-new-age-outlaw-country-of-lydia-loveless-and-sturgill-simpson/|website=[[Grantland]]|date=April 30, 2014}}</ref> Waylon Jennings' son [[Shooter Jennings]] says, "Sturgill isn't imitating at all, and he sounds like my favorite era of my dad, the Seventies, when he would sing quieter and more conversational. That's what struck me about Sturgill from Day One. And still does."<ref name=RStone-CountryMessiah-2014>{{cite web|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Is Sturgill Simpson Country Music's Savior? Not If He Can Help It|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/is-sturgill-simpson-country-musics-savior-not-if-he-can-help-it-20140603|website=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> [[Country Music Television]] suggested that Simpson has "a voice that recalls Merle Haggard [and] guitar licks that bring [[Buck Owens]] to mind."<ref name=CMT-Metamodern-2014>{{cite news|last=Deusner|first=Stephen M.|title=Sturgill Simpson Puts a Metamodern Spin on Country Music|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|date=May 16, 2014|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1727479/sturgill-simpson-puts-a-metamodern-spin-on-country-music//|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205232020/http://www.cmt.com/news/1727479/sturgill-simpson-puts-a-metamodern-spin-on-country-music/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 5, 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Simpson's song "Oh Sarah", from his album ''A Sailor's Guide to Earth'', is dedicated to his wife,<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/watch-sturgill-simpsons-tender-oh-sarah-on-conan-87056/ | title=Watch Sturgill Simpson's Tender 'Oh Sarah' on 'Conan' | magazine=Rolling Stone  | first= Jon |last= Freeman| date=April 28, 2016 | access-date=April 28, 2020}}</ref> and the record as a whole<ref name="Hyden" /> is dedicated to his first son. The couple have three sons.<ref name=WSJ-CountryMeta-2014 /><ref name= CountryStandardTime-Metamodern-2014>{{cite web|last1=Barker|first1=Brian|title=Simpson Gets Metamodern|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=1163|website=[[Country Standard Time]]|date=July 2014}}</ref>

Simpson is a [[Kentucky Colonel]], having been honoured at the [[Kentucky State Capitol]] on March 20, 2018. Rep. [[James Kay (Kentucky politician)|James Kay]] described Simpson as "independent" and "very proud to be from our great Commonwealth," calling ''Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'' "one of the best albums of all time ... pure Kentucky and ... pure Sturgill Simpson."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/sturgill-simpson-kentucky-colonel/|title=Sturgill Simpson Honored By Kentucky Lawmakers, Is Now a Kentucky Colonel|last=Stefano|first=Angela|website=The Boot|date=March 21, 2018|access-date=June 13, 2018}}</ref>

Simpson has been open about his struggles with substance abuse and mental health issues. In a 2020 interview, he said that he had been pursuing his own forms of self-care, including cutting sugar from his diet, racing [[Rallying|rally cars]], participating in [[shooting range]]s, and ignoring news regarding the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]]. In the same interview, he described his political views as not leaning "one way or the other" and classified himself as an [[Anarchy|anarchist]].<ref name="Hyden" /> Simpson also took up [[Equestrianism|horseback riding]] before filming his role in ''Killers of the Flower Moon''.<ref name="RS21" />

In 2015, Simpson denied media speculation that he was an [[atheist]], replying that he has a tattoo of [[Jesus]]' name.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/31/sturgill-simpson-country-music-reluctant-saviour-metamodern-sounds-interview|title=Sturgill Simpson: 'People think I pour LSD on my Cheerios'|last=Hann|first=Michael|work=The Guardian|date=August 31, 2015|accessdate=December 19, 2021}}</ref>

{{Short description|Canadian country/folk music group}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = The Bros. Landreth
| image           =
| caption         =
| image_size      = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels -->
| landscape       =
| alias           =
| origin          = [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada
| genre           = {{hlist|[[Alternative country]]|[[folk rock]]|[[rock music|rock]]}}
| years_active    = {{start date|2013}}–present
| label           = [[Slate Creek Records]] <br /> [[Birthday Cake Records]]
| associated_acts =
| website         = {{URL|thebroslandreth.com}}
| current_members = {{unbulleted list|Joey Landreth|David Landreth}}
| past_members    = {{unbulleted list|Alex Campbell|Cody Iwasiuk|Ryan Voth|Ariel Posen}}
}}

'''The Bros. Landreth''' are a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[alternative country]] and [[folk music]] group.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6327854/bros-landreth-interview "Meet the Bros. Landreth Before Their January Debut"]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', November 26, 2014.</ref> Their debut album ''Let It Lie'' won the [[Juno Award]] for [[Juno Award for Roots & Traditional Album of the Year – Group|Roots & Traditional Album of the Year – Group]] at the [[Juno Awards of 2015]].<ref name=rayner>[[Ben Rayner]], "A long road to band of brothers: Joey and David Landreth frustrated themselves with side gigs before joining forces". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', April 2, 2015.</ref>

The group was first formed in 2013 by brothers Joey and David Landreth, the sons of [[Winnipeg]] musician Wally Landreth.<ref name=familybusiness>"Musical brothers stick to family business". ''[[Saskatoon Star-Phoenix]]'', January 16, 2014.</ref> The brothers share vocal duties, while Joey plays guitar and David plays bass. The initial band lineup also included Alex Campbell on piano and Ryan Voth on drums.<ref>[http://exclaim.ca/Music/article/winnipegs_bros_landreth_announce_let_it_lie "Winnipeg's the Bros. Landreth Announce 'Let It Lie'"]. ''[[Exclaim!]]'', August 6, 2013.</ref> The band has also toured with musicians Ariel Posen on second guitar, Cody Iwasiuk, Curtis Nowosad and Michael Carbone on Drums, and Liam Duncan, Darryl "Duke" Havers on Keys.<ref name=rayner/>

''Let It Lie'' was released independently in 2013.<ref>"Bros. Landreth just 'Let it Lie'; Winnipeg group's new album channels 60s and 70s sounds". ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', September 12, 2013.</ref> In 2014, the band signed an American distribution deal with [[Slate Creek Records]], who rereleased the album in the United States and Europe in January 2015.<ref name=rayner/>

At the [[10th Canadian Folk Music Awards]] in 2014, the band won the award for New/Emerging Artist of the Year,<ref>"National music award thrills Rheaume; Ottawa singer-songwriter honoured along with Shari Ulrich and Coig". ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', December 1, 2014.</ref> and ''Let It Lie'' was a nominee for Contemporary Album of the Year.<ref>"Local singers up for national folk awards; Edmonton's Lappa, Cook among 68 acts nominated in 19 categories". ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', September 25, 2014.</ref> The band was nominated for Songwriter Of The Year and Roots Group Recording Of The Year at the Western Canadian Music Awards. 

The band have toured both Canada and the United States. They attracted additional media attention when American rock icon [[John Oates]] agreed to perform as an opening act for the band at a 2015 tour stop in [[Nashville]].<ref name=oates>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/john-oates-to-open-for-winnipeg-s-bros-landreth-in-nashville-1.3052913 "John Oates to open for Winnipeg's Bros. Landreth in Nashville"]. [[CBC News]], April 29, 2015.</ref>

In 2019 the band released their album ''87''.

On February 24, 2022, [[Bonnie Raitt]] released a cover of "Made Up Mind", which appears on her album ''[[Just Like That...]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/now-playing/2022/02/25/1083127716/bonnie-raitt-made-up-mind|title=Bonnie Raitt's 'Made Up Mind' channels a steady rockin' spirit: #NowPlaying|last=Powers|first=Anne|date=February 25, 2022|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=February 28, 2022}}</ref> Her recording of the song won a [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Performance|Best Americana Performance]] at the [[65th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2023.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2023/02/07/winnipeg-group-humbled-by-bonnie-raitts-grammy-win-for-single-written-by-them.html "Winnipeg group ‘humbled’ by Bonnie Raitt’s Grammy win for single written by them"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', February 7, 2023.</ref>

==Personal lives==
David Landreth is married to Roberta Hansen,<ref name=oates/> an artist and designer who also won a Juno Award in 2015, in the [[Juno Award for Recording Package of the Year|Recording Package of the Year]] category, for her work on [[Steve Bell (musician)|Steve Bell]]'s album ''Pilgrimage''.

{{Short description|American rock band}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name              = The Departed
| image             = CodyCanadaApr09.jpg
| caption           = 
| image_size        = <!-- Only use for images smaller than 220 pixels -->
| alias             = Cody Canada and the Departed, Jeremy Plato and the Departed
| origin            = [[Yukon, Oklahoma]], [[United States|USA]]
| genre             = [[Alternative Rock]], [[Southern Rock]], [[Alternative Country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt]]
| label             = Underground Sound
| years_active      = 2011-present
| associated_acts   = [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]],<br/>[[ZZ Top]]<br/>[[Jason Boland & the Stragglers]]<br/>[[Wade Bowen]]<br/>[[Stoney LaRue]]<br/>[[Mike McClure Band]]<br/>[[Jonathan Tyler and the Northern Lights]]
| current_members   = [[Cody Canada]]-Lead Vocals,<br/>Jeremy Plato-Bass Guitar,<br>[[Eric Hansen (drummer)|Eric Hansen]]-Drums
| past_members      = Dave Bowen, Seth James, Steve Littleton, Chris Doege, Ross Smith
| website           = [http://www.thedepartedmusic.com/ thedepartedmusic.com]
}}
'''The Departed''' (also known as '''Cody Canada and the Departed''') is an American [[Rock music|rock]] band. The band was formed in 2011 by [[Cody Canada]], the former lead vocalist and guitarist for [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]] after that band broke up in 2010. The band currently consists of Canada (guitars and lead vocals), Jeremy Plato (bass guitar and vocals), and [[Eric Hansen (drummer)|Eric Hansen]] (drums).

==Formation==
After Oklahoma based southern rock band [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]] broke up in 2010, [[Cody Canada]] decided to start the Departed that was billed by Texas and Oklahoma music scene observers as a "Super Group." Canada remained on lead vocals and lead guitar and former Ragweed bass guitar player Jeremy Plato joined Canada. Canada recruited friend and Texas based blues rock singer and songwriter Seth James to be co-lead on guitar and vocals, well known red dirt keyboardist Steve Littleton, and fellow [[Yukon, Oklahoma]] native Dave Bowen on drums. Naming themselves "The Departed" as all had left previous bands to join together, the group at first billed themselves as "Cody Canada and The Departed" namely for fan recognition according to the band members in a 2011 interview.

==''This Is Indian Land''==
The band released its first album in June 2011 titled ''This Is Indian Land'' through its own record label, Underground Sound. The record was a tribute album to Oklahoma music and songwriters. The band's cover version of the Red Dirt Rangers song "Staring Down the Sun" was the only released single from the album. Two other songs, "The Ballad of Rosalie" and "Skyline Radio" both charted on the Texas and Oklahoma music charts.

==''Adventūs''==
On August 24, 2012, now billed as simply The Departed, the band announced on its website and in social media that it would release its first original album, ''Adventūs'' (Latin for "arrival") on November 13, 2012, on Underground Sound. Bowen had left the group and was replaced by Chris Doege on the drums. The band moved to an [[alternative rock]] and grunge sound with driving electric guitars and the power vocals of James and Canada. Three singles were released: "Worth The Fight", "Prayer For the Lonely" and "Flagpole".

==''HippieLovePunk'' & Line-Up Changes==
In September 2013, Seth James announced that he intended to leave the band. The parting was amicable; as James said. "After three years of great times and great music, I have decided to take a step down as a band member of the Departed. It has been an unbelievable ride and I am so grateful for the support and love along the way. My last show will be November 23 at Gruene Hall. I look forward to supporting these guys alongside you as they continue down the road."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://newsok.com/cody-canada-announces-the-departed-lineup-changes-new-solo-acoustic-live-album-due-this-fall/article/3883601 |title=Cody Canada announces The Departed lineup changes, new solo acoustic live album due this fall |author= Brandy McDonnell |date= September 16, 2013 |work=NewsOK }}</ref> The band continued performing as a four-piece group.

In 2014, the band finished a new album, ''HippieLovePunk''.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/5-minutes-in-texas-with-cody-canada-20140721 |title=5 Minutes in Texas With Cody Canada|author= Jim Casey |date=July 21, 2014 |magazine= Rolling Stone }}</ref> It was released on January 13, 2015, and debuted at No. 9 on the Top [[Alternative Country]] Albums chart, with 4,700 copies sold in the US in its first week. The sound was, for the most part, still like the alt-rock sound of ''Adventūs''.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://roughstock.com/news/2015/01/32254-country-album-chart-report-january-21-2015/|title=Country Album Chart Report For January 21, 2015 |author= Matt Bjorke |date=January 21, 2015 |work=Roughstock }}</ref> Cody Canada and The Departed, as the band was once again known, debuted a new line-up at The MusicFest in Steamboat Springs, Colorado, on January 8, 2015. [[East Texas]] native Ross Smith replaced Littleton on keyboards and took up rhythm guitars, while [[Eric Hansen (drummer)|Eric Hansen]] became the drummer in place of Doege. In late November 2015, the band produced a music video for the song "All Nighter" on ''HippieLovePunk'' at John T. Floore's Country Store in [[Helotes, Texas]]. The song and the video were dedicated to the former bass guitar player for [[Micky and the Motorcars]] Mark McCoy, who had died in [[Idaho]] in 2012 while on vacation. The songs "Inbetweener" and "Easy" were released as singles.

==''Jeremy Plato And The Departed: In Retrospect''==
In early 2016, the band announced on social media that it would be releasing an album consisting of cover versions of classic country songs. This project was named ''Jeremy Plato And The Departed: In Retrospect'', honoring 1960s era country music with songs by [[Johnny Paycheck]], Stonewall Jackson and [[Charlie Walker (musician)|Charlie Walker]], among others. The bass guitarist, Plato, took the lead vocals and had Canada, Smith and Hansen as his backing on the project. [[Reckless Kelly (band)|Reckless Kelly's]] Cody Braun and Cody Angel of Jason Boland and the Stragglers contributed their instrumentation to the project, as well as the folk singer Jamie Lin Wilson, who sang backing vocals and also appeared on a popular duet with Plato.

==''3''==
In early 2017, Ross Smith left the band and The Departed became a 3 piece set with Canada, Plato, and Hansen. On April 20, 2018 the band released the single "Lipstick" from their new album ''3'', that was released on June 29, 2018, by the Underground Sound Label. [[Mike McClure]], who had produced several of Cross Canadian Ragweed's albums, came back to produce the album. The name of the album comes from the number of those who were left in the band. It was also their 3rd album of original content as '''In Retrospect''', and '''Indian Land''' had both been cover albums.

==Current==
Due to the band's current lineup, several popular Cross Canadian Ragweed songs have made their way back into the Departed's nightly set list in addition to the new material the band has written. Canada said in a 2018 Rolling Stone interview that he was "truly happy with the way the band is now and I feel this is the band I have always wanted, and really deserved."

|name            = The Flatlanders
|image           = Flatlanders.gif
|caption         = The Flatlanders playing a concert in [[Lubbock, Texas]], on June 3, 2009
|image_size      = 
|background      = group_or_band
|origin          = [[Lubbock, Texas]], U.S.
|genre           = [[Country rock]], [[alternative country]]
|years_active    = 1972–1973, 1998–present
|label           = Charly, [[New West Records|New West]], [[Plantation Records|Plantation]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]
|associated_acts = 
|website         =  
|current_members = [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]<br /> [[Joe Ely]]<br /> [[Butch Hancock]]
}}

'''The Flatlanders''' are an American [[country music|country band]] from [[Lubbock, Texas]], founded in 1972 by [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]], [[Joe Ely]] and [[Butch Hancock]].<ref>{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1606/biography}}</ref> The group garnered little success during their brief original incarnation from 1972 to 1973, but when the individual members found success in their solo careers, interest in The Flatlanders was rekindled with the band reuniting several times since. An earlier incarnation of this band was known as The Double Mountain Fork Of The Brazos River Boys.

==History==
In 1972, Gilmore, Ely and Hancock, formed The Flatlanders with each contributing vocals, guitar, and songwriting skills. Other key musicians were Steve Wesson on [[autoharp]] and [[musical saw]], Tony Pearson on [[mandolin]] and backup harmony, [[Tommy Hancock]] (no relation to Butch Hancock) on [[fiddle]] and Syl Rice on [[string bass]].

One of the band's first appearances was at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]] in 1972, where they were named one of the winners of the inaugural Kerrville Folk Festival New Folk Singer/Songwriter Competition.

The band's first recording project was produced in 1972 by Shelby Singleton, the then-owner of [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis, Tennessee's]] famed [[Sun Studios]]. A promotional single, Gilmore's "Dallas", was a commercial failure, and the planned album, ''All American Music'', was all but scrapped, being released only in a limited run on [[Stereo 8|8-track tape]] in order to fulfill contractual obligations. 

The Flatlanders performed through 1973 before disbanding. By the end of the decade, however, Gilmore, Ely and Hancock had all found success as solo performers, and rumors of their earlier obscure collaboration began to circulate. In 1990, [[Rounder Records]] issued the 1972 sessions as ''More a Legend Than a Band''.

The three musicians continued to reunite for occasional Flatlanders performances. In 1998 they contributed to the soundtrack of ''[[The Horse Whisperer (film)|The Horse Whisperer]]'', and then in 2002 released their follow-up album, ''Now Again,'' on [[New West Records]].  In 2004 this was followed with ''Wheels of Fortune'', again on New West. In 2004, New West released ''Live '72'' a live recording of the then-unknown country band performing at the One Knite [[honky-tonk]] in [[Austin, Texas]].

In 2009, The Flatlanders released the album, ''Hills & Valleys''. In promotion of the album, the group appeared as musical guests on the ''Late Show with David Letterman'' on July 21, 2009, and on Garrison Keillor's ''A Prairie Home Companion'' on April 27, 2013.

In 2012, The Flatlanders released ''The Odessa Tapes'', an album composed of unreleased recordings culled from 1972 recording sessions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Song Premiere: The Flatlanders, 'Shadow Of The Moon' |date=June 11, 2012 |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/06/song-premiere-the-flatlanders-shadow-of-the-moon/ |publisher=America Songwriter |accessdate=June 14, 2012}}</ref>

The Flatlanders were voted into the Austin Music Awards Hall of Fame in March 2016. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/2016/03/16/country-band-the-flatlanders-inducted-into-austin-music-awards-hall-of-fame|title=Country band The Flatlanders inducted into Austin Music Awards Hall of Fame - The Daily Texan|website=Dailytexanonline.com}}</ref>
