| associated_acts     = The Bumz, Picket Line Coyotes, The Grackles, Old Government, Clocker Redbury and Dusty Slosinger, The Tinys, Kev Russell's Junker, [[Shinyribs]], The Hard Pans, Smith/Mckay All Day, Fancy Dux  
| website                 = [http://www.thegourds.com Thegourds.com]
| current_members     = Claude Bernard<br>[[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]]<br>Keith Langford<br>Kevin Russell<br>Jimmy Smith 
| past_members        = Charlie Llewellin 
}}

'''The Gourds''' are an American [[alternative country]] band that formed in [[Austin, Texas]], during the summer of 1994.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hess |first=Christopher |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/story?oid=oid%3A78666 |title=The Gourds - Songs of Innocence and Experience: The Gourds Kiss the Winged Life as It Flies - Music |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date=2000-09-22 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> After playing together for 19 consecutive years, the band went on hiatus in 2013.

==Career==
Primarily evolving from the Picket Line Coyotes and the Grackles,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shreveport.blogspot.com/2006/12/gourds-writer-singer-kevin-russell.html |title=Shreveport Blog, the site for imagining sustainable suburbs and a schvingy downtown: The Gourds writer-singer Kevin Russell began his career in Shreveport in the Picket Line Coyotes |website=Shreveport.blogspot.com |date=2006-12-23 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> The Gourds first line-up consisted of Kevin Russell (vocals, guitar, mandolin), Jimmy Smith (vocals, bass, guitar), Claude Bernard (accordion, guitar, vocals), and Charlie Llewellin (drums, percussion).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://holanada.com/recent-work|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124114644/http://www.llewellin.net/bio|url-status=dead|title=Hola nada|archive-date=24 January 2008|website=Holanada.com|access-date=9 October 2020}}</ref> Llewellin was replaced by Keith Langford shortly after the second album was recorded, and [[multi-instrumentalist]] [[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]] officially joined the band after being invited to play on their third album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Articles/16539/The-Gourds-Luddite-Juice- |title=Music News & Concert Reviews |website=JamBase.com |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gourds.org/history.html |title=gourds.org |website=Gourds.org |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wilonsky |first=Robert |url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/1999-03-04/music/glory-hallelujah/1 |title=Glory Hallelujah |publisher=Dallas Observer |date=1999-03-04 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> By the following album, Johnston had also become the band's third [[songwriter]], though Russell and Smith continued to share the bulk of those responsibilities.<ref>[http://www.leisuresuit.net/Webzine/articles/gourds_interview.shtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080319102758/http://www.leisuresuit.net/Webzine/articles/gourds_interview.shtml|date=March 19, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Reed |first=Bryan C. |url=http://www.indyweek.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A18398 |title=Honky-tonk Hip-hop Dreams &#124; Music Feature |publisher=Indy Week |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Freedman |first=Pete |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2008/12/the_gourds_kevin_russell_doesn.php |title=The Gourds' Kevin Russell Doesn't Understand Why People Like His Music Or Why He Has To Share The Spotlight With The Rest Of His Band. (Only He's Not As Sensational About It.) &#124; Dallas Observer |website=Blogs.dallasobserver.com |date=2008-12-29 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref>

Despite a sizable amount of original material, The Gourds are probably best known for a song they did not write, and for which they initially did not receive credit. A recording of the band's cover of [[Snoop Dogg]]'s "[[Gin and Juice]]" was widely shared on the popular file-sharing site [[Napster]], with the song miscredited to the band [[Phish]].<ref name="lieck">{{cite news|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2000-06-16/77606/|title=Dancing About Architecture: The Gourds weren't Phishing for trouble when they covered "Gin and Juice"; the Meat Puppets have (probably) found a new home|last=Lieck|first=Ken|date=16 June 2000|work=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|access-date=17 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eventseeker.com/artist/10060-the-gourds|title=The Gourds - Artist Profile|website=eventseeker.com|access-date=7 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://delawareliberal.net/2019/07/17/song-of-the-day-7-17-the-gourds-gin-and-juice/|title=Song of the Day 7/17: The Gourds, "Gin and Juice"|date=17 July 2019|website=Delaware Liberal|access-date=7 April 2020}}</ref> In fact, for most of the 16 years following their first live performance of the song,<ref>[http://www.discorder.ca/oldsite/features/02novgourds.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201155745/http://www.discorder.ca/oldsite/features/02novgourds.html|date=February 1, 2008}}</ref> fans could regularly be heard calling out for the band's [[cover version]] of the song, sometimes before the show had even started. This led some to consider it an [[albatross (metaphor)|albatross]], but the band continued to play the crowd pleaser, often adding a medley of impromptu cover songs to its midsection.<ref>[http://www.austinmusicmagazine.net/mag-pdf/_AMM-04-07-issue-Web/AMM-04-07-issue-Web.pdf]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713114328/http://www.austinmusicmagazine.net/mag-pdf/_AMM-04-07-issue-Web/AMM-04-07-issue-Web.pdf|date=July 13, 2007}}</ref><ref>[http://www.juneauempire.com/entertainment/stories/080207/spo_20100802024.shtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516044531/http://www.juneauempire.com/entertainment/stories/080207/spo_20100802024.shtml|date=May 16, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://launch.groups.yahoo.com/group/cucurbitaceae/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120710052840/http://launch.groups.yahoo.com/group/cucurbitaceae/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 10, 2012 |title=Yahoo! Groups |website=Launch.groups.yahoo.com |date=1998-10-14 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref>

While The Gourds' studio efforts were generally well received, their high-energy live performances and constant touring earned them the reputation of a band that had to be seen to be appreciated.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://popmatters.com/music/concerts/g/gourds-030322.shtml |title=Music Reviews, Features, Essays, News, Columns, Blogs, MP3s and Videos |website=PopMatters.com |access-date=2016-01-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112030546/http://www.popmatters.com/music/concerts/g/gourds-030322.shtml/ |archive-date=2016-01-12 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tuesday, February 03, 2009 |url=http://twangville.com/1136/the-gourds-live-at-visulite-charlotte-january-22nd/ |title=The Gourds – Live at Visulite Charlotte January 22nd |website=Twangville.com |date=2009-02-03 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/music/entries/2008/04/10/gourds_still_the_best.html |title=Austin Music Source |website=Austin360.com |date=2015-01-06 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://crack.podbean.com/2008/05/14/140508/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2008-05-15 |archive-date=2022-03-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220331120523/https://crack.podbean.com/2008/05/14/140508/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> As a result, they enjoyed a dedicated fan base<ref>{{cite web|last=Moser |first=Margaret |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/story?oid=oid%3A102419 |title=The Gourds - Life, Death, and Shoofly Pie: The Gourds and their Internet Fan group - Music |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date=2002-09-13 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/18/magazine/18wwln-domains-t.html?_r=2&oref=slogin&oref=slogin |title=Jimmy Wales - Wikipedia - the New York Times |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=2017-02-23 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201132340/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/18/magazine/18wwln-domains-t.html?_r=2&oref=slogin&oref=slogin |archive-date=2017-12-01 }}</ref> that was happy to follow them from town to town,<ref>[https://archive.today/20110716051813/http://sharkbitten.com/wordpress/2008/01/16/the-gourds/] </ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Michael |first=William |url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2009-01-08/music/the-gourds-land-a-real-haymaker/ |title=The Gourds land a real Haymaker! |publisher=Houston Press |date=2009-01-07 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> and became a favorite among those who tape live music.<ref>[http://casa-huevos-negros.com/AcresOfClams/AcresOfClams.htm]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120164705/http://casa-huevos-negros.com/AcresOfClams/AcresOfClams.htm|date=November 20, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/search.php?query=collection%3Aetree%20AND%20creator%3A%22The%20Gourds%22 |title=Internet Archive Search: collection:etree AND creator:"The Gourds" |website=Archive.org |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref>

In March 2011, The Gourds traveled to [[Levon Helm]]'s studio in [[Woodstock, New York]] to record their 10th studio album, ''Old Mad Joy''. Produced by [[Larry Campbell (musician)|Larry Campbell]], the record was released by [[Vanguard Records]] on September 13 that same year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Powell |first=Austin |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-03-04/off-the-record/ |title=Off the Record: Music News - Music |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date=2011-03-04 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.houstonpress.com/rocks/2011/04/gourds_levon_helm.php|title=Gourds Drummer Lives The Dream At Levon Helm's Studio|last=Smith|first=William Michael|date=12 April 2011|work=[[Houston Press]]|access-date=17 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/sal-nunziato/get-ready-for-the-gourds-_b_945334.html?ref=fb&src=sp |title=Get Ready For The Gourds and Their Feel-Good Record of the Summer &#124; Sal Nunziato |website=HuffPost |date=2011-09-01 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref>

In August 2011, director Doug Hawes-Davis began shooting a documentary on the band that combined candid interviews with live performances, past and present. Musician and filmmaker [[Brendan Canty]] worked as a camera operator and ran location sound on the project, which drew partial funding from [[Kickstarter]] in 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/225802176/all-the-labor|title=All The Labor by Doug Hawes-Davis — Kickstarter|date=11 June 2012|work=[[Kickstarter]]|access-date=17 February 2014}}</ref> and premiered in Austin at the [[South by Southwest]] film festival on March 13, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://schedule.sxsw.com/2013/events/event_FS13814|title=All the Labor (Schedule)|publisher=[[South by Southwest]]|access-date=17 February 2014}}</ref> The film was released on DVD in 2014.<ref name="pernu">{{cite news|title=Rev. of The Gourds, ''All the Labor''|last=Pernu|first=Dennis|date=April 2014|pages=140–41|work=[[Vintage Guitar (magazine)|Vintage Guitar]]}}</ref>

On October 18, 2013, The Gourds announced that they were taking a hiatus. No reason was provided. Their final show before the break occurred on October 27, 2013, at Threadgill's World Headquarters in Austin, Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://concertblogger.com/2013/10/gourds-announce-hiatus/|title=The Gourds announce hiatus - Concert Blogger Music Magazine|website=Concertblogger.com|access-date=2016-01-09|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112030546/http://concertblogger.com/2013/10/gourds-announce-hiatus/|archive-date=2016-01-12}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thegourds.com/2013/10/21/1142/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022042442/http://www.thegourds.com/2013/10/21/1142/|date=October 22, 2013}}</ref> Despite having only nine days notice, Gourds fans from 26 different states were in attendance, and many more watched from home via live streaming video.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegourds.com/watch-haitus-show-live/ |title=Watch the hiatus show live via Ustream |publisher=The Gourds |date=2013-10-27 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> During an interview the following year, Russell stated, “I think it’s done,” adding, “The only reason we said hiatus was that we didn’t want to say it was done, because that would be final".<ref>{{cite web|last=Wildsmith |first=Steve |url=http://www.thedailytimes.com/entertainment/a-gourd-no-more-kevin-russell-finds-new-musical-life/article_8d0869c7-4d29-54e9-bbb0-d782b2435f0a.html |title=A GOURD NO MORE: Kevin Russell finds new musical life as Shinyribs |publisher=The Daily Times |date=2014-09-24 |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> In response to Russel's comments, Langford stated, "I still wish that someday there could be a project of some kind. Knowing all these dudes, it probably wouldn't be an extended thing. But, some new songs or shows or something".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TheGourdsNews/posts/10202676720711651?comment_id=10202676847034809&offset=0&total_comments=13 |title=Facebook |publisher=Facebook |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> Two months later, in December 2014, Russell seemed slightly more accepting of the idea when he said, "We left it open-ended for a reason . . . I have a little hope that one day we'll get back together and do something".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theeagle.com/news/local/shinyribs-ready-to-groove-grand-stafford-theater/article_18c93c8b-8694-545d-ab1d-dc5abab73939.html |title=Shinyribs ready to groove Grand Stafford Theater - The Eagle: Local News |publisher=The Eagle |access-date=2016-01-09}}</ref> To date, Bernard, Johnston, and Smith have not commented publicly on either the hiatus or the possibility of a reunion.

==Members==
*Claude Bernard – [[accordion]], [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s, [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]], [[Steel-string acoustic guitar|acoustic guitar]], [[Percussion instrument|percussion]]
*[[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]] – [[Singing|vocals]],  backing vocals, [[fiddle]], [[lap steel guitar]], mandolin, acoustic guitar, [[banjo]]
*Keith Langford – [[Drum kit|drums]], [[harmonica]], backing vocals
*Kevin Russell – vocals,  backing vocals, [[mandolin]], [[Electric guitar|guitar]]s, acoustic guitar, harmonica
*Jimmy Smith – vocals, backing vocals, [[Bass guitar|bass]], acoustic guitar, percussion, harmonica, [[double bass]]

==Discography==

*''Dem's Good Beeble'' – 1996
*''Stadium Blitzer'' – 1998
*''Ghosts of Hallelujah'' – 1999
*''Bolsa de Agua'' – 2000
*''Shinebox'' – 2001
*''Cow Fish Fowl or Pig'' – 2002
*''Blood of the Ram'' – 2004
*''Heavy Ornamentals'' – 2006
*''Noble Creatures'' – 2007
*''Haymaker!'' – 2009
*''Old Mad Joy'' – 2011

*''Shinebox'' – 2001

*''Something's Brewin' in Shiner'' – 2004
*''All The Labor'' – 2014

*Bernard: ''The Tinys'' – 2001 (unreleased)

*Johnston: ''[[Max Johnston (musician)|Max Johnston]]: Dismantling Paradise'' – 2014
*Russell: ''Shinyribs: Okra Candy'' – 2015

==Television and film==
The Gourds have been featured on ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' (2006) and appeared briefly playing their song "Declineometer" in the season one "Homecoming" episode of ''[[Friday Night Lights (TV series)|Friday Night Lights]]'' (2006). They were the subject of a 96-minute documentary by director Doug Hawes-Davis entitled ''All the Labor'' (2013).<ref name="pernu"/> Their song "Dying of the Pines" was included in the [[HBO]] Documentary ''Unknown Soldier: Searching for a Father'' (2005){{citation needed|date=February 2014}} and their cover of "Gin and Juice" was used in the season three episode of ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'' (2007) entitled "The Frank Factor". The band has also scored the Mike Woolf documentaries ''Growin' a Beard'' (2003) and ''Something's Brewin' in Shiner'' (2004).{{citation needed|date=February 2014}}

| origin              = [[Miami]], [[Florida]], U.S.
| genre               = {{Hlist|[[Country music|Country]]<ref name="allmusic"/>|[[alternative country]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://seattlespectator.com/2023/02/01/2022-was-the-year-of-queer-country-music/ |title=RAUL MALO: 'I'M NOT IN THE MAINSTREAM COUNTRY MUSIC GAME ANY MORE' |author=Staff |date=December 3, 2010 |work=OC Weekly |access-date=2023-07-25 |quote=the Grammy Award-winning alt-country Mavericks. |archive-date=2023-07-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725234725/https://seattlespectator.com/2023/02/01/2022-was-the-year-of-queer-country-music/ |url-status=live }}</ref>|[[country rock]]<ref name="allmusic"/>||[[Americana (music)|Americana]]<ref name="allmusic"/>|[[Tex-Mex music|Tex-Mex]]<ref name="allmusic"/>}}
| years_active        = 1989–2000, 2003–2004, 2011–present
